title: in god i put my trust
message:
JANUARY 1 Monday

BH 259:Trusting Jesus

RBT: Romans 1-2

IN GOD I PUT MY TRUST

Text: Psalm 56

Golden Text: In God, whose word I praise – in God I trust and am not afraid. What can mere mortals do to me? Psalm 56:4, NIV

Elisabeth Elliot\'s books tell of her life as a missionary and the wonderful lessons God has taught her over the years. But her life had not always been \'wonderful.\' She had lost two husbands: the first, missionary Jim Elliot was killed by the Auca Indians in Ecuador while he was trying to reach them with the Gospel. The second, Addison Leitch, died of cancer. In telling these experiences, Elliot said, “In the first shock of death, everything that has seemed most dependable has given way. Mountains are falling, earth is reeling. In such a time, it is a profound comfort to know that although all things seem to be shaken, one thing is not: God is not shaken.” Elliot\'s confidence in God in the midst of her troubles is similar to the psalmist’s trust in God. When King David wrote Psalm 56, he was in the midst of crisis (cf.1 Samuel 21:10-15). Many take this psalm as an individual lament, but it could also be a psalm of anticipated thanksgiving. The description of troubles and prayers changed into gratitude that God has heard and will act. When it looked like he would be swallowed up, the psalmist trusted God. “When I am afraid, I will trust in you. ... I will not be afraid. What can mortal man do to me?”(vv. 3-4)

Regardless of your previous experiences, this year, God wants you to trust Him absolutely. You may not know what the year holds, but with your trust in the God who knows the end from the beginning, you will have a fruitful year. God is forever trustworthy because He is faithful. Let go of all your fears, and trust Him every step of the way. And He will surely act on your behalf. Have a trust-filled year!

Wisdom : Trusting God brings stability in the midst of troubles.

Food for Thought : Are you willing to put your absolute trust in God this year?

Follow-up Action : Make a list of those situations that bring fear, and trust them to God to handle.

Prayer : Heavenly Father, I trust my life and family to you this year. Take care of us.

title: the lord god defeats baal
message:
JANUARY 2 Tuesday

BH 40: A Mighty Fortress Is Our God

RBT: Genesis 1-3

THE LORD GOD DEFEATS BAAL

Text:1 Kings 18:30-39

Golden Text: Then the fire of the Lord fell and burned up the sacrifice, the wood, the stones and the soil, and also licked up the water in the trench. 1 Kings 18:38, NIV

History books speak of the Six-Day War between Israel and four of its Arab neighbours – Iraq, Syria, Jordan and Egypt – in June 1967. While Israel had 275, 000 troops, the united Arab forces had 456,000 soldiers, with more than double tanks of weaponry and military equipment. But, in a matter of six days, in what many have described as a miracle, Israel routed all the four powerful enemies. By the end of the fourth day, Egypt gave in and signed a cease-fire with Israel. By the morning of the sixth day, the Syrian Army was in full retreat, and by nightfall, Syria signed a cease-fire. Then the war was over. The then Israeli ambassador to the UN said, “I proclaim the glorious triumph of Israel armies and the redemption of Jerusalem. Never before has Israel stood more honoured and revered by the nations of the world.”

The contest in 1 Kings 18 can best be described as the father of all contests – 450 prophets of Baal against Elijah the prophet of God. The prophets of Baal did everything possible to bring fire down, but to no avail. Elijah repaired the altar for a demonstration of God\'s power and had the whole area soaked with water. God sent fire which burnt up the sacrifice, stones, dust and water, showing He is the true God. When you are in Christ, everyone who fights you fights God. And the proven truth is that God always wins. This year, trust your battles to the Lord as you stand boldly in prayer, without any iota of doubt about God\'s capability to defeat the enemies, no matter who they are. Your victory over all challenges and enemies that confront you is sure. As you cooperate with God, He will show the world that He indeed is the real God over and above all other gods.

Wisdom : One with God is a majority.

Food for Thought : Who do you ascribe power to – your challenges or God?

Follow-up Action : Make a list of things that are confronting you, and take them to God in prayers.

Prayer : Lord, help me to trust Your ability always.

title: faithful living in another land
message:
JANUARY 3 Wednesday

BH 433: I Am A Stranger Here

RBT: Joshua 1-5

FAITHFUL LIVING IN ANOTHER LAND

Text: Jeremiah 29:4-9

Golden Text: Also, seek the peace and prosperity of the city to which I have carried you into exile. Pray to the LORD for it, because if it prospers, you too will prosper. Jeremiah 29:7, NIV

The dream of the Nwachukwus was to live and work abroad. When their applications were eventually granted, their joy knew no bounds. Getting abroad, they discovered that life was not what they thought it was. In their new country, many values that they held so high meant nothing to the people. They felt estranged. Going back home could have been an option but for their determination to make it in the foreign land.

The Israelites found themselves in a foreign land, where the language and culture of the people were different from theirs. Instead of feeling estranged, God sent word to them to settle down, prosper there, as they also seek the peace and prosperity of the land.

For the believer, the world is a foreign land (1Peter 2:11) where God requires us to be faithful to Him. Jesus said that though we are in this world, we are not of this world. Our citizenship is in heaven. Our heavenly culture and language are different from this world\'s. But as representatives of heaven, we must be faithful to the Lord. We should contribute to the peace and progress of the world we live in. Pray for the peace of your community and live at peace with your neighbours. Do not be among those who destroy public properties or divert public funds to private pockets. Pay your tax and be active in your community development because the prosperity of your country affects your own prosperity.

Wisdom : The wise work for the peace of their community.

Food for Thought : Am I an active player in my community?

Follow-up Action : Pray for the leaders of your community and nation.

Prayer : Father in heaven, give me the wisdom to contribute to the progress of Nigeria.

title: always live as salt and light
message:
JANUARY 4 Thursday

BH 431: Make Me a Blessing

RBT: Psalms 1-2

ALWAYS LIVE AS SALT AND LIGHT

Text: Matthew 5:13-16

Golden Text: You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its saltiness... It is no longer good for anything. You are the light of the world. A town built on a hill cannot be hidden. Matthew 5:13-14

A blogger makes a list of 30 most beautiful lighthouses, across the world, which have become centres of attraction for tourists. But lighthouses are not built for tourism; they are not meant to be admired alone. A lighthouse is a tower with a bright light at the top, located at an important or dangerous place on waterways to guide ships and warn them of danger.

Just like lighthouses, Christians are called to be light to wayfarers in a crooked and perverse world. In a world of relativism, where, as someone said, \'There is no right or wrong, it is all in your mind, it is not what you do, but how you do it; besides everyone is doing it, so do it\'; believers are to be salt. As salt, we preserve the world from decay, and we also season it by making it better. As light, we are to drive away darkness and provide direction for people treading on dangerous terrains.

As good is becoming bad and bad is becoming the norm in the world, many are confused. But Jesus, the Light of the world has placed you here to dispel darkness, and give people direction. May you shine as light that will never go dim, and may your presence wherever you go make life better for those around.

Wisdom : When light shines , darkness disappears.

Food for Thought : Are you a light to the world around you?

Follow-up Action : Speak boldly and lovingly against evil around you.

Prayer : Dear Jesus, let me shine as light everywhere I go.

title: be faithful when tested
message:
JANUARY 5 Friday

BH 364: Yield Not to Temptation

RBT: Job 1-2

BE FAITHFUL WHEN TESTED

Text: Revelation 2:8-11

Golden Text: Do not be afraid of what you are about to suffer. I tell you, the devil will put some of you in prison to test you, and you will suffer persecution for ten days. Be faithful, even to the point of death, and I will give you life as your victor\'s crown. Revelation 2:10, NIV

Jesus states the certainty of persecution for Christians in this world. The church in Smyrna was encouraged to remain faithful as they endure persecution. The city of ancient Smyrna (modern-day Izmir, Turkey) was located on the coast and was a harbour city. The Church was under the Roman rule and they were not treated well. Though materially poor, the Smyrnan believers were spiritually rich. God promised them the crown of life (vv. 8-10) as a reward for their faithfulness.

Everyone who will follow Jesus must be prepared for a measure of rejection from the people of this world. Jesus says, “Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.” Are you going through persecution for your faith? Jesus says, do not be discouraged; hold on; endure to the end. As you pass through trials and endure them, you become more like Jesus, the Author and Finisher of your faith. At the end, you will reign with Him.

Wisdom : Going through a test is tough, coming out of it is rewarding.

Food for Thought : : Only those who endure to the end shall be saved.

Follow-up Action : S hare your testimony of a time you faithfully endure a trial.

title: training plan for the captives
message:
JANUARY 6 Saturday

BH 360: Jesus Calls Us o\'er the Tumult

RBT: Isaiah 1-6

TRAINING PLAN FOR THE CAPTIVES

Text: Daniel 1:3-7

Golden Text: Young men without any physical defect . . . to teach them the language and literature of the Babylonians. Daniel 1:4, NIV

The exile fulfilled Isaiah\'s prophecy to King Hezekiah in 2 Kings 20. Hezekiah had shown the representatives of Babylon around his treasuries, hoping to form an ally with them against the Assyrians. Because he had thus failed to trust in the Lord, it was prophesied that the treasures he had shown the Babylonians, as well as some of his descendants, would be carried off to Babylon. In the third year of Jehoiakim\'s reign, the Israelites were taken into exile. To train the select young people for service in the king\'s court, Nebuchadnezzar made them learn the Babylonian culture, language and literature. They were given names inked with Babylonian deities in place of Israelite names, which were linked to Yahweh. This was an effort to indoctrinate the exiles into the Babylonian culture and thereby disconnect them from their origin.

The temptation to blend into the system of this world is always there. But as God\'s children, we must always remember that though we are in this world, we are not of the world. As much as we want to enjoy and be comfortable in the world, we should not get carried away as to forget our country of origin. We are citizens of heaven. We are on a sojourn in this world and we would return home one day. The Scripture says, “Do not conform any longer to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God\'s will is — his good, pleasing and perfect will” (Romans 12:2).

Wisdom : The wise always remember that they are not of this world.

Food for Thought : Ask yourself: In what ways am I conforming to this world?

Follow-up Action : List five things that are used as bait to lure Christians into sin.

Prayer : Lord God, help me to live as a citizen of heaven as I sojourn

title: stand by your principles
message:
JANUARY 7 Sunday

BH 411: Dare to Be Brave, Dare to Be True

RBT: Matthew 1-2

STAND BY YOUR PRINCIPLES

Text: Daniel 1:8-21

Golden Text: But Daniel resolved not to defile himself with the royal food and wine, and he asked the chief official for permission not to defile himself this way. Daniel 1:8, NIV

Kim Davis, a county clerk for Rowan County, Kentucky, USA, gained international attention in 2015 when she defied the US Supreme Court order to issue marriage licence to same-sex couples. A jail sentence and a lawsuit against her would not make her change her stance. She refused to give in despite the threats because she was “acting under God\'s authority.” She would not give licences that bear her name to same-sex couples because she was convinced that such is against God\'s will. Daniel and his three friends resolved not to defile themselves with the king\'s delicacies. They avoided the rich diet to protect themselves from being tempted and polluted by the Babylonian culture. Their restricted diet continually reminded them that they were God\'s people in a foreign land. They were dependent upon God for their food and their very lives, not King Nebuchadnezzar. The result was that God favoured them, gave them good health, outstanding wisdom, and they were better than those who gave in to eating the king\'s delicacies.

Godly principles are not popular in our days. Those who want to do what God wants may not have many friends. Nevertheless, believers need to always remember that they are not under the control of the world\'s system; they are to be governed by the principles of the kingdom of God. God does not call us to blend in with the world; rather, He wants us to stand out and uphold biblical principles, even when it means standing alone.

Wisdom : Dependence on God and self-discipline will help you stand strong for godly principles.

Food for Thought : Are you compromising your faithinChrist?

Follow-up Action : List your guiding principles and evaluate them in the light of the Word of God today.

Prayer : Lord, help me to do Your will in all things.

title: we must speak about jesus
message:
JANUARY 8 Monday

BH 455: We\'ve a Story to Tell

RBT: Romans 3-4

WE MUST SPEAK ABOUT JESUS

Text: Acts 4:13-22

Golden Text: But Peter and John replied, “. . . as for us, we cannot help speaking about what we have seen and heard.”Acts4:19-20,NIV

Renowned preacher, Peter Cartwright was invited to speak at a Methodist church in the southern part of America on one Sunday. During the song before the message, the church\'s pastor whispered to Cartwright that Andrew Jackson, who was the President ofAmerica then, had just entered the sanctuary. The pastor cautioned Cartwright to be very careful of what he would say so the president would not be offended. Halfway through his sermon, Cartwright said, “I understand thatAndrew Jackson is present in the congregation today. If he does not repent of his sins and accept Jesus Christ as his personal Saviour, he will be just as lost as anyone else who has never asked God for His forgiveness.” Peter and John boldly declared that they must continue to speak about Jesus in spite of threats to their lives. The healing of the cripple at the Beautiful Gate caused uproar and attracted the attention of the council to the apostles. The council asked them to stop speaking about Jesus, but because they had been with Jesus, they stated categorically that they must continue to speak, to please God rather than humans.

Evangelism has been relegated to the background today. When we think of evangelism, we consider it the business of others. We know that many are yet to be reached with the Gospel, yet we shy away from speaking to them about Jesus. Peter and John could not hold back because they have caught something so real to them. We witness what we know about Jesus and leave the rest for God. Will you ask for renewed boldness to speak of Jesus to those who are yet to know Him?

Wisdom : Telling the world about Jesus is a command, not an option.

Food for Thought : If you refuse to tell your friends about Jesus and they die, your friendship ends here.

Follow-up Action : Share your salvation experience with someone today.

Prayer : Dear Lord God, empower me with boldness to share my faith with others.

title: we must obey god, not humans
message:
JANUARY 9 Tuesday

BH 413: Who Is on the Lord\'s Side?

RBT: Genesis 4-7

WE MUST OBEY GOD, NOT HUMANS

Text: Acts 5:27-32

Golden Text: Peter and the other apostles replied: “We must obey God rather than human beings!”Acts 5:29, NIV

While on a bus travelling to another city, a man stood up to share the Gospel with other passengers on the bus. As he greeted the people, before he could even start the preaching, the bus driver shouted at him, “Mr man, no preaching on this bus.” If you were this man, what would you do? Peter and John found themselves before the highest authority in the land, answering questions on the healing of the crippled beggar. Having seen the people\'s interest in their teaching after witnessing the man\'s healing, the council members became agitated. They knew they could not undo the man\'s healing and that people have started believing in Jesus. But there was only one thing they could do: to stop the disciples from preaching in the name of Jesus. To this the apostles replied, “We must obey God rather than human beings.”

Each day, believers find themselves torn between obeying God or human beings. And many times, because God is not physically present with us, we tend to obey human beings that we can see. While we should live at peace with everyone, and obey authorities, conflict with the world is inevitable for Christians. There will be situations where you cannot obey both God and humans. In such situations, choose obedience to God and trust His words. Allow the words of Jesus in Luke 6:22 to encourage you. Yes, people may hate you for being an ardent follower of Christ. Ask yourself before you make your choice: which one is according to the plan and purpose of God? Who is supreme: God or humans?

Wisdom : The wise choose to obey God rather than humans.

Food for Thought : Why fear mere human beings when God is awesome?

Follow-up Action : Discuss ways to obey God rather than people.

Prayer : Dear Father, help me to be bold and resolute to obey You always.

title: prayer, fasting, and bold move
message:
JANUARY 10 Wednesday

BH 439: Ready

RBT: Joshua 6-10

PRAYER, FASTING, AND BOLD MOVE

Text: Esther 4:5-17

Golden Text: Go, gather together all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. I and my attendants will fast as you do. When this is done, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law.And if I perish,I perish.Esther 4:16, NIV

Considering his experience as the founder of China Inland Mission, Hudson Taylor said, “Unless there is an element of risk in our exploits for God, there is no need for faith.” Esther\'s life was at stake because going to the king without being invited could lead to death. But because of the direness of the situation, she decided to take a risk. She may have been fearful initially, but with Mordecai\'s encouragement, Esther decided to break out of her comfort zone, and take a step of faith. She did not do that thoughtlessly; she asked all the Jews to fast for her three days. She and her attendants also joined in the fasting. She knew the risks involved in what she was about to do but she believed that the risk was worth it. She considered the sacrifice of her life as nothing compared to the wiping out of a whole generation of Jews.

Ambrose Redmoon said, “Courage is not the absence of fear, but rather the judgment that something else is more important than fear.”Faith involves taking risks. After you might have sought the face of God concerning a matter, you need to put your faith into action, even when it does not seem reasonable. Many have allowed themselves to be cowed by fear that they cannot live the life that God has ordained for them. Do you have a difficult task to face? Rather than being fearful about the situation, take action with confidence in God by following Esther\'s inspiring example. Dare your fear and live your faith with courage that God has got you on the other side.

Wisdom : Faith without risk is no faith at all.

Food for Thought : A family that fasts and prays together will be closer to God and to each other , accomplishing great things in Jesus\'Name.

Follow-up Action : Confront the difficult situation today with prayer and support of others.

Prayer : Lord Jesus, grant me boldness and courage to face difficult situations of life.

title: all ordered to worship the image
message:
JANUARY 11 Thursday

BH 422: March On, O Soul with Strength

RBT: Psalms 3-5

ALL ORDERED TO WORSHIP THE IMAGE

Text: Daniel 3:1-12

Golden Text: Then the herald loudly proclaimed, “Nations and peoples of every language, this is what you are commanded to do . . . you must fall down and worship the image of gold that King Nebuchadnezzar has set up.” Daniel 3:4-5, NIV

It was a time of great celebration in Babylon as the princes, governors, captains, judges, treasurers, counsellors, sheriffs, and all the rulers of the provinces gathered together to dedicate the golden image that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up. The high point of the party was that at the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, dulcimer, and all kinds of music, everyone would fall down and worship the image. Those who would refuse to worship it would not be spared as a burning fiery furnace had been prepared into which they would be thrown. Because Shadrach Meshach and Abednego were rulers over provinces, all eyes were on them. And when the people saw that they would not bow down to the image, they brought them to the king. The law must take its course – they would be thrown into the fiery furnace.

Today\'s idol worship is not only of bowing down to a graven image. We have sophisticated and well packaged idols in our days. Technology is a major idol of modern times. Smart phones and other tech gadgets, if allowed, can take the place of quality worship and fellowship with God. Idol is anything that shifts our focus from God. In his book, The Reason for God, Hellen Keller says “Nothing whatsoever – money, possession, fame, pleasure, gratification, comfort, relationships – should be the centre of our life.” Once we take God away from the centre of our hearts and place any other thing there, we are already practising idolatry. God wants you to rid your heart of any idol and give Him full attention.

title: we will not serve babylonian gods
message:
JANUARY 12 Friday

BH 419: Stand Up, Stand Up for Jesus

RBT: Job 3-4

WE WILL NOT SERVE BABYLONIAN GODS

Text: Daniel 3:13-18

Golden Text: “But even if he does not, we want you to know, Your Majesty, that we will not serve your gods or worship the image of gold you have set up.” Daniel 3:18, NIV

Christian martyr Polycarp was 86 years old when he was brought before a Roman official who asked him to renounce his faith in Christ. Polycarp had refused to worship the Roman emperor as a god, along with other gods of Rome. He knew what he would face – a painful death, either by being thrown into the arena with a wild animal or burned alive at the stake. Three times the Roman official told him, “Swear; curse Christ and I will release you.” Three times, Polycarp replied, “Eighty-six years have I served Him (Christ), and He has done me no wrong: how then can I blaspheme my King who saved me?” Nebuchadnezzar was outraged when the three Hebrew men did not obey his orders. He, therefore, ordered the furnace to be heated seven times hotter than usual. Pressured to deny God, the three men chose to serve and worship Him no matter what happened. They trusted God to deliver them, but were determined to be faithful regardless of the consequences. There was no doubt in their minds that God had the power to save them. They also realised that God may choose not to save them.

The world is becoming increasingly hostile to the Gospel, and Christian persecution is on the increase. Sometimes, it is wrapped in socio-economic and political upheavals, where believers are pressured to choose between suffering and staying true to Jesus or comfort and denying their faith in the Lord. It may be pressure to do the will of a boss at work, or risk dismissal. You could try to manipulate your way out and risk your faith in God. The pressures may be so great that they even threaten your life. God promised never to forsake us (Heb. 13:5). However, like the Hebrew boys, we would need to decide whether our faith is worth fighting or dying for.

Wisdom : Bowing to other gods may be appealing, but the consequences bring grief.

Food for Thought : You may have good excuses, but none will justify you before God.

Follow-up Action : Resolve to stand for Christ today.

Some people believe that Christians find themselves in the fiery furnace of life only when they disobey God. Don Williams\' response to this in his \'Biblical Theology of Suffering\' is that suffering is God\'s plan for us. But then, in suffering, our primary resource is God. While they showed deep respect for King Nebuchadnezzar, they were unwilling to follow any orders that compromised their faith. The three men proclaimed publicly their God had the power to save them, but whether He saved them or not, they would not deny Him.

Their obeisance to God and faith that the outcome was in God’s hand demands that Christians today consider our own loyalties. Are we ready to stand for God like these men? When you are faithful to God, expect His deliverance. Even if it is in death, He promises to deliver His children from evil. If you stand firm for God, you will stand out and become outstanding. It may, however, be painful, but in the end God will give you victory.

Golden Text: Declare a holy fast; call a sacred assembly. Summon the elders and all who live in the land to the house of the Lord your God, and cry out to the Lord. Joel 1:14, NIV

It was John Maxwell who said, “Everything rises and falls on leadership.” When anything goes wrong with the head, the whole body shivers in pain. So it is with any society with a failed leadership. Little wonder God had to call the leadership of Israel to repentance for the sins of the nation. Joel delivered God\'s message of repentance to the spiritual leadership of Israel – the priests and those who minister at the altar of God. He charged them to get ready, put on sackcloth and lament for the pitiable condition of the nation. In place of great harvest, they had drought, famine, and their joy was taken away. “The storehouses are in ruins, the granaries have been broken down, for the grain has dried up. ...The cattle moan! The herds mill about because they have no pasture; even the flocks of sheep are suffering” (vv. 17-18).

Just like God called the spiritual leaders of Israel, God is calling His people – the Church – to repentance over the sad situation of the nations. God called us out to lead the course of action in our nation. We often exonerate ourselves from the decay around us. But the truth is, if we would take our place in the world, things would improve. Many Christians live in the midst of the moral decadence in their nations; they only fold their hands and go about their businesses, feeling unconcerned.

Many groan under the weight of poverty and oppression occasioned by sin. But they only complain and castigate. God is calling us to repentance – the leaders and members of the church. Enough of complaints borne out of self-righteousness! This is the time to wake up, repent, call a solemn assembly, ask for God\'s mercy, and seek His face for our land. This is the time to rise up, pray and declare the kingdom of God in our communities. As we do this, we can expect a time of refreshing from God.

John Wesley said, “God will do nothing on earth except in answer to believing prayer.” Through purposeful study, Daniel understood the will of God for His people, even in exile. While he clocked time in captivity, Daniel trusted the prophecy of Jeremiah – \'This is what the LORD says: “When seventy years are completed for Babylon, I will come to you and fulfil my gracious promise to bring you back to this place.”\' (Jer. 29:10) As this period was coming to a close, Daniel got busy petitioning God to honour His promise. BH 62: Be Thou My Vision

VISION SENDS JACOB TO EGYPT

Text: Genesis 46:1-7

Golden Text: I am God, the God of your father,” he said. “Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you into a great nation there.” Genesis 46:3, NIV

In big cities across the world the GPS (Global Positioning System) has made travel easier and navigation through unfamiliar terrains less difficult. You only need to input your desired destination into the GPS at the beginning of your journey; with this,you can trust the system to assess traffic flow as it also gives you step-by-step instructions and warnings when you need to make a turn or take an exit.Life gets easier with timely directions. Jacob seemed fearful about his journey to Egypt. He was uncertain of so many things and could not figure out what the future held. In the midst of his confusion, God spoke to him in a vision, giving him divine confirmation. God comforted Jacob and eased his fears, promised to make his family a great nation in Egypt. God also gave a promise of return to their country in the future. Jacob\'s confidence in God was made stronger by the vision and he stepped out in faith to go to Egypt.

You need direction for your life and the most accurate direction you can get is the one your Maker gives. When you have God\'s direction, you face life with utmost confidence. You are not afraid to get on your journey and you are assured of His presence. Today, many people venture into jobs, professions, journeys, marriages, without getting direction from God. Then, they ask God to bless the actions already taken. Before you attempt anything in life, seek God\'s direction first, obey it, and receive His blessing to move on. God\'s direction will take you to where His grace abounds and give you peace in the midst of turbulence. Will you ask for His direction today?

message:

EZEKIEL CALLED TO SPEAK TO ISRAEL

Text: Ezekiel 1:26-2:7

Golden Text: You must speak my words to them, whether they listen or fail to listen, for they are rebellious. Ezekiel 2:7, NIV

In apartheid South Africa, where government forbade any rally, Archbishop Desmond Tutu conducted a church service. As the Archbishop started preaching, the police entered the cathedral and took notes of the sermon. Rather than being intimidated, Desmond Tutu preached against the evil of apartheid. At a point, he addressed the police, “You are powerful. You are very powerful, but you are not gods and I serve a God who cannot be mocked. So, since you\'ve already lost, I invite you today to come and join the winning side!” The task before Ezekiel was tough – to go to a people who were obstinate, stubborn and rebellious. He fell to his face when he saw the glory of God and heard Him speak. He was commanded to stand up and hear God\'s specific instructions. The Holy Spirit entered into Ezekiel to prepare him for the intimidating task of speaking to the rebellious Israelites. God chose the man, equipped him and the Holy Spirit would go with him. Ezekiel had everything he needed for success. There was no reason to fear; God was on his side, preparing the way for him.

Philips Brooks said, “Don\'t ask for tasks equal to your powers. Ask for powers equal to your tasks.” God calls you to speak on His behalf. There is no need to fear, for He not only calls, but equips and empowers to ensure success. Does the task look huge? Trust the Holy Spirit who dwells within and rest assured that the One who sends you is greater than any task at hand. Are you ready and willing? Remember, God calls you to speak for Him, but you are not responsible for the way people respond to the message. Your success is determined by your obedience to God\'s command.

Not many people like interruptions, especially when they are fixed on getting to a desired location within a specific time frame. We often find it difficult to accept sudden change in plans. But is it possible to go through life without any interruption? Paul was on his way to Asia to preach the Word, which is a good and noble plan until the Holy Spirit threw a road-block in the way. God commands believers to preach the Word, right? However, even that command had specific details. Paul received a vision that changed his destination. In a night vision, he saw people in Macedonia pleading for him to come. This trip would put him into prison, but God\'s plan was to use Paul to save those whose heart He had prepared. The God who calls us to preach His Word is also ready to give us direction on how to go about it. If only we can listen, He speaks moment by moment, giving us specific instructions about the task. Being sensitive to the Holy Spirit and obeying every detail of instruction will yield the results God intends. The results may not look the way you expect. Who wants to sit in prison? But being deliberate in your obedience will bring success. Paul delivered the gospel message to Lydia, the jailer, their families and others in Macedonia. bringing them into the kingdom. When you see God\'s vision, doing the work He has assigned you becomes easy. Ask for His direction today.

TIME OF THE END

Text: Daniel 12:8-13

Golden Text: He replied, “Go your way, Daniel, because the words are rolled up and sealed until the time of the end.” Daniel 12:9, NIV

In the heat of World War II, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a protestant theologian, was imprisoned for taking a stand against Hitler. Even in prison, Bonhoeffer continued to urge fellow believers to resist Nazi tyranny. The believers believed that Hitler was the antichrist. They therefore told Bonhoeffer, “Why do you expose yourself to all this danger? Jesus will return any day, and all your work and suffering will be for nothing.” Bonhoeffer replied, “If Jesus returns tomorrow, then tomorrow I\'ll rest from my labour. But today I have work to do. I must continue the struggle until it\'s finished.” Daniel\'s vision came to conclusion with a picture of the end time. When he sought understanding of what he saw, the angel asked him to go his way. \'Go your way\', rather than being a literal instruction, means that Daniel should focus on his purpose and leave the fulfilment of the prophecies to God. Instead of worrying about things he did not know, Daniel should simply do what God has assigned him to do. Jesus alluded to Daniel\'s prophecy of the abomination of desolation as one sign that would mark the imminence of His return (Matthew 24:15) – a proof that Daniel\'s prophecy was not restricted to his days. We all have a role to play in this end time. The rest of the signs that Jesus gave (Matthew 24:3ff) are already being fulfilled in our days. As we get ourselvesready, we should also prepare others for Jesus\' return. Donot keep quiet. Show concern for the salvation of sinners. Speak the word to them. Pray earnestly that they would be saved. Jesus\' coming is near, and we must do everything possible to bring more people to God\'s kingdom.

Wisdom : The wise watch and pray because the end is near.

title: fulfilling the law

BH 443: In Christ There Is No East or West

RBT: Romans 9-10

FULFILLING THE LAW

Text: James 2:8-13

Golden Text: If you really keep the royal law found in the Scripture, “Love your neighbour as yourself,” you are doing right. James 2:8, NIV

As a student, Mahatma Gandhi read the Gospels and became interested in Christianity. One Sunday morning he decided to go to a church. As he made to enter the church, he was stopped by some ushers who told him that the church was for high- caste Indians and whites only. They told Gandhi to seek a church where his own people worshipped. He left and never went back. He said, “If Christians have caste differences also, I might as well remain a Hindu.” Brother James emphasised that keeping the royal law of love requires that we treat people equally and fairly. James was speaking against the error of treating people who are rich better than those who are poor in the church of God. He stated that the act of dishonouring the poor in the church to honour the wealthy, who came from outside, is a sin. When the royal law of love is violated, it is a violation of all other laws.

Not many people like to associate with poor people. Everyone likes to associate with the rich and the high of the society. Every human being is susceptible to the temptation of considering those who appear well above those who are less privileged. The admonition of James is that if that is what obtains in the world, the Church should set the right example by treating everyone equally, regardless of their economic status or any other basis by which we discriminate against people. Partiality or favouritism violates the Royal Law. Treating the rich better than the poor goes against loving your neighbour as yourself. God\'s grace is available to all and we must see everyone as God sees them.

Wisdom : To receive God\'s mercy, give mercy to others.

Food for Thought : When you show favouritism , you relegate God \'s creation.

Follow-up Action : Show mercy to a poor person in \'shabby clothes\' today.

THE ROYAL LAW

Text: Leviticus 19:13-18

Golden Text: Do not pervert justice; do not show partiality to the poor or favouritism to the great, but judge your neighbour fairly. Leviticus 19:15, NIV

Ron Hutchcraft told of his experience with an airline: “I got bad news at the airport that my flight had been canceled, and the airline I was booked on couldn\'t get me to my destination in time for the meeting I was supposed to speak for. But the good news was that they found me a seat on another airline...which I had barely heard of. But this airline was with a wonderful difference from all the others. There was no first class section; every seat was as wide as a first class seat! And instead of the plastic plates, paper napkins and average food I\'m used to in economy class, I got (we all got) china plates, cloth napkins, a real meal - I mean like they usually get in first class. That\'s the kind of treatment you would only get if you\'ve paid for those expensive seats up there. But what a great concept this particular airline has - treat everyone as if they\'re first class!” God wants us to treat everybody as first class. That is why He commands those in leadership positions not to show partiality in judging the poor or show favouritism to the rich. When we show favouritism, it means God, the Creator of both, is down-played. All people must be treated equally for they are created in His image.

In a world where people are respected based on how much they have and what they can offer, God expects Christians to treat everyone with God\'s love. Donot look down on anyone. Do not consider anyone unimportant. Treat everyone as God\'s image. It is true that we have special relationships with some people in our lives. title: justified by faith

JUSTIFIED BY FAITH

Text: Romans 3:21-31

Golden Text: God presented him as a sacrifice of atonement, through faith in his blood . . . so as to be just and the one who justifies those who have faith in Jesus. Romans 3:25-26, NIV

Tim did not need anyone to tell him that he had to stop schooling since he was sent home because his dad could not pay his school fees for the Tsession. There was no hope of getting money to clear the debt. But then, his dad got a call from the registrar of Tim\'s school who told him that Tim\'s debt had been written off by the school\'s governing council. Tim no longer owed any debt because the record has been cleared. That Tim\'s debt was cleared may sound unbelievable but that is what Christ did for us when He died as a sacrifice of atonement for our sin. Justification is not a product of reasoning. Apostle Paul says we become justified by our faith in Christ. Justification precedes salvation. To be justified means to be acquitted of the offence someone had committed and be declared “not guilty\'. Justification is God\'s act of grace by which He pardons a sinner and accepts him or her as righteous because of the atoning work of Jesus Christ on the cross. This justification includes forgiveness of sin and freedom from guilt and God\'s wrath. Martin Luther called justification “...the chief doctrine of the Christian faith. It is so important that if you do not understand this doctrine, you really don\'t understand Christianity at all.”

Through faith in Christ, you too can be justified today, no matter the severity of your sins. Justification will launch you into the joy of forgiveness. Maybe you have been guilt-ridden for years; Jesus Christ is faithful to forgive your sin (1 John 1:9).What you need to do is to confess your sin, accept God\'s forgiveness and cleansing by faith.

Wisdom : We are justified by faith, not by anything we have done.

When asked what God had taught him most Wdeeply about life, George Mueller said, “There was a day when I died, utterly died, died to George Mueller, his opinions, preferences, tastes and will, died to the world, its approval or censure, died to the approval or blame even of my brethren and friends, and since then I have studied only to show myself approved unto God.” Apostle Paul restates the great exchange that took place the day one receives Christ. Though Paul was not there when Christ was crucified, he states the spiritual truth that when we come to Christ, our self, human nature actually undergoes crucifixion as it dies to sin and comes alive in resurrection, living the life of Christ alone.

To be crucified means to be dead to sin, self and Satan. Living then means living only to please Christ whose life we receive in exchange for our own. As we allow Christ live His life in us, we no longer respond to the dictates of the flesh. Things that used to entice us to sin against God no longer look attractive and we are empowered by the Holy Spirit to live only as Christ would live. Paul also mentions that we do not build again the life of sin which has been destroyed but rather, we are alive to the righteousness of Christ which is imputed into us when we receive Him. The question is: Are you crucified with Christ? Do people see Christ in you?

Wisdom : Who lives in you will determine your final destination.

Food for Thought : Christ\'s nature in you will shine His love through you.

Follow-up Action : Dethrone other kings in your heart and enthrone the Lord fully.

title: spirit comes through faith not law
message:
FEBRUARY 3 Saturday

BH 523: Spirit of the Living God

RBT: Isaiah 23-28

SPIRIT COMES THROUGH FAITH NOT LAW

Text: Galatians 3:6-14

Golden Text: He redeemed us in order that the blessing given to Abraham might come to the Gentiles through Christ Jesus, so that by faith we might receive the promise of the Spirit. Galatians 3:14, NIV NIV

Just like a mirror that we look into which shows us the spots or blackheads on the face but has no power to remove the spots; so is the law capable of Jrevealing our sins and need for Saviour, but is not able to remove sins. Faith in Christ alone, through the power of the Spirit, is what takes away sin. Paul told the Galatian Christians that observing the law would not make them children of Abraham but that their faith in Christ would make them partakers of God\'s promise to Abraham – the promise of the Holy Spirit.

The Christian life is a supernatural life. We can only live it by faith as we are empowered by the Holy Spirit. Without the Holy Spirit, we will struggle to please God. We must avoid getting caught in the web of confusion that trapped the Galatians. Though they understood the role the Holy Spirit played in their conversion, they missed out on the work of the Spirit in living the Christian life. The Holy Spirit is the life of the believers. He empowers, teaches, guides and comforts us. His presence in our lives makes obedience easier. Christ is revealed more in us as we yield to the promptings of the Holy Spirit, as He helps us to manifest the fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23). As Paul says, “If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit (Galatians 5:25).

Wisdom : If obedience to the law could bring salvation , then Christ\'s death is in vain.

title: faith without works is dead
message:
FEBRUARY 4 Sunday

BH 434: Serve the Lord

RBT: Matthew 11-13

FAITH WITHOUT WORKS IS DEAD

Text: Romans 3:21-31

Golden Text: God presented him as a sacrifice of atonement, through faith in his blood . . . so as to be just and the one who justifies those who have faith in Jesus. Romans 3:25-26, NIV

Charles Ryrie said, “Unproductive faith cannot save, because it is not genuine faith. Faith and works are like a two-coupon ticket to heaven. CThe coupon of works is not good for passage, and coupon of faith is not valid if detached from works.” Good works cannot earn us salvation. Salvation is free and it comes by faith in Christ alone. Faith is fundamental for justification while work is a manifestation of true faith. Nevertheless, James\' central concern is that faith is of no use if it does not work. After we might have been saved by faith, the proof of our faith is seen in what we do. Though faith is invisible, it becomes visible to people around us because they can feel its effect through the way we live. The faith that works is the one that changes lives and makes impact in others. Faith in Christ is not an abstract thing that only lies in the belly of the carrier and achieves nothing.

Our commitment and conviction to follow Christ require that people see our good works to glorify God. One of the ways through which Christ will receive glory on earth is through believers\' good works. Therefore, we must shine as light for others to see. Christ met the needs of people and we must do the same. Some believers separate their faith from what they do. They are saints on Sunday, but something else on other days. The best evidence for your faith is your actions. If you actually carry faith in Christ, then people must see it working. Is yours a working or a dead faith?

Wisdom : Faith is like the vehicle; work is like fuel.

Food for Thought : Who you work for determines who will pay you.

Follow-up Action : Put your faith to practice by practising what you profess to believe.

title: people live by god's word
message:
FEBRUARY 5 Monday

BH 181: Wonderful Words of Life

RBT: Romans 11-12

PEOPLE LIVE BY GOD'S WORD

Text: Deuteronomy 8:1-3

Golden Text: He humbled you, causing you to hunger and then feeding you with manna . . . to teach you that man does not live on bread alone but on every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord. Deuteronomy 8:3, NIV

he story was told of Sir Walter Raleigh who was undergoing a heart-rending crisis, T having sustained a great loss. In that low moment, he said to his servant, “Please bring me the book.” Because Raleigh\'s library was a huge one, the servant asked him, “which book?”; to which Sir Raleigh replied, “At a time like this, there is but one Book”, referring to the Bible.

The Bible is one book that we cannot do without if we must live a successful Christian life. Moses charged the people of Israel to obey the commandments that God has given them as they enter the Promised Land. For them to live, increase and take possession of God\'s promise to them, they must abide by the Word of God. They must remember how God had led them through the wilderness; how He humbled them, making them hunger, and feeding them with manna. God took them through these so they can learn to live by His word.

The modern life provides us with many options of things we can live by. There are many things calling for our attention as they present themselves to us as means for survival. But the truth is that no matter how much we acquire; there is no viable means of survival that can be compared to the Word of God. In a world of confusion and depression, the Word is able to give us direction. The Word of God does not only provide sustenance for this time; it has been proven to be the only means of surviving till eternity. Of all the things that we seek after, none can satisfy the soul; only God\'s word can. For a victorious life, we need the word of God.

Wisdom : God\'s Word instructs you how to live for Him.

Food for Thought : The way of the Lord is located on the pages of the Bible.

Follow-up Action : Make a commitment to read the Bible through this year.

title: set a guard over my mouth
message:
FEBRUARY 6 Tuesday

BH 532: Let the Words of My Mouth

RBT: Psalms 12-14

SET A GUARD OVER MY MOUTH

Text: Psalm 141:1-4

Golden Text: Set a guard over my mouth, O Lord; keep watch over the door of my lips. Psalm 141:3, NIV

A BBM sponsored message reads: “Ever wish you could go back in time to un-send a message? We can help.” How easy can it be to un-send a message? The psalmist must have understood that spoken words are not easily un-sent, and so he prays that God would set a guard over his mouth, and keep watch over the door of his lips. Because the psalmist also knows that the root of the mouth is the heart, he prays again that God would not allow his heart to be drawn towards evil so he would not take part in wicked deeds.

We must not underestimate the power of the mouth. Words have destroyed homes and cities, and words have built great homes and mighty cities. If we must speak, the Bible advises us to “Let no unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building up the one in need and bringing grace to those who listen” (Ephesians 4:29). Instead of letting the mouth control us, we must discipline ourselves to control it. Spoken words are not easily retractable. That is why we must daily ask for grace, like the psalmist, to keep a guard over our mouth. The battle over the mouth is a battle of the heart. Jesus says, “Out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaks.” If we would receive answers to our prayers, then we must guard our hearts and mouths. “The tongue has the power of life and death...” (Proverbs 18:21). And we have the bridle to determine what it produces. We should continually pray like the psalmist: Lord set a guard over my mouth and keep watch over my lips.

Wisdom : A wellguarded mouth is evidence of a Godfilled heart.

Food for Thought : Be mindful of what you say. Your words could come back to bite you.

Follow-up Action : Talk with God before talking with people today.

title: judged by your words
message:

BH 356: Take My Life and Let it Be

RBT: Judges 1-6

JUDGED BY YOUR WORDS

Text: Matthew 12:33-37

For by your words you will be acquitted, and by your words you will be condemned. Matthew 12:37, NIV

n his book, Yet Will I Trust Him, John Mark Hick tells of his son\'s experience on a school bus. The son was born with a syndrome that causes slow Imental and physical degeneration. But whenever he saw a school bus, he was always eager to ride on it just like his sister. Every morning, Hick would take the son to wait at the bus stop for the bus to take him to school. But one morning, he noticed his son was reluctant to get on the bus. Hick said, “But as the bus drove away I learned why he was hesitant; I heard words that tore my heart. It was as if a knife had been stuck into my gut and twisted. His schoolmates were ridiculing him. The older children were calling him names. They ridiculed his need for diapers. As the bus drove off, I could hear the mockery, and I could see my son stumble down the aisle as he looked for a seat.”

Jesus says we would be held accountable on the Day of Judgment for every idle word we speak. Words have power to tear people\'s hearts or build them up. Just as the fruits of a tree reveal the condition of the tree, so did the hearts of the Pharisees manifest in their speech.

What kinds of words do you speak? \'Talk is cheap\' is a popular saying. But when we put to mind the truth that we are accountable to God for our speech, then, we would begin to place a cost on what we say. Whenever you are tempted to speak words of ridicule, mockery or slander, always remember that you will be judged by your words.

Wisdom : Let no corrupt talk come out of your mouth.

Food for Thought : What kind of words do I speak?

Follow-up Action : Make a commitment today to never speak unwholesome words to anyone.

title: from the heart the mouth speaks
message:

BH 230: Let Jesus Come into Your Heart

RBT: Psalms 15-17

FROM THE HEART THE MOUTH SPEAKS

Text: Luke 6:43-45

Golden Text: The good man brings good things out of the good stored up in his heart, and the evil man brings evil things out of the evil stored up in his heart. For out of the overflow of his heart his mouth speaks. Luke 6:45, NIV

"Your accent gives you away" is a popular English axiom. Linguists say the true test of where a person comes from is not just in their Youtward appearance but much more in their accent. You can tell what part of a country – south, east, west or north – a person is from by their speech. From their words, you can know who a person really is. Just as the accent reveals a lot about a person, Jesus says our speech reveals a lot about the condition of our hearts.

Jesus told the discples that speech is reflective of the heart. A righteous heart yields righteous words while a filthy heart yields filthy words. People will identify you as godly or evil by your speech. We may appear godly on the outside but the true test of who we are is the words we speak, which reflect our hearts. Each day we make choices of what words to speak. We should make good choices because our words impact people either negatively or positively. Many have been marred by the impact of words so much that they find it difficult to make headway in life. And many others have soared to their God-given destination by the power of the words they heard. If our heart is the tree which produces the fruit which is our words, then it is important that we, by the power of the Lord, prune our hearts so that it would not produce sour or bitter fruits, but sweet and desirable fruits of blessing and grace, to those who listen to us.

Wisdom : Your words are a reflection of your heart.

INFANTS AND BABIES SPEAK

Text: Matthew 21:14-16

Golden Text: Do you hear what these children are saying? they asked him. Yes, replied Jesus, have you never read, from the lips of children and infants you have ordained praise? Matthew 21:16, NIV

A granddaughter to the adult\'s worship service for the first time. The girl sat quietly, keen on Aeverything going on in the service and attentive to every word spoken. When the time came for the pastoral prayer, the pastor said, “We thank you Lord for your presence.” As the pastor mentioned \'presence\', the little girl became more alert and she whispered to her granny, “Grandma, I think we\'re going to get presents.” It is amazing to note that while the chief priests and scribes were displeased at the wonderful things that Jesus did, the children were happy and they praised Him saying, “Hosanna to the Son of David.” They brought encouragement to Jesus in the midst of the hostility of the scribes and priests. Quoting the psalmist (Psalm 8:2), Jesus told the scribes that God had ordained praise out of the mouths of babes and sucklings.

Children have a role to play in the matters of God\'s kingdom. As they were to Jesus, children can be a source of encouragement to us. Through them, we can learn faith and trust; and we can be encouraged by their innocence and openness to the things of the Spirit. We should not make the mistake of neglecting them with the thought that they are children. When we shove them aside, or refuse to make adequate room for them in our worship, we deny them the opportunity of playing their God-ordained role. Jesus loves children and He can use them to proclaim His glory on earth. They are capable of knowing God and serving His purpose, if we expose them to the truths of God\'s kingdom right from birth.

Wisdom : Children can know God and serve Him.

title: say only 'yes' or 'no'
message:
FEBRUARY 10 Saturday

BH 352: Living for Jesus

RBT: Isaiah 29-33

SAY ONLY 'YES' OR 'NO'

Text: Matthew 5:33-37

Golden Text: Simply let your Yes be Yes, and your No, No; anything beyond this comes from the evil one. Matthew 5:37,NIV

The concept of relativism is that there is no one standard for truth and falsehood that is valid for everyone. Relativism is rooted in the desire of Tthe fallen human nature to revolt against all forms of authority and find freedom in doing whatever is convenient at any time. In our world of relativism, many things that used to be held as sacrosanct truths are becoming relative.

In a world as this, Jesus says we must let our Yes be Yes and our No, No. As believers, our words are attached to our reputation. Jesus says anyone who says No when s/he should say Yes belongs to the evil one (v. 37b). People swear when they want to convince the other person that they are saying the truth. But we would need no swearing if we say things the way they are. We would not need to make efforts to convince people when we have said the truth.

Integrity, honesty and truth telling should be our lifestyle as believers. To be honourable is for our words to be trustworthy. A man or woman of good reputation is one whose word is his or her bond. If you have made a promise to someone then you must keep it. When you are on the phone with someone, integrity demands that you give the person the true picture of the situation, even when he or she cannot see you. In an age where trustworthiness is scarce, you can be a beacon of light that shows people that a life of honesty is still attainable. When we allow the Spirit of truth to guide us each moment, we can be people whose Yes means Yes and No means No.

Wisdom : You can borrow books, but you cannot borrow integrity.

CONTROL YOUR TONGUE

Text: James 3:1-12

Golden Text: But no man can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison. James 3:8, NIV

William Norris, known for using simple rhymes to communicate great messages, once wrote: “If your lips would keep from slips, five things observe with care: To whom you speak; of whom you speak; and how, and when, and where.” James says the tongue is not very big but it has enormous power. When words are many, offence may not be far away. As a little bridle controls a big horse; and a small rudder controls a big ship, so is the tongue capable of controlling the whole body.

Those who cause division in the church and those who bring unity use one thing – the tongue. A Christian must exercise power over his or her tongue. Great good can be accomplished when you use your tongue to encourage, edify, and enrich others. However, when the tongue is misused to condemn or destroy, it does great damage. James encourages us to refrain from using the same mouth with which we bless, to curse people. Learn to hold your tongue from evil words and let the Holy Spirit use your speech for the glory of God and growth of the kingdom.

title: widow's son restored to life

RBT: Romans 13-14

WIDOW'S SON RESTORED TO LIFE

Text: 1Kings 17:17-24

Golden Text: The Lord heard Elijah's cry, and the boy's life returned to him, and he lived. 1 Kings 17:22, NIV

The widow was God\'s instrument to sustain Elijah during the three years of famine that ravaged Israel. Though it was a tough time for all (even tougher for the widow who had no helper), the woman honoured God\'s word through Elijah as she attended to the man of God before herself and her son. And God also honoured her with abundance. After these things, the widow\'s son fell ill and died as a result of the sickness. In sorrow, the woman cried unto Elijah, “What do you have against me, man of God? Did you come to remind me of my sin and kill my son?” (v.18). Her husband\'s death was enough tragedy; the death of the son again could make life unbearable for her. Elijah took the dead son, laid him on his bed and laid flat on him.“Then he cried out to the Lord, "O Lord my God, have you brought tragedy also upon this widow I am staying with, by causing her son to die?" ... "O Lord my God, let this boy\'s life return to him!”(vv. 20-21). As the man of Godprayed, God restored the boy\'s life; and he gave him back to his mother alive. At this, the woman said, “Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the Lord from your mouth is the truth” (v. 24).

Miracles confirm the potency of God\'s word. Hopeless situations change at the power of God\'s word and faith. There is no situation that God cannot turn around when we call on Him in faith. As God revived the widow\'s hope, He can revive the dead hope in your marriage, academic, health and business. Call on Him today in faith, and He will answer you.

title: jesus raises widow's son
message:
FEBRUARY 13 Tuesday

BH 305: Take the Name of Jesus with You

RBT: Genesis 24-27

JESUS RAISES WIDOW'S SON

Text: Luke 7:11-17

Golden Text: The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother. Luke 7:15,NIV

Yesterday we saw how Elijah in the Old Testament raised the widow\'s son back to life. Today, we see in the New Testament how Jesus raised another widow\'s son. Widowhood is not a desirable state but whenever the undesirable happens, people learn to cope with life and move on. Having lost her husband, the poor widow moved on with life, taking care of her only son. She must have invested so much in her son, who was the symbol of her hope. So when death came calling again, and took her only son, it brought to her an emptiness and a dejection that may not be explained in words. Jesus understood the widow\'s grief, and out of compassion restored order to her life. Many times, we speak words of comfort to those who are bereaved, just for want of something to say to them. But when Jesus told her, “Weep not”, it was a statement backed up with power and a willingness to change her situation. Jesus came and touched the coffin; called the dead man to arise, to the amazement of the pallbearers. Immediately, “The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother” (v.15).

The power of Jesus the great Prophet is still potent right now, and He is compassionate and willing to visit those situations that have brought chaos into your life. He can restore order into the disorder that has made you an object of people\'s pity. He can bring to life your deadness and give you back your life.

title: care for widows and orphans
message:
FEBRUARY 14 Wednesday

BH 431: Make Me a Blessing

RBT: Judges 7-11

CARE FOR WIDOWS AND ORPHANS

Text: James 1:22-27

Golden Text: Religion that God our Father accepts as pure and faultless is this: to look after orphans and widows in their distress and to keep oneself from being polluted by the world. James 1:27, NIV

Rwandan Purpose Driven and Peace Orphan Care Initiative, a ministry effort of Saddleback Church taught in a neighbourhood about the negative effect of orphanages on children as well as the effect of lack of one-on-one care and attention of a parent on a child\'s overall development. A disabled woman who was at the teaching and whose son had been in the orphanage said, “I don\'t want my son to be there, but... I don\'t have another choice. I cannot take him to the place where I am staying—it is too small and the people who are kindly accommodating me won\'t allow my son. Is there anyone who can help me find a different living situation where I will have room for my son? Right there, a pastor replied, “Yes, the church will help you. I have spoken to my wife and we have agreed to offer our home to your son until you can make the preparations for him to come back home to live with you.” “The church is a family to families. When the church steps up and steps in, the load is lighter and the road is brighter.”

Widows and orphans are a representation of the helpless of the society. Unfortunately, many times, we only consider them as a burden, not people to be cared for. James says that true religion is one that includes the care of the widows and orphans.

James pointed the church\'s attention to the special concern that God has for widows and orphans. If anyone would serve God acceptably, then God\'s concern must be their business. People do not care how much you know until they know how much you care. Do you care for the less-privileged ones around you? Do you contribute to your church\'s care of widows and orphans? God is concerned about helpless widows and orphans and He wants us to be concerned too.

Wisdom : The wise are concerned with what concerns God.

FEBRUARY 15 Thursday

BH 53: God Moves in a Mysterious Way

RBT: Psalms 18-20

PETER'S HEALING MINISTRY

Text: Acts 5:12-16

Golden Text: As a result, people brought the sick into the streets and laid them on beds and mats so that at least Peter\'s shadow might fall on some of them as he passed by. Acts 5:15, NIV

In an article, Matt Sorger, a revivalist, sharing from his personal experience in ministering healing to people, says, communion and intimacy prepares us Ito operate in God\'s healing power. Cultivating God\'s presence, cultivating faith in our heart and acting out our faith; practising prayer and fasting and learning to hear God\'s voice are some of the things that would qualify us to become vessels of God\'s miraculous power.

Peter\'s shadow became a medium of healing for the people. Having seen the awesomeness of God\'s power operating in the lives of the apostles, the people no longer had any doubt about the power of the Gospel.

Jesus is the same yesterday, today and tomorrow; His power does not change. In Peter\'s day, people saw the power of God and believed. Healing miracles are real today just as during the time of the apostles and the purpose of the miracles remain the same - to bring the lost into a relationship with Jesus. The power to operate in the miraculous is still much available as it was then. If we are not experiencing miracles, it is not because God is far away. One reason is that we have lowered the standard when it comes to tolerating sin. Sin weakens the Church and hinders the flow of God\'s power. We are called to change our world for God, subduing the kingdom of darkness as we minister God\'s healing to the sick and oppressed.

title: philip's preaching ministry
message:
FEBRUARY 16 Friday

BH 455: We've a Story to Tell

RBT: Job 13-14

PHILIP'S PREACHING MINISTRY

Text: Act 8:4-8

Golden Text: Philip went down to a city in Samaria and proclaimed the Christ there. Acts 8:5, NIV

Luke mentioned categorically that the persecution arose against the church which scattered the disciples to the regions of Judea and Samaria. Persecution does to the church what wind does to a seed. God allowed it to scatter believers so the whole world could hear the Gospel. Samaria particularly was not a place that a typical Jew would like to go. But that was where Philip found himself. But he never gave up preaching the Gospel. The people of Samaria heard the word, accompanied by signs and wonders, and they believed. “And there was great joy in that city.” (v. 8)
God wants us to move beyond our comfort zones to preach the Gospel. He wants us to take the message of good news to unfamiliar terrains. We must not be silent about the Gospel, even in the midst of intense persecution. When our state in life is not what we want it to be, the Gospel must not suffer.

The Gospel is \'the power of God to salvation for everyone who believes\' (Romans 1:16, NKJV). It is God\'s \'dynamite\' for breaking down sin\'s barriers and setting prisoners free. All believers, in the power of the Holy Spirit, are called to proclaim Christ. Philip preached the Gospel and performed miracles so people would believe. What unfamiliar places or people would God want you to take the Gospel today?

Wisdom : Preparedness to preach the Gospel is a sign of commitment to God.

Food for Thought : How can the lost believe in Jesus without hearing about Him?(Romans 10:14-15)

title: aeneas healed, residents turn to god
message:
FEBRUARY 17 Saturday

BH 258: 'Tis So Sweetto Trust in Jesus

RBT: Isaiah 34-39

JUSTIFIED BY FAITH

Text: Acts 9:32-35

Golden Text: Aeneas, Peter said to him, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and take care of your mat. Immediately Aeneas got up. Acts 9:34, NIV

On many occasions in the book of Acts, miracles accompany the preaching of the Gospel. As Apostle Peter passed through the regions of Judaea Galilee and Samaria, he came to the believers in Lydda. There, he met Aenea who was paralysed and had been bedridden for eight years. Peter said to Aeneas, “Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and take care of your mat.” (v.34). And the man was healed immediately.

Miracles are called signs because they point to something greater accomplished through the preaching of God\'s word. Salvation does not rest on miracles. Salvation comes only by hearing the truth of the word of God, but miracles also give credence to its power. Miracles are tools for evangelism. Apostle Paul affirmed that he had fully proclaimed the Gospel through preaching, and the power of signs and wonders done through the power of the Holy Spirit (Romans 15:18-19). As Aeneas was confined to bed due to physical paralysis, so is a believer reduced to a functionless and powerless being by the forces of secret sins. The highest form of miracle a person can receive is not healing of the body, but of the spirit, which brings about salvation from sin.

The purpose of the miracle was accomplished in that those who saw it turned to the Lord. A genuine miracle moves people toward Jesus, the Miracle Worker. Today, God can still use believers the way He used Peter to wrought miracles in accomplishing His purpose to save all people. Devote yourself to God and let Him use you.

Wisdom : God uses ordinary people to do extraordinary things.

message:
FEBRUARY 18 Sunday

BH 416: Soldiers of Christ Arise

CALLING THE CHURCH TO ACTIVE SERVICE

Text: Acts 9:36-43

Golden Text: In Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha (which . . . is Dorcas), who was always doing good and helping the poor. Acts 9:36,NIV

Each year, rating agencies rank people across the world based on how much they have acquired or achieved in their lifetimes. It feels good to be Edubbed the greatest athlete in the world; the world\'s richest man or the best corporate organisation. But truly, the greatest deeds done on earth are those done for the needy, not for the attention it would attract, but for the sake of the Lord. Dorcas\' faith in the Lord Jesus was seen in her loving, charitable deeds to the needy. Little wonder those she had helped became grief-stricken when she died. They sent for Peter, who came and prayed; then, Dorcas came alive.

Luke\'s description of the earthly ministry of Jesus was that He went about doing good (Acts 10:38). As Christ\'s followers, we are called to emulate our Master in doing good to others in the name of the Lord. Christian service includes acts of kindness towards others; supplying the needs of those who cannot obtain life\'s necessities. Jesus relieved the suffering of people during His earthly ministry. He had compassion for people and did not send them away hungry, lest they faint. We should be encouraged by Dorcas who put her faith to use by helping the needy. Many people are hungry, thirsty, without clothing and desperate around us. Who will care for them? It is your service to God to care for these ones by providing their needs. As the church shares the message of the Gospel to the lost, we should also be involved in meeting their physical needs. May we, by the power of the indwelling Holy Spirit, have the compassion of Dorcas to relieve the suffering of others around us.

Wisdom : Service not status makes you precious to God.

TIMOTHY JOINS PAUL'S TEAM

Text: Act 16:1-5

Golden Text: The brothers at Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him. Paul wanted to take him along on the journey . . .Acts 16:2-3, NIV

When it comes to recruiting people for organisations, employers always say they want team players. Good team players place the objectives and goals of the team above personal interests; and they make every effort to get the work done while harnessing the strength of team members. Apostle Paul understood the power of a team. He knew what it is to be a good team player. On his missionary journey to Lystra and Derbe, Paul met a young disciple, Timothy, whom he felt could enhance the work of the ministry. and he did not hesitate to enlist Timothy in his team. To remove every hindrance to Timothy\'s acceptability to the Jews, Paul circumcised him, not for salvation (for Timothy was already a believer) but so that he (Timothy) would not become a stumbling block to the Jews. Timothy had a good reputation in his home town. It might have been one of the reasons why Paul chose him as a missionary partner. The result of their partnership was seen in spiritual and numerical growth of the churches.

We must not underestimate the power of team work in spreading the gospel. We must shun every tendency to undertake alone what would have been better done in partnership with others. The goal is not for us to be praised but for the glory of God to be seen. What we cannot achieve as individuals, we can achieve as a team. In what area do you need to collaborate with someone to get God\'s work done better?

Wisdom : Teamwork makes the work easier.

Food for Thought : Where do I need to partner with someone for the furtherance of God\'s kingdom?

FEBRUARY 20 Tuesday

BH 181: Wonderful Words of Life

RBT: Genesis 28-31

TIMOTHY, AN ACTIVE TEACHER WITH PAUL

Text: Romans 3:21-31

Golden Text: For this reason I am sending to you Timothy, my son whom I love, who is faithful in the Lord. He will remind you of my way of life in Christ Jesus, which agrees with what I teach everywhere in every church. 1 Corinthians 4:17, NIV

A burning candle has a parallel to teaching. Effective teachers are like a burning candle; they burn brightly for others to see. Without reservation, Paul commended Timothy to the Corinthians as a faithful son in the Lord who will remind them “of my (Paul\'s) way of life in Christ Jesus, which agrees with what I teach everywhere in every church” (v. 17).Teaching in the Christian context is more than mere speaking. It is not theoretical, but practical. A Christian teacher must live in accordance with Christ\'s teaching or the teaching would not be productive. When your teachings and actions agree, it produces integrity and gives authority to your teaching. Then others will see you as an honourable teacher.

Teachers must live above reproach. They must live a truthful life that is worthy of emulation. Teachers must not be proud. They must not live a double life and should avoid engaging in anything that diminishes God\'s power in their lives. Jesus bemoaned the attitude of the Pharisees for they taught things they did not practise (Matthew 23:13ff).Timothy did not just teach, but he was faithful to God in living true to his teaching. What is your life teaching others? If people follow your teachings and way of life, will it lead them to Christ?

Wisdom : Christian teaching is not saying then doing; it is doing then saying..

Food for Thought : Does my life agree with my doctrines?

Follow-up Action : Value integrity in your preaching and teaching ministries.

title: epaphroditus, paul's coworker and minister
message:
FEBRUARY 21 Wednesday

BH 463: Forward through the Ages

RBT: Judges 12-16

EPAPHRODITUS, PAUL'S COWORKER AND MINISTER

Text: Philippians 2:25-30

Golden Text: But I think it is necessary to send back to you Epaphroditus, my brother, fellow worker and fellow soldier . . . Philippians 2:25a, NIV

In the late 1800s, missionaries coming to Sub-Saharan Africa would pack their load in their coffins knowing it was unlikely they would leave Africa alive. Yet, they were willing to bring the Gospel to those who have never heard the name of Jesus, knowing they may suffer malaria, other tropical diseases and even death. They ministered faithfully and willingly for their Lord.

The call to ministry is a call to labour not luxury. Epaphroditus\' name was mentioned in some few short verses of Philippians, but those few verses are loaded with virtues that can endear one to his reputation as a brother, fellow worker and fellow soldier to Paul, and messenger of the church at Philippi. As a fellow soldier with Paul, he fought side by side with him to rescue people\'s soul from hell. As a brother, he was concerned for Paul. He was sent to minister to Paul in prison. While there, he fell sick and almost died. But God\'s mercy kept him from dying. Epaphroditus\' selfless service, even in the face of death, did not go unnoticed. After his recovery, Paul praised him, sent him home and recommended him for honour.

In the midst of unbearable experience for the sake of the Gospel, we should rest assured that we have victory in Jesus. Those who triumphed over the devil by the blood of the Lamb and the word of their testimony were those who did not love their lives so much as to shrink from death (Rev. 12:11). Many times, we find it hard to give up our comfort, time or possessions for the cause of Christ. Epaphroditus gave up his comfort and even his life to serve Paul in prison and invariably God. What are you willing to give up for the sake of the Gospel?

Wisdom : The wise go extra mile for their Lord.

Food for Thought : Are you willing to extra mile for the Gospel?

message:
FEBRUARY 22 Thursday
