RBT: Psalms 21-23

TIMOTHY, PAUL'S ENVOY TO THE CHURCHES

Text: 1 Thessalonians 3:1-10

Golden Text: We sent Timothy, who is our brother and co-worker in God\'s service in spreading the gospel of Christ, to strengthen and encourage you in your faith.1 Thessalonians 3:2, NIV

Over the years, hundreds of missionaries have been forced to leave China; they were often accused of religious infiltration and extremism. One of the missionaries deported said, “When they were taking pictures like I was a criminal, I knew I was being deported, for sure.” Those who were forced to leave are often anxious to hear about the churches and brethren they left behind.

Although Paul was forced to leave Thessalonica (Acts 17:5-10), his affection for the church was not affected. He sent Timothy, another ministry helper like Epaphroditus. Timothy became Paul\'s ambassador to suffering churches. Paul knew the power of encouragement in standing firm in the faith. The persecution faced by the Thessalonian brethren was becoming more intense (vv. 3-5) and Paul knew what that could do to those who are just coming up in the faith. He then sent Timothy to encourage them.

Apostle Paul said Christians are destined for persecution. Some people turn to Christ to escape from suffering on earth, but God did not promise believers a life of ease. The Christian life entails complete obedience to God despite persecution and temptation. As Timothy took encouragement to the church in Thessalonica, he also brought Paul words of encouragement which strengthened his own faith and gave him assurance that his labour was not in vain.

Life can be challenging and we all need words of encouragement. As we expect encouragement from people, let us also give encouragement to people who are burdened or weighed down by life\'s challenges. We can encourage others through counselling, visitation and meeting their needs. Be a source of encouragement to someone today.

Wisdom : The power of encouragement cannot be underestimated.

TEACH THE SOUND WORDS OF CHRIST

Text: 1Timothy 6:2b-8

Golden Text: If anyone teaches false doctrines and does not agree to the sound instruction of our Lord Jesus Christ and to godly teaching, he is conceited and understands nothing.1Timothy 6:3-4a, NIV

Flemings discovery of penicillin marked the antibiotic revolution as it changed the way doctors treat patients with infectious diseases. FPenicillin became the antidote to many sicknesses that used to claim the lives of people. Apostle Paul also teaches that sound doctrine is the antidote to false teaching. Paul admonished Timothy, as a church leader, to combat the false teachings spreading around them with the sound teaching of Christ. Sound teaching of God\'s Word is the most powerful weapon against heresies, strife, malice and wrong perception about faith and ministry.

Ministry is driven by money among some ministers today. Prosperity and materialism are replacing the desire to live the life of Christ; covetousness is replacing contentment in Christ. Paul says, “If anyone teaches false doctrines and does not agree to the sound instruction of our Lord Jesus Christ and to godly teaching, he is conceited and understands nothing” (vv. 3-4a). In combating false teachings, we are not to be docile or passive. Though we are not to quarrel with those who peddle false teachings, we must recognise these teachings and resist them by teaching the sound doctrine of Christ. For our teaching to be sound, we must be well versed in the Word of God and be committed to living it out, in all circumstances.

title: root of many evils
message:
FEBRUARY 24 Saturday

BH 420: My Soul Be on Thy Guard

RBT: Isaiah 40-44

MONEY, ROOT OF MANY EVILS

Text: 1Timothy 6:9-10

Golden Text: For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil. Some people, eager for money, have wandered from the faith and pierced themselves with many griefs. 1Timothy 6:10, NIV

In a world of wealth and affluence, not having money brings frustration to many. Many people struggle to, at all costs, acquire goods and gadgets, Iwhich come out in latest versions, so that others would consider them comfortable. Sometimes we are tempted to think that if only we have more money things would be fine.

In today\'s world, having more money is equated with more happiness. People are always looking for more money, more success, and more luxuries. Almost everything revolves around money such that people lie, cheat, bribe, and kill to get money. In a world such as this, the Scripture warns us against being desperate for money by desiring to get it at all costs. Paul told Timothy that those who want to get rich fall into snares and temptations which can plunge their soul to ruin. When people are desperate for money, nothing else matters. The only thing that matters is to get money – whether through crooked or noble means.

Money is good when it serves God\'s purpose and it does not make us drift away from God. But Christians should live above materialism. We should not run after money to the detriment of enriching our souls for the life to come. Proverbs 10:2 says, “Ill-gotten treasures are of no value.” In the long run, what matters most is not acquiring more money, but godliness and contentment which is great gain (1Timothy 6:6).

Wisdom : Godliness with contentment is great gain.

Food for Thought : Using the Gospel to extort money from others is sin.

Follow-up Action : Eliminate everything that borders on preference for worldly gain over dedication to Christ.

title: the good fight of faith

BH 406: Fight the Good Fight

THE GOOD FIGHT OF FAITH

Golden Text: Fight the good fight of the faith. Take hold of the eternal life... 1 Timothy 6:12, NIV

Fight\' is not a word many love to hear. Not many people like to get involved in fighting of any kind. Those who fight are considered troublesome and are \'often looked upon with disdain. But Apostle Paul says there is a fight that is good, which Christians are called to fight. This fight is not physical but spiritual. Paul enjoined Timothy to fight the good fight of faith. Those who fight wars have a purpose in mind. They do it to secure peace for citizens of their homeland. Paul also said the fight of faith is not aimless. We fight the good fight of faith to take hold of eternal life. In our fight to keep eternal life, we must flee evil and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love and gentleness. We must live blameless lives that await the appearing of Christ. Instead of putting our hope in riches, we must put our hope in God; do good deeds, be generous and willing to share. We must guard what God has entrusted to our care and “Turn away from godless chatter and the opposing ideas of what is falsely called knowledge, which some have professed and in so doing have wandered from the faith” (vv. 20-21).

For us to combat the enemy of our soul, we cannot shy away from the fight of faith. 1 Peter 5:8-9a enjoins us to “Stay alert! Watch out for your great enemy, the devil. He prowls around like a roaring lion, looking for someone to devour. Stand firm against him, and be strong in your faith.”

Each year, in November, citizens of the United states observe a national holiday of Thanksgiving in which families gather to celebrate and make merry. The history of Thanksgiving dates back to the pilgrims who gathered after their first harvest to thank God for the bounty they had received. People tend to forget God or acknowledge His provision and care when they are comfortable. Before entering the Promise Land where there would be plenty, Moses warned the Israelites of the tendency to forget God. The provision of manna was a test to see if Israel would depend on God. When things are rosy, people tend to forget God. As Christians, we should know that whatever we have is given to us by God. Therefore, we should ascribe all glory to Him. God, the giver of all things, should be the centre of our praise. Let us appreciate Him for His daily provisions for us. Take time to reflect on God\'s goodness each day. Keep a record of His goodness and determine to daily remember Him and appreciate all that He has done in your life.

message:
FEBRUARY 27 Tuesday

BH 364: Yield Not to Temptation

RBT: Genesis 32-35

JESUS TESTED IN THE WILDERNESS

Text: Matthew 4:1-11

Golden Text: Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the desert to be tempted by the devil. Matthew 4:1, NIV

Shortly after the Reformation, some young followers of Martin Luther wrote him a letter saying, "We are harassed by many temptations Swhich appeal to us so often and so strongly that they give us no rest. You don\'t seem to be troubled in this way and we should like to know your secret. Don\'t temptations bother you? Are you somehow immune to sin?" Luther wrote them back saying, "I, too, know something of temptation. But the difference is that when temptation comes knocking at the door of my heart, I always answer, \'Go away! This place is occupied. Go back where you came from, for Christ is here.”
That Jesus was led to the wilderness to be tempted by the Devil underscores the reality of temptations for all Christians. The Devil came to test Jesus through His areas of need. Each time the Devil tempted Him, Jesus conquered him with the Word and the authority He carries. Though Jesus\' needs were legitimate, he would not meet them by Devil\'s offers.

Temptation is a reality for us as believers and we are daily tested by the Devil to see how grounded we are in the faith. Each day we face the temptation to meet legitimate needs by ungodly means. Whether we give in or stand our grounds is determined by our knowledge of who we are in Christ. To overcome temptation, you must be born again and maintain an intimate relationship with God. Fasting and praying will help you focus on God and hear Him when He speaks. Follow the Holy Spirit\'s leadership and use God\'s Word to combat Satan when he tempts you. To use God\'s Word as a weapon against temptation demands that you read it, study it, meditate on it, memorise it and manifest it.

Wisdom : Temptation is not sin, but yielding to it is.

BH 252: Faith of Our Fathers

FAMILY LINEAGE OF ABRAHAM PRESERVED

Text: Hebrews 11:17-22

Golden Text: By faith Abraham, when God tested him, offered Isaac as a sacrifice. He who had received the promises was about to sacrifice his one and only son. Hebrews 11:17-18, NIV

William Cowper\'s famous hymn “God works in Wmysterious ways his wonders to perform” underscores the uncommon ways God achieved His purposes to the awe of human beings. One of the stanzas of the hymn states that “Blind unbelief is sure to err; and scan his work in vain. God is his own interpreter, and he will make it plain.”

The road to understanding God\'s ultimate purpose is often fraught with many questions that pop up in our minds. When God asked Abraham to sacrifice his only heir, Isaac, Abraham could have reasoned it out that it did not make sense, and then decide to do otherwise. But faith is not a product of reason. Faith obeys God\'s instruction even when it doesn\'t make sense. Abraham was willing to sacrifice Isaac, at God\'s command, though he knew that he needed a son for his lineage to continue. He practically believed God could raise Isaac from the dead. And God honoured his faith; preserved his lineage by providing a replacement ram for the life of Isaac. He gave Jacob to Isaac and blessed Jacob with twelve sons. God preserved Abraham\'s family and gave them great provisions because of their faith in Him, which they put into action.

More than our profession of faith in Christ, God wants believers to activate their faith by acting on His word even when it seems nonsensical to do so. God\'s covenant with Abraham succeeded generations and eventually culminated in Christ Jesus because in each generation, God found a man of faith who upheld His purpose regardless of the prevailing circumstance. How is your own faith in God? Is it that which is stuck on God even when the road is rough? Are you building a faith that can last generations? Or yours is a faith that can only sustain you for today? May we have a faith, as William Bathurst sang, “that will not shrink...that will not murmur nor complain...that when in danger knows no fear...[but] will lean upon its God.

Wisdom : "He is no fool who gives what he cannot keep to gain what he cannot lose." - Jim Elliot

Food for Thought : What are you holding on to so tightly to that you need to release to God?

Text: Genesis 22:15-19

Golden Text: “I will surely bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and as the sand on the seashore.... because you have obeyed me.” Genesis 22:17-18, NIV

Following orders unquestionably is one of the hallmarks of the military. Junior officers are taught to doggedly follow orders from their superior whether or not they think the command is right. A military officer once said, “We follow higher orders because we know that whatever is commanded is for the overall good of the Army and the nation we are defending.”
God is happy when His children follow His orders unquestionably. Abraham\'s obedience was manifested in that he took a step to relocate when God asked him to (Gen. 12:1-4). His obedience was crowned by his prompt attempt at sacrificing his only son, Isaac. And this did not go unnoticed to God. For the second time, God came to Abraham to reiterate His covenant to bless him and his descendants because “you have done this and have not withheld your son, your only son.” Abraham was not the only recipient of this blessing; his generation was also blessed.

Obedience is the best way to honour God for what He has done for us and to show how much we love Him. How many believers run from pillar to post today seeking after blessing while they treat obedience with levity? How many pay all kinds of sacrifice to attract God\'s blessing while they don\'t count it critical to obey God\'s commands? The Bible is filled with instructions for us to obey the Lord and follow Him wholeheartedly (Deut. 28:1; John 14:23). It is one thing to worship and praise God at church; it is quite another to move out into the world and worship Him through daily obedience. As a magnet will not fail to attract metal so will obedience not fail to attract God\'s blessings. Cultivate daily obedience so you can have daily blessings.

Wisdom : To obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed is better than the fat of rams.

title: god provides the sacrificial ram
message:
MARCH 4 Sunday

BH 286: O God Our Help in Ages Past

RBT: Matthew 23-25

GOD PROVIDES THE SACRIFICIAL RAM

Text: Genesis 22:1-3, 6-14

Golden Text: Abraham looked up and there in a thicket he saw a ram caught by its horns. He went over and took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering instead of his son. Genesis 22:13, NIV

The greatest test of faith that Abraham ever faced was the command to sacrifice his T only son, Isaac. Having waited for 25 long years to have Isaac, God called him one day to go and kill him – that was what it was. Abraham\'s relationship with God was so real that he did not have to doubt if it was God speaking to him or not. He knew God\'s voice so well that he was sure it was God – even when the instruction seemed illogical. “How can God ask me to kill the same son through whom He promised to raise descendants?” Yet, in the midst of this, Abraham still believed God and obeyed His instruction. He concluded that God could raise the dead (Heb. 11:9), and so he set his mind on sacrificing Isaac.

Can you imagine Abraham\'s mood as he set out on the journey to Mount Moriah (which lasted three days) to carry out God\'s instruction? What do you think would be going on in his mind as Isaac asked him, “Father... the fire and wood are here...but where is the lamb for the burnt offering? Abraham answered assuredly, “God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering my son.” And God indeed provided.

God wants us to trust and obey Him even when all does not seem to make sense. Can you trust and obey God even when your physical senses are saying \'no\'? Can you follow Him on a journey to where you don\'t know what will happen? God\'s test is not to break us but to make us. In the midst of our test, He is with us. He wants us to trust and obey Him all the time. And He always honours obedience.

Wisdom : It is sensible to obey God even when it doesn\'t make sense.

Food for Thought : Is your obedience to God complete?

Follow-up Action : Determine to trust God irrespective of your situation.

You also need to realise that being chosen comes with responsibility. God has chosen you in Christ and He is committed to fulfilling His promises to you. GOD CHOOSES TO DWELL IN ZION

The city of Zion used to be just one of the cities in Israel. But when God specially chose it, its status changed forever. God\'s presence is the utmost that anyone should seek in life. In His presence are all that we would ever need for life. When we have God\'s presence, we have direction, and with God\'s direction, success is secured. You are God\'s choice for a dwelling place. You are therefore destined for great blessings. Golden Text: For David did not ascend to heaven, and yet he said, "\'The Lord said to my Lord: "Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet." \' "Therefore let all Israel be assured of this: God has made this Jesus, whom you crucified, both Lord and Christ."Acts 2:34-36, NIV

Burt Saginaw, who died in March 1919 as one of the richest men in America, indicated in his will that nothing from his estate should be shared until 21 years after the death of his last grandchild. The conditions of Burt\'s will were met in 2010, 21 years after the death of his last grandchild in 1989. In 2011, 12 of Burt\'s descendants were able to share his fortune, estimated at about $100 million.

Peter\'s sermon on the Day of Pentecost was punctuated with references to the lordship of Christ as the heir to David\'s throne. Jesus Christ is the fulfillment of the prophecy of the seed of David (2 Samuel 7:14–16). Matthew 1 gives the genealogical proof that Jesus, in His humanity, was a direct descendant of Abraham and David through Joseph, the espoused husband of Mary. David had predicted the resurrection and exaltation of Christ – who would be raised up to sit upon his (David\'s) throne (vv 34-35; Psalm 110:1).

Burt Saginaw\'s will, though considered strange by his family was respected despite the time lag. God\'s promises are more valid. It took generations for God\'s promises through David\'s prophecy to be fulfilled. But it surely came to pass. Jesus came through David\'s family and became the fulfilment of God\'s promises to David. Jesus did not reign for a season; His kingship is eternal. He reigns on the throne forever. Have you given room for Him to reign in your life? Also, are there long awaited promises of God in your life? Trust God; they will be fulfilled in God\'s time and in God\'s way.

Wisdom : Your right to God\'s kingdom is established through Jesus Christ.

title: foreigners welcome in god's temple
message:

BH 293 Love is the Theme

RBT: Job 19-20

FOREIGNERS WELCOME IN GOD'S TEMPLE

Text: 2 Chronicles 6:28-33

Golden Text: As for the foreigner who does not belong to your people Israel but has come from a distant land ...when he comes and prays toward this temple, then hear from heaven, your dwelling place, and do whatever the foreigner asks of you, so that all the peoples of the earth may know ... that this house I have built bears your Name.2 Chronicles 6:32-33, NIV

Racial reconciliation is a major issue for the Church in countries where people are identified or discriminated against based on the colour of their skin. In these countries, it is rare to find white and black believers fellowship together. The problem emanated from the society and the Church has not done much to help the situation. In other climes where the issue is not about the colour of the skin, some believers still discriminate against one another based on their ethnic affiliation, language and other differences.

In today\'s text, Solomon demonstrates the fact that Israel does not have the monopoly of access to the Almighty God. In his prayer of dedication, he thanks God and intercedes for the Israelites. He prays for the people to be heard as they pray towards Jerusalem in repentance in a variety of circumstances like famine, plague, blight or mildew, diseases or disaster. He also envisages that the revelation of God in Israel is not only nationalistic; it reaches out to all peoples everywhere. The temple is to be a house of prayer for all nations (see Isaiah 56:6-7). He, therefore, prays that people outside of Israel may come to know God through this temple and that their prayers will be heard (vv. 32-33).

As believers in Christ, our concern for others should go beyond the natural tendency of affiliating with those from our people group. The gospel of Christ is not for some selected group of people, but for all nations (Matt. 28:19-20). Through His death, Christ has broken every wall of partition that has separated peoples of all races, and in place of hostility, He has given us peace to dwell with one another without any discomfort (Eph. 2:14). In Christ, no one is a foreigner, for we are all one in Christ.

Wisdom : God accepts all who come to Him in true submission and humility

PRAYERS OF REPENTANCE DURING CAPTIVITY

Text: 2 Chronicles 6:36-40

Golden Text: When they sin against you... and if they have a change of heart...in the land of their captivity where they were taken, and pray toward the land you gave their fathers... then from heaven, your dwelling place, hear their prayer... And forgive your people, who have sinned against you. 2 Chronicles 6:36-39, NIV

The story was told of a man, Jones, who was caught by Tan, stealing chicken in a dairy farm where they both worked. Jones begged Tan not to report him to their boss. Tan agreed but with a condition that Jones would take his shift the following week. Jones agreed, but Tan kept coming to give Jones one thing or the other to do for him, or else he would report him. Whenever Jones was reluctant, Tan would say, “the chicken”, and that would be it. One day, wearied by the burden of being Tan\'s slave, Jones decided to report himself to their boss, who scolded him, but eventually forgave him. The next time Tan came, and said, “the chicken,” Jones told him to go ahead and report to the boss.

Sin brings captivity, and humans constantly struggle with sin. This reality was not hidden from Solomon (verse 36). Solomon predicted the exile experience of the Israelites and pleaded with God to hear the prayers of His people once they pray towards the temple in Jerusalem, from wherever they might have been taken captive. Solomon asked that God would hear the people as they repent and submit to God. Centuries later (586 BC), Daniel in exile prayed towards the temple in Jerusalem (Dan. 6:10) just as Solomon predicted. Right there in Babylon, Daniel prayed a prayer of confession (Daniel 9:3ff) and God heard.

Today, we do not need to look towards any particular temple to pray to God. God is everywhere and He indwells His children. But when we sin, He wants us to come in penitence of heart, confess to Him, and repent of the sin. Like Jones, we will be set free from sin\'s captivity once we make up with our Father, who is always ready to forgive.

Wisdom : Submission to God attracts divine mercy.

Food for Thought : Where do I turn to when I sin against God?

Follow-up Action : Confess your sins to God and repent of them.

He wants to be our passion, vision, and mission. He wants to be involved in all of our lives, not a part of it. When we are completely dedicated to God, it will not be hard to yield to Him all that we possess. Our dedication should be absolute, and without any reservation.

During the US civil war, Abraham Lincoln met with a group of ministers for a prayer breakfast. At one point, one of the ministers said, “Mr President, let us pray that God is on our side.” But Lincoln said, “No, gentlemen, let us pray that we are on God\'s side.”

The context of today\'s text is a discussion that the Jews had with the man born blind who received his healing from Jesus. The leaders were out to discredit Jesus. In fact they concluded that Jesus was a sinner because the healing took place on a Sabbath day. The healed man\'s response (v.31) shows us the manner of worshippers that God listens to – God-fearing and obedient people.

Worship is relationship with God based on love, and Jesus says, “if you love me, you will obey what I command” (John 14:15). Worship is our response to God\'s love as we express our love to Him. It is not just what we do in church but a life that we live in consonance to the will of God – obeying His instructions. It should be a total adoring response to God\'s revelation of Himself to us per time. Our acts of worship do not only consist in Bible study, prayer, and meditation on the scripture, but culminate in wilful obedience to God\'s commands. God seeks worshipers who not only come to raise their hands to Him in church, but those who also go out in the week, living their lives in obedience to His instructions. Will He find such a worshipper in you?

Wisdom : Our worship is right only when we are right with God.

Food for Thought : Do I restrict worship to Sunday only and neglect worshipping God with my life during the other days of the week?

The Lord Almighty will bless them, saying, "Blessed be Egypt my people, Assyria my handiwork, and Israel my inheritance." Isaiah 19:23-25

Movement across countries of the world is restricted by borders. And patrols have been assigned to guard these borders to ensure that people do not move in anyhow. Sometimes, it looks like we have built a border around our worship centres too, and some people are not allowed to come in.

Today\'s text presents a prophecy of international worship of God. According to the passage, the day will come when Egypt will build an altar to the God of Israel within the borders of their country. The altar will have such impact that “the Egyptians will know the Lord in that day” (Isaiah 19:21). Also, there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria (v. 23), an indication of free movement from one country to the other. A highway is a main road that links cities. In place of borders of restriction, there would be a free way that encourages free movement. Egypt will be in friendly relationship with Assyria because of their common allegiance to the Lord and Israel will not be left out of this awesome experience of the worship of God.

This was a picture of the Church that Christ was going to redeem with His blood. The death of Christ breaks every barrier between peoples of the earth and provides a free way to the worship of God for all who have received Him. As followers of the soon-coming King, we have a mission to proclaim the Good News of salvation to all nations. Our worship of God must be without boundaries. We must not hinder others from coming to God because they are \'different\' from us. Rather, we should embrace peoples of every nation in the name of Christ.

message:

BH519: We Would Worship Thee

RBT: I Samuel 1-5

HEZEKIAH ARRANGES A WORSHIP SERVICE

Text: 2 Chronicles 29:25-30

Golden Text: As the offering began, singing to the Lord began also, accompanied by trumpets and the instruments of David king of Israel.2 Chronicles 29:28, NIV

It is always amazing to see an orchestra performance. The ensemble of the bowed instruments, percussion, wind and brass instruments usually gives a symphony that is hard to describe with words. Imagine the large number of musicians that are usually involved in the orchestra. The music they produce is often one that transcends the barriers of language, and can transform listeners and viewers from the natural to the supernatural.

In 2 Chronicles 29 we find Hezekiah succeeding his father, Ahaz. Though Ahaz had denigrated the worship of Yahweh, Hezekiah came as a reformer. He arranged for a special worship of God as he assembled the priest and the people, purified the temple and asked officials to bring animals for a sin and burnt offering. Hezekiah made elaborate preparation for the worship of God by appointing the Levites with different instruments of music. He positioned the Levites in the temple with cymbals, harps, and lyres (v.25); as the Levites stood, ready with David\'s instruments, the priests stood with their trumpets. As the offering began, the people sang to the Lord, accompanied by instruments, and the whole assembly bowed down in worship. “So they sang praises with gladness and bowed their heads and worshipped” (v. 30b). Hezekiah did so in obedience to all the commands that the Lord had given to King David.

We will achieve much when we all work together like musicians in an orchestra to produce inviting and lifetransforming sounds to the world around us. In place of a worship service that is centred around some few people, where it looks like others have come to see a show, we should seek a service where everyone participates and all have something to contribute. We all have been gifted by the Holy Spirit, and when we come together, we have the duty of ministering to God and then to one another. “The more we work together, the happier we\'ll be.”

Wisdom : Worship becomes more meaningful when we are all united in the Spirit.

Food for Thought : Do you offer to the Lord a joyous, reverent thank offering because of His grace shown to you through the blood of Christ?

Follow-up Action : Introduce musical instruments into your family worship, and make the worship a celebration of God and a joyful experience.

In October 25, 2013, the news broke of three women who had been held against their will in a house in London but were rescued after 30 years of bondage and forced labour. How happy they were to be free! Like the story of these freed women was in the news, the psalmist encouraged those redeemed by God to tell their story.

The experience of the Israelites in exile was not a pleasant one. They were afflicted by their enemies (v.2); they were scattered to unknown places and wandered in the wilderness, lonely and with no place to stay (vv. 3-4) Hungry and thirsty, their soul fainted in them (v. 5). But when they cried out to the Lord, in their many troubles, the Lord heard them, and delivered them from their enemies. God did not only deliver them, He also led them out and brought them to a place of their own (v. 7). The psalmist, therefore, call on all the redeemed to tell their story of deliverance, and give thanks to God, for His goodness and His mercy that endures forever.

Praise is due to God for His works of mercy and goodness that we receive every day. Many times, God had delivered us from troubles that we thought would take our lives. In His mercy, He has not allowed the enemy to afflict us beyond what we can endure. He has redeemed our lives from the pit and from destruction that has taken the lives of many, not because we are better than those but because of His mercy towards us. What then should we give in return to this merciful God? The psalmist encourages us recall the terrible experiences, and also tell how God delivered us. As much as our prayer for deliverance was, so should our praises be.

HEALED AND FORGIVEN

Text: Psalm 107:17-22

Golden Text: Then they cried to the Lord in their trouble, and he saved them from their distress. He sent forth his word and healed them; he rescued them from the grave. Ps 107:19-20, NIV

We live in a fallen world and one of the realities of the fall is sickness. Sin caused the fall and brought with it many troubles, not just because God wants to punish humanity but because sin paves way for the devil to strike. Sin is breaking God\'s rules and it is a natural consequence that when sin takes place, there is corruption – of what God had created.

Though not all sicknesses come as a result of sin, the psalmist says sin could be a reason for sickness. He explains how fools bring sickness upon themselves, to the point of death, as a result of sin. Fools neither believe in God nor acknowledge His ways. A fool lives life as s/he wants without any thought about God and His ways. But when sickness came and they were on the verge of death, these fools cried out to God, who had mercy on them, and “He sent forth his word and healed them; he rescued them from the grave.” The psalmist then asked them to give thanks to the Lord for His wonderful deeds to them; they should sacrifice thank offerings and tell of His works with songs of joy (vv. 21-22).

Not because of anything we had done, God sent His Son to die for our sin, and pave way for our forgiveness. By the stripes with which He was beaten, we constantly receive healing and wholeness of soul. Telling the story of our healing and forgiveness honours God, and tells of His goodness as the rescuer of His people. When the people cried to God for deliverance, He forgave and healed them (v. 20). Golden Text: And King Solomon offered a sacrifice of twenty-two thousand head of cattle and a hundred and twenty thousand sheep and goats. So the king and all the people dedicated the temple of God.2 Chronicles 7:5, NIV

The temple\'s dedication brings to mind the words of Robert Murray McCheyne to Dan Edwards after the latter\'s ordination as a missionary. Robert wrote: “In great measure according to the purity and perfection of the instrument, will be the success. It is not great talents God blesses so much as great likeness to Jesus…”

All of Israel had gathered in Jerusalem to celebrate the completion of the temple Solomon had built for God. It was a time of great excitement and elaborate celebration. But in the midst of this celebration, Solomon did not lose sight of the One to whom the temple was built and should be dedicated. So he offered prayers to God. At the end of his prayer, fire came down from heaven, consumed the offering and sacrifices, and the glory of the Lord filled the house (v. 1). The glory was so awesome that the priests could not enter into the house of the Lord (v.2). That was God\'s response to the sacrifice of His people and a mark of acceptance of the temple being dedicated to Him.

Dedicating something to God has to do with identifying Him as the Owner of that thing and releasing it for His use. Today, the temple is not a building but our bodies. Paul wrote: “Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit... Therefore honor God with your body.” (I Corinthians 6:19-20) When God\'s people worship Him in acceptable ways, we cannot miss out the presence of His glory, approval and blessings. May our lives be offered up as acceptable sacrifices, holy and pleasing unto Him. And may we not for once miss His glory and blessings.

Wisdom : Dedication is not merely a service for Christians; it is a lifestyle.

Food for Thought : Our success in this life is dependent on our dedication and devotion to the Lord Jesus Christ.

Follow-up Action : Rededicate yourself to God for His use.

title: god's activists
message:
MARCH 19 Monday

BH399: I Gave My Life For Thee

RBT: I Corinthians 7-8

GOD'S ACTIVISTS

Text: Isaiah 58:6-12

Golden Text: "Is not this the kind of fasting I have chosen: to loose the chains of injustice and untie the cords of the yoke, to set the oppressed free and break every yoke? Isaiah 58:6, NIV

Martin Luther King Jnr was an American Baptist minister and a civil rights activist. King believed that racism, which was the norm in America, is an affront to God\'s will, and he fought it with his life. Activists are known for their resoluteness in whatever cause they are fighting. They often campaign for social change and they are actively involved in protests for a particular social or political cause. Isaiah takes to task those who perform religious duties while oppressing the helpless, and failing to help those who are weak. While the citizens of Judah were fasting, they neglected the clear instructions from the Lord to care for the less fortunate among them and to treat them as members of their own family.

The kind of worship pleasing to God includes a desire to live an upright life and to help the poor and oppressed. Being God\'s activists means taking our faith into every sphere of life, including the workplace, politics, economics, education, and the arts. We should not take a passive stance, waiting for God to deal with social evils. Rather, we should confront them by living an upright life. Fasting should result in selfdenial, not self-indulgence. Religious activities are not bad in themselves, but God wants us to translate our activities into godly lives dedicated to serving Him and others. What is the use of going to church everyday when our lives do not bless others who do not know God? How can we claim to know God when people cannot feel any aroma of godliness in and around us? Our knowledge of God should translate into holy living, a life that impacts others positively to the glory of God.

Wisdom : Inner righteousness, as opposed to a hypocritical outer righteousness, will be revealed in acts of charity and justice.

Food for Thought : Could God be manipulated through fasting and prayer?

Follow-up Action : Meet the basic needs of life of someone today.

Prayer : O Lord, help me to imitate You by acting for the betterment of humankind.

message:

RECONCILIATION MAKES GIFT GIVING JUST

Text: Matthew 5:21-26

Golden Text: Therefore, if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you, leave your gift there in front of the altar. First go and be reconciled to your brother; then come and offer your gift. Matthew 5:23-24, NIV

Elisha A, Hoffman\'s hymn, “Is thy heart right with God” explains clearly the importance of a right heart in God\'s sight. One of the stanzas of the hymn states, “Is there no more condemnation for sin? Is thy heart right with God? Does Jesus rule in the temple within? Is thy heart right with God?”As important as giving to the Lord is, Jesus says reconciling with our brothers and sisters should take priority. This is an indication that the worship that the Lord seeks is one that focuses more on the state of our heart than the magnanimity of our outward activities. True religion, according to Jesus, is not one that claims that once God is pleased, it does not matter if our fellow brother or sister is displeased. Leaving our gift before the altar signifies an incomplete worship, and what makes it complete is a right heart with God which offers forgiveness and reconciliation to offenders.

The kind of offering that God seeks is not just the offering of our financial gifts but a total offering of our lives to Him in complete obedience to His commands. To reconcile means to settle offences, apologise for wrongdoing, and seek to mend broken relationships. God considers being at peace with others a greater gift than our money, and He wants us to seek reconciliation without delay.

Wisdom : Unresolved anger is a sin that disrupts our worship and offering to God.

Food for Thought : If God takes anger and insults against our brothers seriously, should we take it lightly?

title: treat others fairly with compassion
message:
MARCH 21 Wednesday

BH217: Throw Out the Lifeline

RBT: I Samuel 6-10

TREAT OTHERS FAIRLY WITH COMPASSION

Text: Exodus 22:21-29

Golden Text: Do not mistreat an alien or oppress him, for you were aliens in Egypt. Do not take advantage of a widow or an orphan. Exodus 22:21-23, NIV

A grandpa once lived with his family. As the Grandpa grew older, he began to slobber and spill his food. So, the family had him eat alone. At a time, he broke his bowl; the son and his wife scolded him and got him a cheap wooden bowl. Grandpa was so unhappy. One day the grandson was carving wood. His mom and dad asked him, "What are you doing?" "I\'m making a wooden bowl," he said, "for when you two get old and must eat alone."The parents were sad; they could not imagine being treated like they treated the grandpa. The Israelites were commanded to care for others as a remembrance of their experience in Egypt. God made this very clear when He told them to treat those of lesser social rank as they themselves would want to be treated. They are forbidden to "afflict" some categories of people like the stranger, the fatherless, the widow, and the poor. Because their experience in Egypt was not a pleasant one, God wanted them to learn not to treat others cruelly, but to treat them with compassion as they would like to be treated.

Our world today is filled with many people who lack feelings for others. Many needy people suffer because of neglect or oppression by the rich and powerful but God is interested in them because of His own compassionate character (v.26b). Christians have the same responsibility to the poor and downtrodden as Israel had. As God\'s children, we have the responsibility of helping the helpless in whatever capacity we can. We must live true to the popular church slogan that “whoever you have the ability to help is your neighbour; take care of him or her.” God expects us, as His people, to hear the cries of the powerless, defend their rights, and care for them.

Wisdom : The closer you are to God, the more you will have a heart for others.

RBT: Psalms 33-35

LIFE IS THE BEST CHOICE

Text: Deuteronomy 30:15-20

Golden Text: This day I call heaven and earth as witnesses against you that I have set before you life and death, blessings and curses. Now choose life, so that you and your children may live. Deuteronomy 30:19 NIV

Choices are the blocks upon which life is built. We will always have to make choices, and every choice we make comes with consequences. While the consequences of some choices can be immediate and momentary, other choices can have eternal consequences.Moses was virtually telling the Israelites that life is full of choices.

The relationship between God and the Israelites had constantly gone through the up-and-down cycle of highs and lows. Moses reminded Israel of all God had done for them – deliverance, provision and all. He reminded them of God\'s teachings and rules which they need to follow throughout their lives. Now on the verge of crossing to the Promised Land, he presented them with two options– life and death. Choosing to do good comes with life while choosing evil comes with death.

It is presented to everyone alive to choose between life and death, and the choice always determines the consequences. But choosing life has always been better by far. Jesus says eternal life is knowing the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom He has sent (John 17:3). “Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life, but whoever rejects the Son will not see life, for God\'s wrath remains on him” (John 3:36). To have life is to choose Jesus Christ; to choose anything else is to choose death. Have you made a choice of Jesus? The time is right now. Tomorrow may be too late.

Wisdom : Maturity is recognizing that the choices we make carry consequences.

title: faithful walking key to solomon's rule
message:
MARCH 23 Friday

BH370: Walk in The Light

RBT: Job 23-24

FAITHFUL WALKING KEY TO SOLOMON'S RULE

Text: 1 Kings 9:1-5

Golden Text: As for you, if you walk before me in integrity of heart and uprightness, as David your father did, and do all I command and observe my decrees and laws, I will establish your royal throne over Israel forever... 1 Kings 9:4-5, NIV

Walking before God or with God is a common metaphor in the Scripture, especially the Old Testament. God told Abraham to walk before Him and be blameless (Gen. 17:1). It was said of Enoch that he walked with God (Gen 5:24).What does it mean to walk with someone? To walk with someone, you have to be in close proximity with that person. It means to focus your attention on that person alone as you ignore all other things going on around. It could also involve talking with the person, laughing with them and sharing your hearts as you walk along.
Just as walking with someone requires focusing attention on that person, walking before God involves realising His presence which gives us strength to be perfect before Him. After the completion of the temple, God appeared to Solomon the second time, confirming answer to his prayers and affirming His presence in the temple. But God also told Solomon that he had to walk before Him in uprightness and integrity of heart as his father David had done. God stated that for Him to fulfil the promise He made to David – of always having a son on the throne – Solomon had a personal responsibility of walking before Him with a perfect heart.

God created us for a walking relationship with Him, and the secret to a fruitful and blessed walk with Him is faithfulness. Walking is progressive; it is not static, and God expects us to grow in grace as we mature in Christ. To be faithful in our walk with God is to have our loyalty to Him alone. It means being perfect and complete, focusing our passion and desire on what God wants alone. The opposite is being double-minded, seeking alternatives outside God. How is your walk before God? When we shun all distractions, and live to please God alone, then our blessing shall be great and lasting.

Wisdom : If we maintain an attitude of faithfulness, God\'s blessings will be established upon us.

Food for Thought : The blessing that God pours on us is not just for us alone but also for our family and those around us.

Follow-up Action : Identify a promise from God and depend on Him with absolute confidence for fulfilment.

Prayer : O Lord, help me to walk before you and be blameless.

DANGEROUS RESULTS OF UNFAITHFUL ACTIONS

Text: 1 Kings 9:6-9

Golden Text: But if you or your sons turn away from me and do not observe the commands and decrees I have given you and go off to serve other gods and worship them, then I will cut off Israel from the land I have given them and will reject this temple I have consecrated for my Name. Israel will then become a byword and an object of ridicule among all peoples.1 Kings 9:6-7, NIV

St. Augustine says, "There can only be two basic loves, the love of God unto the forgetfulness of self, or the love of self unto the forgetfulness and denial of God." God warned Solomon and his descendants against such forgetfulness which could make God withdraw His blessings from them. The promise of judgment for sin is a promise that we must take seriously. God knew that Solomon would not remain faithful and true in all things. God also knew that the kings who would follow Solomon would not be as faithful either, so God issued His conditions for the continued blessing of Israel and the judgment that would befall them for their unfaithfulness and disobedience. God frowns at unfaithfulness in all its manifestations. He desires that we stay true to Him, without looking for options outside of Him. Whenever we engage in unfaithfulness, we make God unhappy as we also lose His presence. Whenever we lose His presence, we give room for untold things. Many people who had once served Jesus are now facing the terrible judgment of God against their family, finances and homes because of sin in their lives. Whatever God has called you to do, make sure you stay faithful and put your all into your work for Him.

Wisdom : Once honesty has been breached in some form, it becomes easy to stop upholding the truth elsewhere.

BH260: “When we walk with the Lord”

RBT: Mark 3-4

RESULTS OF SOLOMON'S DECISIONS AND ACTIONS

Text: 2 Chronicles 7:12-22

Golden Text: ...if you walk before me ... and do all I command, and observe my decrees and laws, I will establish your royal throne.... But if you turn away and forsake the decrees and commands I have given you and go off to serve other gods and worship them, then I will uproot Israel from my land.2 Chronicles 7:17-21, NIV

In response to Solomon\'s prayer (1 Kings 3:5-9), God appeared to him by night to assure him that He had chosen the temple as a place of His dwelling. God blessed the temple and filled it with the glory of His presence. God also promised that during difficult times (drought, locusts, pestilence) if the Israelites would humble themselves, pray and seek His face at that temple, He would answer their prayer, forgive their sins and heal their land (2 Chronicles 7:14). God stated clearly that He had chosen and sanctified the temple, and that perpetually, His eyes shall be open, His ears attentive to the cry of His people, and His heart shall be there. For Solomon, God promised to establish his throne as He had promised his father David. On the other hand, God also promised to uproot him as well as the temple if they forsook the Lord to go after other gods.

The continuous reign of Solomon and his descendants was tied to their continuous obedience to God. God showed the Israelites the result of their decisions and actions. God is faithful but He wants us to also remain faithful to Him. Oswald Chambers said "Nothing is so important as to keep right spiritually." Many people want God\'s blessing but do not want God. They reject biblical morality, ignore God\'s Word, and rely on the political and entertainment arenas for moral guidance. Christians cannot afford to be disobedient to the commandment of God neither can we be unfaithful in our service to Him. Whenever Christians compromise godly principles, we walk dangerously close to destruction.

Wisdom : The promises of God often hinge on our obedience to Him.

Food for Thought : What could be the results of my current actions and decisions?

JESUS FORETELLS HIS SUFFERING AND DEATH

Text: Mark 8:31–9:1

Golden Text: He then began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders, chief priests and teachers of the law, and that he must be killed and after three days rise again. Mark 8:31, NIV

A year before he was killed, Martin Luther King, Jr. preached on the "Fierce Urgency of Now." He warned his hearers, "If we do not act, we shall surely be dragged down the long dark and shameful corridors of time reserved for those who possess power without compassion, might without morality, and strength without sight."Jesus began to speak to His disciples about His sufferings and death shortly after they identified Him as the Messiah. Peter rebuked Jesus because he only had human concerns and lacked the concern of God and His will.
Why did Jesus not live in fear of His suffering and death, like many of us do today? He was telling the disciples that they have to be familiar with the road of cross bearing; leave the worn path of success, power, prestige, and glory to follow the path of losing oneself to Him. He wanted them to know that the way to glory is not only decorated with flowers and fragrance, but also with suffering and dying to self. Today, some, like Peter, only want the pleasant part of the Christian life. They are not willing to suffer but they want the crown and the glory. Jesus said, “If anyone would come after me, he must deny himself, and take up his cross and follow me. For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for me and for the gospel will save it” (vv. 34b-35). May we receive strength and courage today to pass through the goads on our journey to glory.

Wisdom : Triumph would make us proud, if accompanied by humility.

Food for Thought : Do I want my comfort at the expense of the will of God?

title: do this in remembrance of me
message:
MARCH 27 Tuesday

BH393: In Memory of the Saviour\'s Love

RBT: Genesis 48-50

DO THIS IN REMEMBRANCE OF ME

Text: 1 Corinthians 11:23-26

Golden Text: ... The Lord Jesus, on the night he was betrayed, took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it and said, "This is my body, which is for you; do this in remembrance of me." In the same way, after supper he took the cup, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood; do this, whenever you drink it, in remembrance of me."1 Corinthians 11:23-25, NIV

Rcently, my spouse was clearing some stuff in the house and came across some of our old pictures. This afforded us the opportunity to look at those pictures again, and it brought back memories of people we have met in life, some of them now old, some far, and others near. A particular one reminded us of a brother, who, though late now, has done something that would forever keep him in the hearts of those he met on his life\'s journey. Memories are powerful because they remind us of our pasts and give us a renewed vision for the future.

On the night Jesus was betrayed, He broke the bread, and shared wine with His disciples. In both instances, He reiterated the words: “do this in remembrance of me.” Apostle Paul had to bring this to the remembrance of the members of the Corinthian church to help them link up with the history of the Lord\'s Supper and give them a new perspective on sharing the Lord\'s body and blood.

Every time the Church gathers together and partake of Lord\'s Supper, we participate in a living illustration of the Gospel message. With reference to His broken Body Jesus wants us to remember the pain of His sacrifice on the cross. The salvation we enjoy today is free for the taking, but it cost the Lord Jesus Christ His life on the cross. From the Cup, we remember the shedding of His blood for a new covenant. Christ, by His once for all sacrifice, paid for all our sins. He gave Himself in our place so that we might go free from the penalty of our sins. Also, we remember the promise of His resurrection, that the Saviour who died for us on the cross is alive today. And He is coming back again.

Wisdom : The measure of your life is not in what you receive, but in what you give .

Food for Thought : Do I always remember the reason for the Lord\'s Supper?

title: first examine yourselves, then eat

FIRST EXAMINE YOURSELVES, THEN EAT

Text: 1 Corinthians 11:27-34

Golden Text: A man ought to examine himself before he eats of the bread and drinks of the cup.1 Corinthians 11:28, NIV

Quite often people look into the mirror to assess themselves and then improve on their outward look. In the same way, Paul told the Corinthians to undergo a spiritual examination to have a correct assessment of their spiritual status. One specific problem the Corinthian church had was with the way they worshipped. Before they celebrated the Lord\'s Supper, they would have a time when they shared the Scriptures and ate a meal. There the rich were getting drunk and the poor were starving resulting in internal strife preceding the Lord\'s Supper. Thus, many became weak and sick, and some died. God had to discipline them to bring them back to the faith.

Paul was saying that there is a way that we can approach the Lord\'s Table unworthily, and actually sin against His body and blood. We need to be prepared to receive the Lord\'s Supper by examining ourselves. A stern warning appears in our passage today to judge ourselves whenever we approach the Lord\'s Table, or the Lord Himself will judge us. A daily examination of our spiritual status is necessary not only in preparation for the Lord\'s Supper but to prevent spiritual weakness or illness. Scripture says “Examine yourselves to see whether you are in the faith; test yourselves” (2 Cor. 13:5). God has given us His Word and the Holy Spirit to help us in this daily examination.

Wisdom : Just as we go to the doctor for a physical examination; we need to go to the Word of God for a spiritual examination.

title: wash one another's feet
message:
MARCH 29 Thursday

BH431: Make Me a Blessing

RBT: I Samuel 14-15

WASH ONE ANOTHER'S FEET

Text: John 13:1-5, 12-17

Golden Text: Now that I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also should wash one another\'s feet. John 13:14, NIV

What would you be doing if you knew that you had less than twenty-four hours to live? Perhaps, you would be praying to be spared from death. Or maybe you would be doing some lastminute confession of sin. Less than twenty-four hours away from Jesus\' death on the cross, He washed the disciple\'s feet. His mind was set on preparing His disciples for His imminent departure. Jesus was not perturbed by His imminent death because He “...knew that the Father had put all things under his power, and that he has come from God and was returning to God...” (v.3).Because Jesus knows His origin and His destiny, He was able to serve others. In response to this knowledge, He showed Himself to be a servant of humanity and left us a vivid portrait of the kind of heart we are to have for others.

Service is grounded in love. In verses12-17, Jesus poses a question to His disciples to make sure that they have really caught this truth. He then follows up His question with a powerful declaration: “You call Me Teacher and Lord; and you are right, for so I am.\' If I then, the Lord and the Teacher, washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another\'s feet” (vv. 13-14). One of the greatest incentives to serving others is to recognise that Jesus Christ has a vast, unconditional love for you. When you begin to grasp this love, it will motivate you to serve others as an expression of gratitude to Jesus.

title: women first witnesses to empty tomb
message:
MARCH 30 Friday

BH428: Must JesusBear the Cross Alone

RBT: Psalms 36-38

WOMEN FIRST WITNESSES TO EMPTY TOMB

Text: Luke 24:22-24

Golden Text: ...some of our women amazed us. They went to the tomb early this morning but didn\'t find his body. They came and told us that they had seen a vision of angels, who said he was alive. Luke 24:22-23, NIV

During the Battle of Waterloo on June 18, 1815 England thought the battle was lost because fog disrupted the news transmission and the country was thrown into despair. But when the fog lifted they could see the final word, "Wellington defeated Napoleon." And their mood changed from one of tragedy to triumph.

The two disciples on their way to Emmaus were crestfallen, and the future, for them, seemed bleak considering their experience of Jesus\' death since three days. Their conversation with Jesus showed their disappointment, first of all at Jesus\' death, because they thought He was the one to physically redeem Israel from the grip of Roman oppression. The climax of their disappointment was that it was three days after Jesus had been buried. Though, they were conversing with Jesus Himself, they could not identify Him. The only light they could see in their dark experience was the news that the women who went to the tomb that morning brought – that Jesus was risen. Mary Magdalene, Joanna, the other Mary (mother of James one of the apostles) and other women had gone to the tomb to anoint Jesus\' body. Two angels appeared to them, announcing that Jesus is no longer to be found among the dead. With this angelic reminder (24:8), the mood of the women changed, and they immediately went back to the disciples and broke the news to them.

The women became the first set of witnesses and proclaimers of the resurrection because of their passion and commitment to the Master. We all must learn from these women. If we would be witnesses of Christ to the world, then we must also be His committed seekers. For us to be light in the darkness of this world, we must be willing, amidst odds, to seek Christ, know Him in a definite encounter and be ready to proclaim Him to the world.

Wisdom : The resurrection proves the claim of Jesus that He was who He claims to be.

Food for Thought : Are you joined to the resurrection power of Jesus?

Follow-up Action : Tell someone about your encounter with Jesus.

Prayer : O Lord, help me to seek You that I may be light to my generation.

title: jesus meets disciples on emmaus road
message:

BH109: Come, Ye Faithful, Raise the Strain

RBT: Job 25-26

JESUS MEETS DISCIPLES ON EMMAUS ROAD

Text: Luke 24:13-21

Golden Text: Now that same day two of them were going to a village called Emmaus... They were talking with each other about everything that had happened. As they talked and discussed these things with each other, Jesus himself came up and walked along with them; Luke 24:13-15, NIV

It was H.G. Wells, British author (1866-1946) who said “I am an historian, I am not a believer, but I must confess as a historian that this penniless preacher from Nazareth is irrevocably the very centre of history. Jesus Christ is easily the most dominant figure in all history.”

Easter is big for many people, but they just do not know why. They look but they do not see. That happened to two depressed disciples of Jesus on the way to Emmaus, a village seven miles out of Jerusalem. They had seen the \'tragedy\' that took place as it unfolded before their eyes. Jesus was arrested, tried, beaten, spat on, insulted, and ultimately they saw Him die a cruel death on the cross. The story did not end there because Jesus rose from the grave but they had not yet realised it. The discouragement showed on their faces and in their speech. When Jesus drew near, they were eager to tell Him the whole story as well. People who are depressed talk too little or too much without coming to any encouraging conclusions. Throughout the eleven kilometres of walking and talking, they were still discouraged. Their hearts were heavy and their look forlorn. But their meeting with Jesus changed their situation. Jesus brought them out of their distress.

Situations change when Jesus gets involved. If only we would recognise His presence in our times of distress. If only our hearts will not be so bowed that we refuse to see Jesus, the Light in the dark nights of our soul. Jesus\' resurrection brought hope and that hope is still with us today. May we forever recognise His voice and presence which is able to deliver us from our distress.

Wisdom : The remedy to discouragement is the discovery that Jesus is alive.

Food for Thought : What can keep you from recognising Jesus?

Follow-up Action : Help someone to recognise Jesus as the Son of God.

Prayer : O Lord, remove every impediment that keeps me from recognising You.

message:

RBT: Jeremiah 1-6

JESUS LIVES AGAIN

Text: Luke 24:1-12, 30-35

Golden Text: He is not here; He has risen! Remember how He told you, while He was still with you in Galilee. Luke 24:6, NIV.

Life is about beginnings and endings. Beginning signals the existence of a thing or person while ending signals termination. Endings come with finality. When we lose loved ones, we mourn and grieve at the reality of never seeing them again. We experience pain because we wish they never died in the first place. But the resurrection story tells us that endings may not be final after all. Death is not the end of every life.
The women who went to anoint Christ\'s body met an empty tomb and angels who declared to them that the Lord had indeed risen. Therefore, they hurried to share the good news with other disciples. As a confirmation, Jesus appeared to two other followers on their way to Emmaus. They had, along with other disciples, forgotten the Lord\'s promise of resurrecting. However, at the breaking of bread, their eyes were opened and they recognized the Lord. This great encounter made the men return to Jerusalem immediately, to confirm that the Lord had truly risen.

The resurrection story is not only for Easter; it is a story for every day. It is the reality and assurance of life after death. It is the anchor of our hope that after here, there is life in eternity, where all who have made Jesus the Lord of their lives would reign with Him forever. Many people have died and resurrected in history, but none has lived forever – only Jesus rose again and lives forever. Those who are in Christ cannot die; they live eternally, because Christ has conquered death for them. With this assurance in you, share the love of Christ, and the hope of resurrection with an unbeliever today.

title: the reasons for the resurrection

THE REASONS FOR THE RESURRECTION

Text: Luke 24:36-49

Golden Text: He told them, \'this is what is written: the Messiah will suffer and rise from the dead on the third day, and repentance and forgiveness of sins will be preached in His name to all nations. Luke 24:46-47, NIV

Famous artist, Michelangelo once turned on his fellow artist in displeasure. He said: “Why do you keep filling gallery after gallery with endless pictures on the one theme of Christ on the cross, and most of all, Christ hanging dead? Why do you concentrate on the passing episode as if it were the last work, as if the curtain dropped on Him with disaster and defeat? That dreadful scene lasted a few hours. But to the unending eternity, Christ is alive; the stone has been rolled away and He rules and reigns and triumphs!”

As the men from Emmaus were narrating their encounter with the Lord Jesus, the Lord stood in their midst and said \'Peace be with you.\' Startled and frightened, they thought they were seeing a ghost, but the Lord showed them the scars of the nails on His hands and feet. He also ate in their presence. Jesus then explained to them that His death and resurrection were a fulfilment of God\'s purpose as contained in the Scriptures. He also told them that the Messiah had to suffer, as it is written, so that repentance and forgiveness of sins would be preached in His name.

\'Peace be with you\' is a regular greeting of the Jews, but this one comes from the resurrected Lord, who alone can give peace to startled, terrified and troubled souls. When you invite the resurrected Prince of Peace into your situation, He finds a lasting solution to it and also gives you rest. Jesus died and resurrected to offer forgiveness to all who would turn to Him in repentance, so as to give them eternal life. Have you received the forgiveness that Jesus offers?

PAUL – WITNESS TO THE RESURRECTED CHRIST

Golden Text: For what I received I passed on to you as of first importance: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures. 1 Corinthians 15:3, NIV

Witnesses play a pivotal role in criminal cases. The testimony of a credible witness often forms a significant part of evidence which helps the jury to discharge and acquit the innocent, and condemn the guilty appropriately. Before meeting Christ personally, Apostle Paul was vehemently opposed to the disciples of Christ. He was very passionate about Judaism, and hated those who believed in the resurrected Lord, Jesus Christ. His passion led him to take permission to kill those who belonged to the Way. But he was accosted on his way to Damascus by Jesus Christ Himself, and he became a Christian. Having witnessed the resurrection, he became a credible witness, and his testimony, a part of the evidence for resurrection.

Because Paul had met the resurrected Lord personally, it was easy for him to say, “For what I received I passed on to you as of first importance: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures, that he was buried, and that he was raised on the third day according to the Scriptures” (vv. 3-4).You can only speak well of a person or an event you know so well. Have you personally encountered the resurrected Lord? You can do that today, if you have not done so. The best way to share the Gospel is to have an experience with the resurrected Lord.

Ministry success is erroneously measured today by the number of worshippers, the size of worship place, the type of car(s) that the man of God is using as well as the status of members, among other things. Philip\'s ministry in Samaria was very successful (Acts 8:5-8), yet God instructed him to leave the “cathedral” and to run after “a man” who needed salvation. Philip obeyed God\'s command without delay, which is a measure of God\'s assessment of success. By the power of the Holy Spirit, Philip identified the eunuch, explained the Scriptures to him and led him to salvation in Jesus Christ.

Philip\'s obedience in the power of the Holy Spirit brought Christianity to the African continent. God cares for a single soul as much as He cares for a city or a nation. Like Philip, Christians today should be obedient and humble enough to take any assignment which God may be giving them. The Holy Spirit is the power of evangelism. He is the fire that burns in the sin-wearied souls and brings them to conviction to accept salvation. E. M. Bounds says, “What the Church needs today is not more machinery or better, not new organizations or more novel methods, but men whom the Holy Ghost can use....” Our evangelism will have the right effect when we give room for the Holy Spirit totally in our lives.

Gregg Cochlan\'s book, “Love Leadership: What the World Needs Now” seeks to chart a new course in leadership called Love Leadership. Cochlan believes that love should not only enhance the way leaders lead, but that leaders should strive to increase their capacity to love as they relate with others.

During the process of Christ\'s restoration of Peter, Christ reminded him of the importance of loving Him to doing His work. Three times, the Lord asked Peter, “Simon son of John, do you love Me more than these?” Jesus knew that Peter loved Him, but He had to ask him the same question three times to emphasise the importance of loving Christ to serving Him. Each time Peter answered that he loved Him, Jesus told him: “Feed my sheep.” After settling the issue of love, Christ said to Peter, “Follow Me” (v. 19).

True love, rooted in Christ, is the basis for successful leadership, and Christian leaders who want to be successful must follow Christ consistently to increase their capacity to love those they lead. Leadership is tough, Christian leadership inclusive; but those whose passion to lead is rooted in Christ will find it easy to lead their followers to where Christ wants them to go. Love will cause a leader to make sacrifices even when it is not convenient; love will motivate you to have selfless concern for others. Are you a parent? Lead your children in love to follow Christ as you also follow Him closely. Are you a pastor, follow Christ daily and lead your members with the love of Christ. As a Christian, you can lead others to Christ through love.

Wisdom : The heart of the matter is true, unconditional love for the Master.

Text: John 20:30-31; 21:24-25

When witnesses provide evidence in a courtroom, the judge and the jury are empowered to make the right choice in judgment. Though the messiahship of the Lord Jesus has been denied severally, John testifies that there are many signs which Jesus performed in the presence of His disciples, but which are not recorded. This is not because they are not worthy of mentioning, but because the ones that are recorded are enough to believe in Jesus as the Messiah and the Son of God. So, John as a firsthand witness of the life and ministry of Christ shares his own testimony. How do we know that his testimony is true? By studying the Scriptures, we are able to understand the life and mission of Jesus fully and share in the eternal life that He offers. title: jesus serves breakfast to the disciples
message:
APRIL 8 Sunday

BH 178: Break Thou the Bread of Life

RBT: Jeremiah 7-11

JESUS SERVES BREAKFAST TO THE DISCIPLES

Text: John 21:1-14

Golden Text: Jesus came, took the bread and gave it to them, and did the same with the fish. John 21:13, NIV

One of the theories against Jesus\' resurrection is that the disciples merely hallucinated about seeing the resurrected Lord. But today\'s passage makes it clear that it was nothing like hallucination. After two prior appearances to the disciples after His resurrection, Jesus again appeared to them at the sea of Tiberias. Perhaps still disillusioned about what next to do after Jesus\' resurrection, Peter told the other disciples of his intention to go back to fishing. Because he was the leader of the group, others decided to follow him. Having toiled all night, with nothing to show for it, the disciples must have resigned to fate. Then, Jesus appeared to them on the shore. They did not recognise Him at first, but after Jesus had given them direction as to where to catch fish, John was able to identify Him. Jesus did not only help them to catch multitude of fishes, He also provided breakfast for them. This is another confirmation that Jesus rose bodily from the grave.

Nutrition experts have emphasised the importance of breakfast to the body, especially to growing children. Since it is the first meal of the day, it replenishes the energy already spent during the night. Jesus\' eating of breakfast with the disciples is symbolic. Just as physical breakfast re-launches us into a new day, the same way Jesus re-commissions the disciples. A daily breakfast from Jesus also helps to launch you into the day. A life of self-sufficiency and service outside Christ, no matter how sincere, will bring no reward. On the other hand, a life connected to the Lord enjoys divine provision, guidance for success and the peaceful presence of the Master. Depending on the risen Lord for everything will definitely ensure a bright and beautiful day, any day. Peter was restored and re-commissioned after the breakfast. As you position yourself for an encounter with the Lord each day, may you be refreshed and re-energised to live a fulfilled life.

Wisdom : Staying connected to the Lord ensures unfailing provision.

title: peter denies jesus three times
message:
APRIL 9 Monday

BH 350: Is Your All On The Altar?

RBT: Mark 7-8

PETER DENIES JESUS THREE TIMES

Text: John 18:15-18, 25-27

Golden Text: Again, Peter denied it, and at that moment a cock began to crow. John 18:27, NIV

A man of God was arrested and interrogated by the police in a communist country. When the interrogation became tough, he thought that denying Christ so as to live to continue to witness for Him was the best choice. After twenty years, he admonished everyone on his death bed never to deny Jesus, because the Spirit of God left him the day he denied Christ. His life was empty for twenty years. Peter\'s strength could not carry him to identify with Jesus at the most crucial time. When Jesus predicted Peter\'s denial, Peter hastily refuted it (John 13:36-38) as he said vehemently that he would die for the Master. But when the moment came, he failed Jesus woefully. If only he had asked for grace to stand! Realising his failure, Peter wept bitterly (Luke 22:62). He wept for his sin; for his empty boast to stick with Jesus even in difficult times.

Following Jesus is a lifelong commitment, and is not something we can do by the power of flesh. Times will come when our faith in Him will be challenged and the only thing that would carry us is the strength that only He can give. Turning back from Jesus is denial. Inability to identify with Jesus is also denial. Peter\'s experience points to how swiftly a person can fall from the peak of moral goodness to the pit of guilt and shame. Like Peter, many of us are guilty of denying the Lord in important areas of our lives by hiding our identity in times of pressure. Move towards restoration today by asking for forgiveness. You need to also ask the Lord today for grace not to deny Him, especially in times of trouble.

Wisdom : Denying Christ at critical times is a sin.

title: thomas moves from doubt to faith
message:
APRIL 10 Tuesday

BH257: My Faith Looks Up to Thee

RBT: 1 Corinthians 13-14

THOMAS MOVES FROM DOUBT TO FAITH

Text: John 20:24-28

Golden Text: Then He said to Thomas, “put your finger here; see My hands. Reach out your hand and put it into My side. Stop doubting and believe. John 20:27, NIV

\'Seeing is believing.\' is a popular saying that shows the natural tendency of every human to see things before they accept them as true. This was what happened to Thomas. He did not believe the other disciples when they told him that the risen Lord had appeared to them because he was not present when the Lord appeared to them. Thomas was on a journey, and he had a moment of doubt about Jesus\' resurrection. But it is comforting to note that he did not remain in doubt. He eventually saw the Master and believed. Thomas could exclaim, “My Lord and my God” because he came to a place of personal faith and trust in the risen Christ. We are often quick to criticise Thomas, but each of us needs to examine our life and see where we are in the journey of faith. Faith is personal and is not something you derive from people’s stories about their encounter with the Lord. It is something that you have as you cultivate a personal relationship with the Lord. So, where are you in your journey of faith? Have you come to a place of assured trust like Thomas or you are in a state of blind belief in which you can only talk about God\'s dealings with others? In the face of life\'s challenges; when it seems that prayers are not answered; can you exclaim that Jesus is still your Lord and Master based on your personal knowledge of Him? Or you doubt whether He is even alive? Our Lord was not hard on Thomas for doubting; instead He showed the proofs Thomas sought. As He said to Thomas, Jesus is saying to you, “Put your finger here; see my hands. Reach out your hand and put it into my side. Stop doubting and believe.” (v. 27).

Wisdom : When you doubt and the Lord provides the answer, let it deepen your faith.

Food for Thought : God is real. His presence is with every believer, there is no reason for doubt.

Follow-up Action : Resolve to be in God\'s presence every day in order to experience His power.

title: go proclaim the good news
message:
APRIL 11 Wednesday

BH459: Ye Christian Heralds

RBT: Exodus 5-8

GO PROCLAIM THE GOOD NEWS

Text: Matthew 10:5-15

Golden Text: As you go, proclaim this message: “the Kingdom of heaven has come near.” Matthew 10:7, NIV

In his autobiography, \'Why Not the Best\', Jimmy Carter, a former President of the United States, and a committed Christian told of his experience at his home church, Plains Baptist Church. They used to have a week of mission in which members would go out into the community to witness to unchurched people. When Carter was to speak at another church on \'Christian Witnessing\', he used his achievement of having visited over 140 homes in his neighbourhood in fourteen years. But then he realised that in his 1966 campaign for Governor of Georgia he had gone out and met at least 300,000 people in an attempt to convince them to vote for him. He said, “The comparison struck me – 300,000 visits for myself in three months, and 140 visits for God in fourteen years!”
Having empowered His disciples, Jesus sent them out to preach the kingdom of God to neighbouring villages. Later, He sent out seventy-two out of His disciples with the same message of good news to the world (Luke 10:1-9, NIV). The Message translation renders verse 5-7 this way: “Don\'t begin by traveling to some far-off places to covert unbelievers. And don\'t try to be dramatic by tackling some public enemies. Go to the lost, confused people right here in the neighbourhood. Tell them that the kingdom (of God) is here.”

We need to be deliberate about proclaiming the good news, beginning from our neighbourhood. Just like Carter realised, many of us find it easy to visit or talk to people in our neighbourhood about other things – politics, entertainment, sports, and the like – while we find it unfashionable to tell them the good news about Christ. Around us are hurting souls who need the message of hope from God, and it is our responsibility to proclaim it to them. How many visits have you made for the the sake of the Gospel this year, and how many have you made for yourself?

Wisdom : The world, filled with bad news, needs the good news of hope.

Food for Thought : Am I preaching the Gospel or hoarding it?

Follow-up Action : Decide to step up action in sharing the goodnews from today.
