title: as labourers go into the harvest
message:

BH 432 “Bringing in the Sheaves”

RBT:1 Samuel 21-25

AS LABOURERS GO INTO THE HARVEST

Text: Matthew 9:35-38

Golden Text: Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into His harvest field. Matthew 9:38, NIV

Harvest time is the crown of each farming season. The harvest makes farmers happy because their efforts have yielded result. The work is, however, not finished until the harvest has been gathered into the barn. This is when the farmer\'s joy is complete. Gathering in the harvest often requires extra hands, and where the farmer cannot get enough helping hands on time, it may lead to loss of the farm produce. This often brings untold pain to the farmer who had laboured so much. Jesus likens bringing people into the kingdom of God to labourers bringing in the harvest. As He went about cities and villages teaching, preaching and healing people\'s diseases, He saw multitudes, who were scattered and helpless. Jesus was moved with compassion and He compared them to harvest waiting for labourers.

Jesus\' prayer for more labourers into God\'s harvest reveals God\'s mind about the lost souls who are heading to hell, except someone intercepts them with the message of eternal life with Jesus. Christians are God\'s hands and legs today to take the good news to the hurting, harassed and helpless world. As a believer, it is your duty to show Christ to someone. You gladden God\'s heart the way a labourer makes the farmer happy at harvest, by praying and preaching to lost souls. Many people are ready to accept Christ only if they can find someone who will show them the way. God is looking for labourers. Will you make yourself available today to prevent His harvest from wasting away?

title: other sheep will listen to me
message:

BH400: Something For Thee

RBT: Psalms 42-44

OTHER SHEEP WILL LISTEN TO ME

Text: John 10:11-18

Golden Text: I have other sheep that are not of this sheepfold. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd. John 10:16, NIV

Helen Baylor grew up in a Christian home, but she chose to become a secular entertainer. She became a famous drug-drained performer who had a big name in the entertainment industry. But she had a grandma, who all these years, kept praying for her to meet with the Saviour Jesus Christ. It took many years but Grandma\'s prayers got answered. Today, Helen sings to the glory of God. In a song and a movie dedicated to her grandma, Helen tells the tearful story of how God honoured her grandma\'s prayer and brought her to salvation.

When Jesus talked about \'the other sheep\', He was talking about potential believers. Jesus had a universal view of His kingdom which is bigger than one denomination. Today, many believers look at other Christians who are not from their denomination with disdain. Jesus\' fold is larger than one denomination, because we all together form \'one fold\', and we have one Shepherd – Jesus Christ. The other sheep is found in Jesus\' prayer for those who would believe in Him through the message of the disciples (John 20:17). If you have been saved, you are one of the \'other sheep\' Jesus mentioned, and He wants you to go after others who are yet to be in the fold. Like the wounded, straying little dog that brought another dog to its kind healer in order to have a taste of the love it has enjoyed, we should also bring others to the Lord after we have experienced Him, irrespective of race, gender, age and social differences. Don\'t build fences around the grace of God. You are to love people who are not members of your family or tribe and to share the Gospel with them.

Wisdom : Spiritual gifts, experience, relational style, vocational skill and enthusiasm are tools to bring others to Christ.

title: lose your life for my sake
message:
APRIL 14 Saturday

BH 439: “Ready”

RBT: Job 29-30

LOSE YOUR LIFE FOR MY SAKE

Text: Matthew 10:34-39

Golden Text: Whoever finds their life will lose it, and whoever loses their life for My sake will find it. Matthew 10:39 (NIV)

Persecution against Christians during Emperor Nero\'s reign was brutal. Believers were skinned alive, thrown into hot oil, thrown to hungry lions or drawn by carriages until they died. They encouraged themselves not to deny Christ, but to be ready to die for Him. A man was tied to roller table with his head and feet pulled apart. When he felt he could no longer bear the pain, he recanted and denied Jesus. As he was released from the roller table, he died.

Jesus\' words “Do not suppose that I have come to bring peace to the earth. I did not come to bring peace, but a sword” should not be taken literally. By this statement, Jesus stated the reality that those who believe in Him would be set up against those who do not. Sword is a weapon of war, and so Jesus told His disciples that they should be ready for war that would be waged against them by even members of their own household. It would be a test of loyalty where they would have to choose where their affections would lie – whether to deny Jesus and love their people who hate Him, or love Jesus to the ire of their family members.

Christians face this test of loyalty every day. We are often torn between losing our comfort, rights, privileges and even physical lives for the sake of the Gospel. This is war. Jesus is calling us to remember that our commitment to Him is much more important than any other person, including our lives. It is either we spare or sacrifice our lives. Sparing one\'s life would make one a loser, while sacrificing one\'s life for Christ will make one a winner. Let your resolution be to live and to die for Christ, releasing your lower life for the greater one above.

Wisdom : The real war is between selfishness and sacrifice.

Food for Thought : The best way to enjoy life is to follow Christ and forgo greed.

Follow-up Action : Make a renewed commitment to remain in Christ forever.

title: follow me and feed my sheep
message:

FOLLOW ME AND FEED MY SHEEP

Text: John 21:15-25

Golden Text: …Then He said to him, \'follow Me!\'John 21:19, NIV

William Hendriksen said, “Attachment to Jesus is an absolute necessity for serving Christ in this world and the next. And in His mercy Jesus is willing to award this great privilege to a person who has a very short résumé, listing only that he or she has a very humble kind of love to offer to his/her Lord.” Peter\'s encounter with the Lord in this passage is a defining one. He had denied the Lord and forsaken Him, but he had been forgiven. After restoring him, the Lord needed to be sure of his love. Christ desired to trust His friend. He, therefore, asked Peter whether he loved Him. Peter answered in the affirmative, and the Lord gave him two instructions: \'Feed My sheep\' and \'Follow Me.\'
The test of love is in how much we are ready to serve those we love. You cannot say you love the Lord without having the willingness to serve Him. In serving the Lord, following Him in a constant and experiential relationship is a prerequisite to doing His will. The key mission of the Church as well as her leaders is to follow Jesus, and then feed His sheep. Following Jesus is the key to fulfilling our mission of feeding His sheep. In following Him, we become His disciples; in feeding His sheep we disciple others. As we follow the Master closely, He guides and directs us on how He wants us to do His business. And it is in that we will have good success. A genuine love for Jesus will keep you following Him, and as you follow Him, you will be able to feed the sheep He has assigned to you.

Wisdom : The true believer lives a godly and sacrificial life.

Food for Thought : When a life comes in contact with Jesus, it experiences a change. Has my life experienced change?

title: judas returns money, hangs himself
message:

JUDAS RETURNS MONEY, HANGS HIMSELF

Text: Matthew 27:3-10

Golden Text: So Judas threw the money into the temple and left. Then he went away and hanged himself. Matthew 27:5, NIV

In the short story, “How Much Land Does a Man Need?”, Leo Tolstoy told of a successful peasant farmer who was not satisfied with what he had. He wanted more of everything. One day, he got a cheap offer to buy all the land around his farm, but with a clause that he must walk round the land in a day if it must become his. Fascinated by the idea of owning everything, the farmer set out on the journey. He ran and ran so he could reach the end of the land and then come back to the starting point. As the sun began to set, he came close to the finish line. He gathered every bit of strength left in him to reach the line before sunset. He immediately collapsed, blood streaming from his mouth. In a few minutes, he was dead. Afterwards, his servants dug a grave - six feet long and three feet wide - and buried him.

Judas appeared to be following Jesus physically but his heart was not with Jesus. He was consumed by greed which eventually consumed him. He allowed himself to be deceived and captured by the devil through his desire. Seeing what he wanted, he betrayed his Master. When he realised the futility of his action, he returned the money and hanged himself.

Greed is subtle and many times we do not know when it begins to eat up our lives. Many are following Jesus not because they want to serve Him but because of what they would get from Him. Many are in the church only for what they can grab from others. Remember that not all that glitters is gold. Watch your desire and pursuit in life. Know for certain that lasting joy lies in Jesus Christ alone. And if you have been caught up in the web of greed, there is still hope for you. Repent of your sins and return to God; He is faithful to forgive and deliver you from destruction.

Wisdom : Any life that dwells in sin has signed in for is charting the path of destruction.

Food for Thought : What is your utmost desire? Your desire determines your end.

Follow-up Action : Watch your actions and your thought, and view every action in the light of the principles of the Word of God.

title: jesus crucified
message:
APRIL 17 Tuesday

BH 91: “O Sacred Head, Now Wounded”

RBT:1 Corinthians 15-16

JESUS CRUCIFIED

Text: Matthew 27:32-44

Golden Text: “When they had crucified him, they divided up his clothes by casting lots.” Matthew 27:35, NIV

In his book, The Life of Christ, Frederick Farrar describes Jesus\' crucifixion: “A death by crucifixion seems to include all that pain and death can have of the horrible and ghastly—dizziness, cramps, thirst, starvation, sleeplessness, traumatic fever, shame, publicity of shame, long continuance of torment, horror of anticipation, mortification of intended wounds—all intensified just up to the point at which they can be endured at all, but all stopping just short of the point which would give to the sufferer the relief of unconsciousness.” Jesus\' experience before and at crucifixion was nothing but horrible. He was mocked, hit, spat on, and given vinegar mixed with gall. Different people heaped insult on Jesus Christ as He was about to finish His task on the cross. This, however, did not distract Him. Jesus finished well because (1) He understood the will of His Father (2) He identified the distractions around Him (3) He endured the pains and suffering (4) He was looking forward to the joy that was ahead.

Jesus took the pain, insult and eventually gave in to death because of you and me. For the joy of giving eternal life to all who would believe in Him, He endured the pain of the cross. His suffering and affliction brought us redemption. God has a purpose for you too, and you must understand the mind of God and identify the distractions around you. You must endure whatever God has planned for you by focusing on the joy that lies ahead of you. Perhaps you are yet to identify with the suffering and agony of Jesus by offering Him your life. Today is another opportunity; don\'t let it slip by.

Wisdom : Distractions will certainly come, but the wise focus attention on their assignment and the Sender.

Food for Thought : Distractions are caused by self, sin, and Satan. Have I given in to them?

Follow-up Action : Identify areas you have been distracted from your divine goal and make a decision to retrace your steps.

GUARDS SECURE THE TOMB

Text: Matthew 27:62-66

Golden Text: So they went and made the tomb secure by putting a seal on the stone and posting the guard. Matthew 27:66, NIV

They killed Him, rolled a big stone against His tomb, put the seal of authority and detailed soldiers there.These were not ordinary but high profile professional soldiers who have been trained to maintain air-tight security. The chief priests and the Pharisees persuaded themselves that Jesus\' tomb would have to be super secured to prevent the fulfilment of Jesus\' prophecy that He would rise on the third day. MARY MEETS JESUS OUTSIDE THE TOMB

Text: John 20:11-18

Golden Text: Jesus said to her, “Mary.” She turned toward him and cried out in Aramaic, “Rabboni!” (Which means Teacher). John 20:16, NIV

The story was told of a time when Martin Luther King was feeling depressed. He was dejected about some life\'s experiences. One day his wife dressed in black and went about her chores for the day. When her husband asked her if she was going to a funeral, she said, “No, but since you act as though God is dead, I thought I\'d join you in the mourning.” That became the message he needed to come out of his depression. Mary Magdalene was so dejected when she got to the tomb and discovered that Jesus\' body was no longer there. Her grief over the death of Jesus and the \'disappearance\' of His body beclouded her to the extent that she mistook the same Lord for a gardener. Jesus brought her to consciousness when He called her name, \'Mary\'. It was then she knew it was the Master. How mistaken she had been to have asked for the body of Jesus when she should be talking to the risen Lord!

Like Mary, several believers are looking for Jesus among the dead. Under the guise of seeking God, some play into the hands of fake ministers who take advantage of their lack of depth in the Word of God to lure them into heretic practices. Jesus Christ is no longer in the tomb but is alive forever, revealing His power to as many as are eager to seek Him.

title: reigning triumphant with christ

REIGNING TRIUMPHANT WITH CHRIST

Text for the Day: Revelation 20:1-6

Golden Text: …And I saw the souls of those who had been beheaded because of their testimony for Jesus and because of the word of God… and they lived and reigned with Christ a thousand years. Revelation 20:4, NIV

In view of success at the end of a tournament, Iathletes always prepare and discipline themselves. They go through the rigours of training, subjecting themselves to pain, denying themselves of the comfort that many people enjoy. Why do they do that? They have a goal in view and they want to give all it takes to get it. Because of the prize that awaits them, they count the momentary discomfort as nothing.

Those who will reign with Christ must be ready to endure discomfort. Apostle John saw the vision of an angel coming down from heaven with a key to the bottomless pit and a great chain in his hand. With this chain the angel bound Satan up, threw him into the bottomless pit, and sealed it for a while. He also saw judgement thrones and the souls of the saints that were beheaded for their witness of Jesus and the word of God. These believers lost their lives because they refused to worship the beast or receive his mark. This earned them a seat to reign with Christ.

Christians must be ready to deny themselves in all areas in view of gaining heaven. Each day comes with a test of our devotion and situations that seek to determine where our loyalty lies – whether in Christ or in this world. This is why we must continually brace up in power of the Lord to face these challenges and come out victorious at the end. Nothing in this life is worth losing our eternal reign with Christ for. Having given our lives to Christ, we must be ready to suffer for Him; we must never compromise our faith for the pleasures of this world. Examine yourself - in what ways have you been compromising the faith? Are you carried away with the king\'s delicacy that corrupts? Repent today and stand firm on your confession of faith. Prepare to reign with Christ in glory as you endure suffering for His sake.

message:

Text: Isaiah 2:1-4

Golden Text: “In the last days the mountain of the LORD\'s temple will be established as chief among the mountains; it will be raised above the hills and all nations will stream to it.”Isaiah 2:2 NIV

The world is chaos and daily challenged by sin, fear and the devil. The world runs into the Church, hoping to find rest for her soul. Will the Church be available to save this dying world? Isaiah\'s prophecy presents the Church as the solution centre to the problems of the world. He presents the Lord\'s house as a place where many would be willing to go so that they can be taught God\'s ways, and walk in His paths. From this house, the law of the Lord and the Word of God shall go forth. This house will judge nations and rebuke many people. This was a picture of the coming kingdom of Christ which the Church shall represent.

The Church today is not just the building but the body of those who have been redeemed by the blood of Jesus. God\'s expectation for the Church is that we would determine the course of things in nations; that we would teach people His Word and cause them to do His will. But is this the picture we have today? Are we in that position that God wants us to be? Is the Church playing her role as an agent of God in this nation? Many times, we complain about the decadence in our society, but fail to look inwards and see where we are failing in our God-given assignment, and make amends. As a believer, you are a part of Christ\'s Church because you carry the Holy Spirit inside of you. Wherever you go, God expects you to declare His kingdom and cause His will to be done there. Are you living up to this expectation?

Wisdom : The Church is God\'s remedy for the decay in the world.

To build the body of Christ, believers are charged to put on a heart of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience, making allowance for each other\'s faults, forgiving and loving one another. As the different parts of the human body work together to accomplish a goal, so has God graciously connected believers to one another for mutual building and uplifting. Any time we fail to understand this, it always leads to lack of fulfilment. Influence is a powerful weapon that can make or mar lives. Everybody has one influence on one person or the other. Parents have influence on their children; leaders have influence on their followers, teachers on their students, government on the citizens, kings on their subjects. On the Sabbath, Paul and his company moved out to a certain riverside where people gathered to pray. There they met some women who had come there to pray. Paul took the opportunity to preach the Gospel to the women. One of the women, Lydia, believed the Gospel because God opened her heart. She was a woman of great influence who later served as a channel of taking salvation to her household. Through her, the Gospel expanded to other parts of the world. She gave both her life and her service to God and His people. How do you use your influence on others? Remember, you are a steward and you will give account to the Lord.

title: jailer and household baptised
message:

BH204: Nothing but the Blood

RBT: Exodus 13-16

JAILER AND HOUSEHOLD BAPTISED

Text: Acts 16:25-34

Golden Text: At that hour of the night the jailer took them and washed their wounds; then immediately he and all his family were baptized. Acts 16:33 NIV

Household salvation is one recurring theme in the ministry of the apostles. Apostle Peter\'s visit to Cornelius\' house, after being convinced of the Holy Spirit, brought about household salvation. Cornelius got saved with all members of his household who heard the gospel message. Lydia\'s salvation also spread to members of her household not only because of Lydia\'s influence but also because the people heard the Gospel and believed.

Apostle Paul had another experience of household salvation with the jailer. Paul and Silas were thrown into jail because they delivered a girl of an evil spirit with which she had been doing fortune telling. The owners of the girl realised that their means of livelihood was gone without the evil spirit in the girl\'s life. So, they instigated an uproar and had Paul and Silas thrown into jail by the magistrates. Instead of glooming over their predicament, the apostles kept praising God. At midnight, as they were praising God, there was a great earthquake and the prison\'s doors opened, and their chains broke loose. The jailer who was sleeping woke up, thought that the prisoners had escaped, and was going to kill himself. But Paul cried out to him not to kill himself, and that they had not escaped. On hearing this, the jailer bowed to them, asking what he must do to be saved. Paul and Silas had not preached to the jailer but their life had preached a great message to him. Seizing the opportunity, they told him that he only needed to believe on the Lord Jesus and he would be saved, with his household.

Paul\'s emphasis on household salvation shows that God is interested in saving a whole household. God is not only interested in you getting saved but that all members of your household should be saved. What efforts are you making for the salvation of members of your family? God is counting on you to take the salvation message to them. Will you extend God\'s love to them? Or do you want them to perish?

Wisdom : God loves everyone, so should we.

Food for Thought : When last did I preach to a member of my family who is yet to be saved?

title: reaching new people
message:
MARCH 1 Thursday

BH 457: “Send the Light”

RBT:2 Samuel 1-4

REACHING NEW PEOPLE

Text: Acts 18:5-11

Golden Text: Crispus, the synagogue ruler, and his entire household believed in the Lord; and many of the Corinthians who heard him believed and were baptized. Acts 18:8, NIV

No one likes to be rejected. Rejection often brings a feeling of being inadequate and could lead to withdrawal. Apostle Paul faced fierce Nrejection in his attempt to preach to the Jews. The Jews opposed and abused him, and he had no choice but to withdraw from them. But did Paul withdraw from preaching the Gospel totally? No. Rather he looked for another opportunity to preach the Gospel, this time to the Gentiles. As Paul left the Jews, he entered the house of a man named Justus, a ruler of the synagogue, whose house was closely attached to the synagogue but never knew the Lord. When Justus heard the good news he believed, not only him but also members of his household. Through Justus, the Gospel also reached many Corinthians, who also believed and were baptised. Paul\'s move to reach the Gentile community with the Gospel pleased God who encouraged him to keep on speaking without fear, “For I am with you, and no one is going to attack and harm you, because I have many people in this city" (v. 10).

Rejection was not an excuse for Paul to stop preaching the Gospel; so it should not be for us. We have been given a message of hope for people in our world, and failure to deliver it will mean that we have left people in bondage whom we should have delivered. When was the last time you delivered this message in your hand? Maybe you have a fixed way of preaching the message or a set of people you think should be reached with the message. You need to reach out to new people by the power of the Holy Spirit. Are there people like the synagogue ruler who are religious but are not saved around you? God wants you to reach out to them. Sometimes, God only waits for you to take that step of faith, and He will back you up with result. Reach out today, and deliver that message in your hand. Stop holding back and you will see God backing you up.

Wisdom : God\'s work done in God\'s way will never lack His provision.

Food for Thought : Man\'s ways are not God\'s ways.

Follow-up Action : Identify areas of divine road block and where God wants you to be.

message:

MATTHIAS CHOSEN TO REPLACE JUDAS

Text: Acts 1:12-26

Golden Text: Then they cast lots, and the lot fell to Matthias; so he was added to the eleven apostles. Acts 1:26, NIV

Life is not a right but a privilege given by God. This privilege, however, comes with responsibilities. Every opportunity to live and do something should be seen as a way to be a right steward of God\'s grace. The disciples returned from Mount Olivet, the point where Jesus Christ ascended into heaven. They had seen Him face-to-face after the resurrection; their boldness had returned as they had been commissioned to spread the gospel of Christ. Therefore, they came together in unity of spirit, praying alongside the women, one of which was Mary the mother of Jesus; his brothers and other disciples. But then, they were eleven core disciples after Judas had hanged himself. Rising from the prayer, Apostle Peter admonished the brethren, quoting prophecies as bases for a replacement for Judas. To affirm the divine choice, the disciples first established the mind of God through the Scripture; second, they prayed for guidance, and third, they took action by faith. Matthias was then chosen to replace Judas, who had the grace but wasted it because of his selfish ambition.

The work of God must progress and only those who make themselves available would be used of Him. Jesus invested so much in Judas Iscariot, but he failed Him because of his unguided desire. God could not but replace him because the ministry must continue. In ascertaining God\'s choice in selecting people to work, we must be cognisant of His will as we situate it in the Scripture through prayer, and be ready to act in faith as God leads. We need to learn that there is always alternative for every fallen warrior. God has several substitutes who are qualified, even far greater than us, but in His infinite mercy, He has decided to use us. We should, therefore, not take His grace for granted.

Wisdom : No one is irreplaceable; don\'t give in to inordinate ambition, thereby declaring your space vacant.

Food for Thought : Am I giving room for any inordinate desire that can disqualify me from God\'s service?

message:
APRIL 28 Saturday

BH433: The King's Business

RBT: Job 33-34

DISCIPLES CALLED AND COMMISSIONED

Text: Matthew 28:16-20; Acts 1:6-8

Golden Text: Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them… and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you… Matthew 28:19-20, NIV

D.L. Moody was once invited to a convention to speak on “How to do mass evangelism”. He arrived at the venue before time, asked his song leader to lead a song, which called people\'s attention and gathered a crowd. Moody mounted the podium and preached the Gospel to the crowd. As he was about rounding off, the delegates of the convention started arriving. Then, Moody said, “We must close now to give room for the organisers of this convention to speak on “How to reach the masses.” While others talked about the how-to of preaching the Gospel, Moody actually preached it.

At a mountain in Galilee, Jesus called the disciples together and commissioned them to preach to all nations; to disciple others, baptise them, and teach them. Just like the organisers of that convention, many believers only talk about the \'how-to\' of the Great Commission. Only few are actually preaching it. One responsibility that accrues to us immediately we become Jesus\' disciples is to disciple others. We become Christ\'s disciples to disciple others who will in turn disciple many others.If you have caught the fire of the Gospel, then, necessity is laid you to pass it on to others because any fire that does not spread will eventually go out. A ndrew Murray said, “God\'s work must be done in God\'s way, and in God\'s power. It is spiritual work, to be done by spiritual men, in the power of the Spirit. The clearer our insight into, and the more complete our submission to, God\'s laws of work, the surer and the richer will be our joy and our reward in it.”

Ecclesiastes 3 is a popular passage often referred to when talking about time. There, King Solomon was inspired to underscore the reality of changes in time and season, and that no time lasts forever. Today\'s passage describes the nature of the work God has given humans, and the certainty of giving account to Him as well as receiving reward for our work. There is a time to work and there is a time to give account of our work, and to receive rewards.

What is the purpose of work? We work to make things better. We work to keep our world moving, and to provide a better place for one another. But ultimately, we work to please the One to whom we will finally give account. Satisfaction comes when we see work as God-given and a calling. Whatever work you do, know that God expects you to be faithful in it as one who would give account to Him, not even your boss. True joy comes from knowing the Lord Jesus and doing our work in the power of the Holy Spirit. The work God has given you is time-bound and you will be called to give account of it. What will you have to say to Him? The way you are doing His work in your charge, do you think He will be pleased when He calls you to account? Think about this.

message:

BH403: All Things Are Thine

RBT: 2 Corinthians 4-5

GIVE ALMS QUIETLY

Text: Matthew 6:1-4

Golden Text: Be careful not to practise your righteousness in front of others to be seen by them. If you do, you will have no reward from your father in heaven. Matthew 6:1, NIV

\'Anonymous\' is the word we use when we want privacy. But not many people like to be treated as anonymous especially when they do something good. We often like to be acknowledged and appreciated for things we do for others. To be anonymous means to not take credit for something for which we are \'credit-worthy\'.

Jesus says we should learn to be anonymous in giving to the needy. In His days, there were three main displays of piety. They are alms giving, prayer and fasting. These three things people do to show their righteousness. Jesus was not condemning these acts but He stated that these good things can be done for the wrong reasons. He regarded as hypocrites those who practise these acts for a show. Because their motive is to be seen and praised of people, Jesus said they have already received their reward: which is the praise of people.

Giving is an act of worship to God and we should make efforts not to call attention to ourselves when we give to the needy. Instead of taking the glory for what God has empowered us to do; we should let the glory go to God. It may not be possible to keep our giving hidden all the time but the motive for which we do it matters to God. Instead of doing our acts of righteousness to attract the praise of people, let us do them for the reward God gives which cannot be compared with anything.

Wisdom : Be careful how you give , because it determines who will reward you; God or people.

Food for Thought : Do I give to call attention to myself?

Follow-up Action : Look out for opportunities to give to the needy quietly from today.

Prayer : Lord, help me to be sensitive to those that are poor around me and to give humbly in Jesus\' name. Amen.

title: gather together your bountiful gifts
message:
MAY 2 Wednesday

BH432: Bringing in the Sheaves

RBT: Exodus 17-20

GATHER TOGETHER YOUR BOUNTIFUL GIFTS

Text: 2 Corinthians 9:1-5

Golden Text: So I thought it necessary to urge the brothers to visit you in advance and finish the arrangements for the generous gift you have promised.2 Corinthians 9:5,NIV

There are two seas in Palestine. One is fresh, with fishes in it; trees spread their branches over it and stretch out their thirsty roots to sip of its healing water. The other has no splash of fish or fluttering leaf. What makes this difference in these two seas? The first one is the Sea of Galilee, which gives and lives. The other sea gives nothing, and it is named the Dead Sea. Apostle Paul was writing to the church in Corinth on the ministry to the saints - believers in the church - which is to gather bountiful gifts and send to them. The Corinthian Church was eager, enthusiastic and willing to give without grudge. They gave to the church in Jerusalem (in our context, the convention) and churches in Macedonia (in our context, sister churches).
Living is giving and giving is living; only those who give their utmost can truly live a worthwhile life. We as believers and local churches are called into the ministry to the saints through gathering together bountiful gifts (cash and kind). The Lord is urging us to do this because it is necessary we give ahead and on time. What gifts will you plan to gather together this week or month for the saints or a local church?

Wisdom : “Live simply so that others may simply live” – St. Elizabeth Seton

Food for Thought : Giving to fellow believers is a ministry we must not neglect.

Follow-up Action : Think about a church in the rural or urban area that you will periodically send gifts to.

title: all tithes are holy
message:
MAY 3 Thursday

BH404: Trust, Try and Prove Me

RBT: 2 Samuel 5-9

ALL TITHES ARE HOLY

Text: Leviticus 27:30-33

Golden Text: A tithe of everything from the land whether grain from the soil or fruit from the trees belongs to the LORD; it is Holy to the LORD. Leviticus 27:30, NIV

An elderly woman confessed that she had not been tithing because she was on a fixed income. But she decided that she was going to start tithing faithfully because she realised this showed her love for God through obedience. Later, she got a letter from a community group that she had been chosen to receive a N150,000 grant to help pay her bills. While she did not tithe because she was expecting a pay back, God blessed her obedience. The Lord instructed the people to give a tithe of everything from the land, which also applies to us as God\'s people today.

It is time to be committed to tithing. You and all you have belong to God. A tithe is one-tenth of what the Lord has blessed you with and is holy to the Lord (the other nine tenth is for you to spend).We are to give the tithe of everything God gives us. One of the tests that prove you are holy is that you please God in your giving. Giving your tithe is a way of appreciating the Lord for giving you the land (ministry, job, business) to produce what you have. When you give your tithe, God throws open the floodgates of heaven and pours out so much blessing that you will not have room enough for it, and He stops the devourer on your behalf.

Wisdom : The tithe you don\'t pay to God directly, you indirectly pay somewhere where there is no reward.

Food for Thought : We give our tithe joyfully because we belong to the Lord

Follow-up Action : I will always deduct my tithe before any other expenses

Prayer : Lord as I give my tithe, I receive every blessing that goes with it.

title: blessings of the righteous
message:
MAY 4 Friday

BH 318: Count Your Blessings

RBT: Psalms 51-53

BLESSINGS OF THE RIGHTEOUS

Text: Psalm 112

Golden Text: Blessed are those who fear the LORD, who find great delight in His commands. Psalm 112:1, NIV

The tomb of Sir John Lawrence, who died in 1879, stood in Westminster Abbey in London. John Lawrence served the British Empire with honour and distinction, even in the face of opposition and danger. On his tombstone are these words: “He feared man so little, because he feared God so much.” The psalmist calls those who fear God and find great delight in His commands blessed. The blessing does not end with them but it extends to their children and generations after them. Some people shy away from serving God and giving Him their lives completely because they feel that there is nothing in it for them. But the psalmist says those who fear God and walk in His ways have a lot going for them. They will have mighty descendants and wealth; they will live in the light, be honest in business, and be secure when evil news comes or enemies attack. They will care for the poor, and their righteousness will endure forever.

The fear of God is no longer popular in the modern world. For the crave of the things of this world, many have pushed righteousness aside. You have a lot to gain when you fear God and keep His commands. Parents should live in the fear of God and guide their children to do same. Every family should intentionally build the fear of God into the norms and values that identify members of the family. The greatest inheritance we can bequeath to our children is to live and teach them righteousness and the fear of God.

Wisdom : The fear of the Lord is the foundation for right living.

Food for Thought : The blessings of the righteous is beyond their lifetime.

Follow-up Action : Live and walk daily in righteousness.

Prayer : Lord, help me to discover any unrighteousness in my life today and give me grace to make amends.

title: gifts for the tabernacle

BH51: O My Soul, Bless God the Father

RBT: Job 35-36

GIFTS FOR THE TABERNACLE

Text: Exodus 35:10-19

Golden Text: All who are skilled among you are to come and make everything the LORD has commanded. Exodus 35:10, NIV

A sobbing little girl who could not enter the church because it \'was too crowded\', was taken in by the pastor who saw her. Two years later, this girl lay dead in her bed. But she sent the money she had saved with a note which read, “This is to help build the little church bigger so more children can go to Sunday School.” The pastor shared what this girl had done and many more contributed for the building of a big auditorium that could take many children for worship. The tabernacle, which was the place of worship for the Israelites while in the wilderness required gifts for its completion. For all the gifts donated by the congregation, skilled people are to come and make all that the Lord has commanded.

The tabernacle is the tent which served as a place of worship, referred to today as the church building. Moses had enough material gifts to do God\'s work, but God also gave him the gift of men, gifted artisans who were willing to make use of the gifts given by the congregation to achieve the desired result. Good stewardship of donations for God\'s work is critical to the success of the work as it also encourages people to give more. Beyond your material gifts, you are also a gift. Give yourself to your local church in building its ministries.

Wisdom : Everyone is skilled and gifted by God.

Food for Thought : The local church and homes are full of skilled people who are not making use of their gifts.

title: give cheerfully and generously
message:
MAY 6 Sunday

BH353: Give of Your Best to the Master

RBT: Jeremiah 27-31

GIVE CHEERFULLY AND GENEROUSLY

Exodus 35:20-29, 2 Corinthians 9:6-8

Golden Text: Each of you should give what you have decided in your heart, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver. 2 Corinthians 9:7, NIV

A man earned a profit of N100,000 and cheerfully gave N10,000 as his tithe. God blessed him and his business began to improve. After a few years, this man was making N10 million, and he decided to go see his pastor because he found it difficult to give 1 million naira as his tithe. The pastor replied, “Should we pray that God reduce your profit? That way you won\'t feel so bad in giving so much.” Moses gathered the Israelites to contribute for the work of the tent of meeting. The purpose of their giving was clear and defined, not for selfish reasons. They all departed from the presence of Moses and immediately went into action. In the New Testament, we see a replica of this heart of giving as Paul exhorted the Corinthian church to give as they have purposed, not grudgingly or out of compulsion, but cheerfully.

From out texts, everyone made a contribution toward the work in proportion to how God has blessed them. They gave cheerfully and generously because their hearts were stirred up and their spirits moved. A cheerful and generous giving starts from a stirred heart and a moved spirit. When your heart is stirred up it leads to an increasing and sacrificial giving. Our giving must be done cheerfully, not grudgingly. Only cheerful givers are rewarded with grace to abound in every good work.

Wisdom : When you give, do it cheerfully and generously.

Food for Thought : Do you always give from a cheerful heart?

Follow-up Action : Deliberately increase your giving from time to time.

title: honour god with your first fruits
message:
MAY 7 Monday

BH437: Our Best

RBT: Mark 15-16

HONOUR GOD WITH YOUR FIRST FRUITS

Text: Proverbs 3:1-10

Golden Text: Honour the LORD with your wealth, with the first fruits of all your crops. Proverbs 3:9, NIV

We all want to be blessed and we pray for financial blessings. We make effort, working and doing things that we feel can bring more money. But it is one thing to make effort, and it is another to know the secret to blessings. Today\'s passage points us to one potent secret to financial prosperity – that is giving of first fruits. The Scripture says, “Honour the Lord with your wealth, with the firstfruits of all your crops; then your barns will be filled to overflowing, and your vats will brim over with new wine (vv. 9-10).

Giving is one topic we often avoid teaching because we feel it is not attractive to people. We seldom talk about money in the church because we do not want people to get turned off. But the truth is that our worship is not complete if we remove giving, not just giving anyhow but quality giving. Offering our first fruits is a demonstration that God owns the first place in our lives, and that nothing is too big to give to Him. God has exclusive ownership of everything on this earth, wealth inclusive (Psalm 24:1; 50:10). We are only managers of His resources. There is nothing that we have that has not been given to us. Giving to God should not be seen as a bribe so we can receive back. Rather it should be treated as an act of worship that comes from a joyful and grateful heart. Because God deserves to have the supreme place in our lives, we should give Him the first of all including our money.

Wisdom : Let God be first in all things.

Food for Thought : First fruit is all about giving honour to God.

Follow-up Action : Teach every member of the family to practise it.

Prayer : Lord, help me to honour you with my first fruits.

title: martyrs, first fruits for god
message:
MAY 8 Tuesday

BH269 : Blessed Assurance, Jesus Is Mine

RBT: 2 Corinthians 6-8

MARTYRS, FIRST FRUITS FOR GOD

Text: Revelation 14:1-5

Golden Text: These are those who did not defile themselves with women, for they remained virgins... They were purchased from among mankind and offered as first fruits to God and the Lamb.Revelation14:4-5, NIV

In an interview with Christianity Today, Carl Moeller, president of Open Doors USA, an organisation founded by Brother Andrew, shared: “I just became aware of a story of a family in Indonesia whose daughter was one of three girls who were attacked by Muslim extremists in 2004. The effort of the mothers on behalf of the cause of Christ to forgive those who had done the most horrible things to their families and their daughters is a testimony of the way the Christians are called to respond… When people die in the name of Jesus Christ, it presents a strong testimony to the culture… The church is correspondingly growing.”

Those who died because of their faith in Christ did not die in vain. They would be duly honoured and comforted by God. From our text, we can see that those who died for the faith would not be ashamed, for on their foreheads is the Father\'s name written and they are purchased as the first fruits to the Lord. The most tragic thing to happen to a person is not death. The worst tragedy that can befall anyone is to live without Christ – without hope of eternal life. Why do many Christians compromise or hide their faith - perhaps for the fear of death? If our faith is worth living for; then it is worth dying for. Because some people laid down their lives for the Christian faith, we are beneficiaries of it today. What are you willing to leave for generations coming after you? God said of the martyrs that they are the first fruits of the faith. What will God credit to your account as a sacrifice for the faith that you have received?

Wisdom : To live is Christ and to die is gain.

Food for Thought : Are you standing for the faith and ready to die for it?

Follow-up Action : Daily pledge your allegiance to the Lamb.

title: gifts, a pleasing sacrifice to god
message:
MAY 9 Wednesday

BH399: I Gave My Life for Thee

RBT: Exodus 21-24

GIFTS, A PLEASING SACRIFICE TO GOD

Text: Philippians 4:15-20

Golden Text: And my God will meet all your needs according to the riches of His glory in Christ Jesus.Philippians 4:19, NIV

We all love to pray Philippians 4:19, “My God shall supply all your needs according to His glorious riches in Christ Jesus.” As much as we love this prayer, we also need to consider the circumstance within which the prayer was said. The Philippian Church was a model of outstanding giving to the work of ministry. While Paul was in Thessalonica, they sent gifts, not once, but many times to meet his needs. When the need of a man of God is met, the work of God would continue without hindrance. Paul said that their gift was not only a gift to him but something that was credited to their account. He called their gift “an odour of a sweet smell, a sacrifice acceptable, well pleasing to God.” So when Paul prayed that God shall supply all their needs according to His riches in glory in Christ, we can better identify with the import of that prayer.

For our giving to be a “fragrant offering, an acceptable sacrifice pleasing to God”, we must be committed to giving, to meet specific needs of the gospel. Whatever we give to the work of the Lord is credited to our account and translates to a pleasing sacrifice before the Lord. When God is pleased with our offering, then we will not lack His supply. What are you willing to give for the furtherance of the gospel in your church and around you? Decide to always give a gift that is pleasing to the Lord?

Wisdom : When we give, God supplies our needs.

Food for Thought : Is my giving pleasing to the Lord?

Follow-up Action : Surprise someone with a pleasant gift this week.

title: preparing grain offering
message:
MAY 10 Thursday

BH437: Our Best

RBT: 2 Samuel 10-14

PREPARING GRAIN OFFERING

Text: Leviticus 2:1-10, 14

Golden Text: When anyone brings a grain offering to the Lord, their offering is to be of the finest flour. They are to pour olive oil on it, put incense on it. Leviticus 2:1, NIV

The grain offering signifies one\'s appreciation of what the Lord has blessed one with. The appreciation is demonstrated by presenting it before the Lord as an offering or first fruit. The unique thing and principle we are to learn from the grain offering is: First, the Lord would not ask you to give whatever He has not blessed you with. While the Israelites were in the wilderness, the Lord supplied the grain they needed for offering. Second, we observe the various ways it can be presented. The grain offering could be presented at the altar in one of five forms: fine flour, oven-baked cakes, cakes baked in a pan, cakes baked in a frying pan or crushed roasted heads of new grain. In our context, grain offering is the work of our hand. Anything offered should be holy to the Lord.

The details of the preparation and presentation of the grain offering shows that God is interested in order and He wants things to be done carefully, not shoddily. Even in giving, God does not appreciate that things are casually done. Giving for us should not be a casual routine but an activity that is well prepared for. As you appreciate the Lord for what He has blessed you with, give Him your best, prepare ahead, make it presentable and acceptable before Him. There is nothing we have that we have not been given. And giving is best when prepared for.

Wisdom : God wants prepared offering

Food for Thought : Do I prepare or casually give my offerings?

Follow-up Action : Always prepare and plan to improve in your giving

title: acceptable offerings are without blemish
message:
MAY 11 Friday

BH352: Living for Jesus

RBT: Psalms 54-56

ACCEPTABLE OFFERINGS ARE WITHOUT BLEMISH

Text : Leviticus 22:17-20

Golden Text: Do not bring anything with a defect, because it will not be accepted on your behalf. Leviticus 22: 20, NIV

My cousin was to host a couple of colleagues from her office to dinner the other day and she invited me to help her. I know she loves cooking but I have never seen her make so much efforts to host people, not even our own family members. The food was a delicacy with all kinds of garnishing, the drinks were assorted, and the dishes and plates sparkling. When we finished setting up the table, I could not but marvel at how we made it happen. I had to ask her why she had to stretch herself so much. She said to me “They are a special people. I can\'t treat them less.” If we could treat people specially, God must be treated more specially.

The Lord instructed Moses to tell Aaron that whatever offering the Israelites would bring before Him – whether cattle, sheep or goats - must be without defect for it to be acceptable. The animal to be offered must not be blind, crippled, injured; it must not have oozing sore, scraps, or damaged testicles.

God is special and the offering we offer to Him must not be less than special. We must avoid giving God the leftovers of money and other things he has blessed us with. Today, how do we make our offering acceptable to God? We must give the best of offering that is well planned and well packaged. Whatever is not acceptable to humans should not be brought as offering to God. When we give God the best, we can expect the best from Him.

Wisdom : Give God the best offering.

Food for Thought : What kind of offering do I give to the Lord?

Follow-up Action : I will examine the state of my offering before I give it to the Lord.

Prayer : Lord, I repent of every leftover giving.

title: observing the sabbath and the festivals
message:

BH490: Come, Ye Thankful People, Come

RBT: Job 37-38

OBSERVING THE SABBATH AND THE FESTIVALS

Text: Leviticus 23:1-8

Golden Text: Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “These are my appointed festivals, the appointed festivals of the LORD, which you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies.”Leviticus 23:2, NIV

A group of alumni visited their old university professor and they were complaining about stress of work and life. He offered them coffee and noticed that all expensive cups were taken up, leaving the plain ones. He said “Life is the coffee; the jobs, money and position are the cups.Concentrating only on the cup, we fail to enjoy the coffee God has provided us.” God brews the coffee, not the cup. Enjoy your coffee!

The Lord commanded the Israelites to observe these appointed times; Sabbath and Passover. Observing the Sabbath and the Passover is an act of worship and reverence to the Lord.The Sabbath as a day set apart to observe rest reminds us that the Lord rested on the seventh day. The Passover, which signifies our salvation, is a reminder of the day the Lord delivered the Israelites from Egypt.

As Christians, we are to celebrate appointed days by deliberately fixing the time and our thought on the faithfulness of God, and to thank Him for all the victories we enjoy. The weekly Sunday worship should be more than mere service or a time of socialising. It should be a special moment of great encounter with the Lord. Easter, Christmas and other festivities should be set apart to recollect God\'s deeds and renew our relationship with Him.

Wisdom : God should be the focus of every celebration.

Food for Thought : Resting is a form of worship when God and self-examination is the focus.

Follow-up Action : Fix a time to rest and share memorable meals with the family.

In African traditional religions, there is a kind of first fruit concept where adherents would not eat yam until after the new yam festival when it had first been offered to a deity. Give God the first of your communion each day. Say \'thank you\' to Him first thing in the morning. Give Him first place in your life, family and career. Let Him have the best of all that He has given you. What fruits are you bearing as a result of the help of the Lord - whether, weekly, daily, monthly or yearly? Let God \'taste first\' of that fruit before yourself or others. Remember you are only giving Him the first of the many fruits; the other fruits belong to you. When you give Him the first fruits, God takes the first place in your life and all endeavours. You can be sure God will place you first.

When writer Bruce Feiler was diagnosed with bone cancer in his thigh, he could not walk without some help for over a year. Learning to walk on crutches caused him to appreciate a slower pace of life. Feiler said, “The idea of slowing down became the number one lesson I learned from my experience.” The Lord instructed the Israelites to slow down their pace as they observe the Sabbath and take some rest. God\'s instructions are simple not complicated, though sometimes we try to reason them out instead of obeying them. The instruction to observe the Sabbath also came with the blessing of good crop yield. In a world of rat race where we have to keep running to keep up with the many demands of life, God is calling us to slow down. Modern people no longer value rest as much as they value work. Just as we love to work, so we are to cherish taking rest. As obedience to the Sabbath brought good yield, so shall observing rest renew our strength. We face the danger of burnout when we only stick to schedules of work and fail to make out time for rest. We make work an idol when we refuse to observe God\'s commandment of rest. The spirit of workaholism which gives attention to nothing else apart from work is against God\'s planned rest for our body. Work becomes worthless when the body dies due to burnout.

Wisdom : By strength shall no man prevail.

BEAR EACH OTHER'S BURDENS

Text: Galatians 6:1-5

Golden Text: Carry each other\'s burdens, and in this way you will fulfil the law of Christ. Galatians 6:2, NIV

\'Ubuntu\', a Malawian word which translates “I am because we are” is an African philosophy. The idea of Ubuntu is that, “we are all connected; we cannot be ourselves without community; health and faith are always lived out among others; an individual\'s well being is caught up in the well being of others.”Apostle Paul recognised the importance of others in the spiritual journey of every believer and encouraged the believers to "carry each other\'s burdens" (v. 2).
According to him, it is probable that a believer mistakenly falls into sin. He, thus, advises that other believers should not neglect the fellow but should rise towards restoring him/her. They should stand by the erred believer and, in the spirit of humility, assist to restore him/her to the faith. However, they should also be vigilant so that they do not fall into the same error (v.1).

People respond differently to mistakes made by others. While some derive pleasure in the fall of other people; others make mockery of those who fell into a sin. Apostle Paul admonishes us against making jest of our fellow believers who fall into one sin or another. Rather than mocking them, believers are challenged to provide the enabling ground for correction that will restore the person to faith again. It is, thus, our duty to bear the burdens of those that mistakenly fall from grace and help them to get back to faith. We are, nevertheless, cautioned to be watchful lest we also fall into the same error.

Wisdom : A believer has the grace not to fall into sin.

A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) is signed when two parties enter into an agreement. MoU states what terms of reference each party is expected to fulfil. God emphatically stated that He would keep His covenant with His people. However, this is based on the condition that they obey God\'s commands (vv. 1-3).

Our God is a covenant-keeping God. Whatever He promises to do, He will not relent in doing it. But the condition for enjoying the blessings of His promises is our obedience. Because God is just, He will not suspend this condition for anyone, irrespective of their status. We position ourselves to enjoy the fulfilment of God\'s covenant when we obey His commands at all times.

In contemporary times, there is a lot of exploitation in the market place. People make things appear to be what they are not and sellers hike prices to maximise profit at the expense of the buyer. SABBATICAL YEAR AND YEAR OF JUBILEE

It is commonly held that "rest is sweet after labour." However, because of various reasons including struggle for material possessions, rest is becoming scarce among humans. God knew the Israelites might not want to rest; hence He instituted Sabbath. He instructed them to allow their land a full-year\'s rest after they might have cultivated the land for six years. The essence of this instruction was to make the people and the land rest, be renewed in strength; and their land would regain its nutrients. The people were to also observe Jubilee, which is the 50th year. This year was to be celebrated as a year of freedom and restoration. People would be released from all their oppressions or bondages and be restored to their people and their land.

As much as people need rest, many things in contemporary times deny many people true rest. Rest allows for renewal and cannot be ignored because nature cannot be cheated. When we fail to rest as instructed by God, we are not only violating the rule of God, we are also doing ourselves harm. Take rest seriously as God does. As believers in Christ, we have the responsibility to proclaim freedom among sinners through Jesus Christ. It is a duty we must not shy away from.

title: the atoning sacrifice for the people
message:
MAY 21 Monday

BH192: Are You Washed in the Blood?

RBT: Luke 3-4

THE ATONING SACRIFICE FOR THE PEOPLE

Text: Leviticus 16:15-19

Golden Text: He shall then slaughter the goat for the sin offering for the people and take its blood behind the curtain and do with it as he did with the bull\'s blood: He shall sprinkle it on the atonement cover and in front of it. Leviticus 16:15, NIV

God instituted several sacrifices among the Israelites, one of which was the sacrifice of atonement. The atoning sacrifice was constituted for the remission of the sins of the people. God instructed the Israelites through Moses on the mode of the sacrifice. The high priest, who ought to have presented the sacrifice for his sin before this general sacrifice (vv. 11-14), was to slaughter a goat and sprinkle its blood on the atonement seat and the front of the Tabernacle. This sprinkling of the blood, thus, served two purposes. First, it cleanses the Holy Place which had been contaminated by the sin of the people. Second, it remits the sin of the people and makes them fit to appear before God again. This sacrifice was to be repeated as often as possible to atone for the sins of the people any time they sinned against God.

In Jesus Christ, we now have the fullness of the sacrifice for our sins. He is both the High Priest and the object of the sacrifice that brings about the once-and-for-all atonement for our sin. His sacrifice is more efficacious than the animal sacrifice instituted in the Old Testament. The old order was defective and imperfect hence the institution of the new order through the precious blood of Jesus Christ. No other sacrifice can be as perfect as that which Christ Himself offered on the cross (Hebrews 9:11-14). Avail yourself of the atonement that His blood offers and free yourself from the guilt of sin.

Wisdom : Every sacrifice other than Christ\'s atoning sacrifice is null and void.

Food for Thought : Are you embracing the atoning sacrifice of Christ for your salvation?

Follow-up Action : Embrace the efficacious sacrifice of Christ today for the atonement of your sins.

title: jesus brings salvation through suffering

JESUS BRINGS SALVATION THROUGH SUFFERING

Text: Hebrews 2:10-13

Golden Text: “In bringing many sons to glory, it was fitting that God, for whom and through whom everything exists, should make the author of their salvation perfect through suffering” Hebrews 2:10

A good friend of mine enjoys pottery. The process of transforming wet, pliable, dull gray clay into beautiful bowls, vases, mugs and plates is fascinating. He begins with a shapeless blob, which he places on his potter\'s wheel. As he spins the wheel, he gently caresses the clay, applying pressure with his fingers and palms. Beneath his skillful touch, the turning clay responds to the varying degrees of pressure until it begins to take the shape he has in mind. But the colours are dull and lifeless until he places the vessels into a kiln, where he bakes the clay for hours in extreme heat. The purpose of the heat is to transform the weak clay into a useful vessel and the dull, ugly colours into radiant beauty.

In the same manner, we all go through some times of “heat” - pain and suffering. The problem of pain and questions about suffering are as old as the human race. Is it God\'s will for his children to suffer and what causes suffering? Sometimes the cause of our suffering may be evident; other times we may never find out the reason for our suffering like Job. But we can know one thing for sure: Jesus cares about our suffering. This is because He also tasted pain in the course of the redemptive work, although not because of any sin He committed. When was the last time you wept on your pillow at night, thinking no one cared? Is the pain so deep and your hurt so great that you cry night after night? In all your afflictions, Jesus Himself is afflicted. Be comforted with these words.

Wisdom : Every time you go through hardship, you develop strength and maturity.

title: jesus destroys the devil's power
message:

BH 409: The Kingdom Is Coming

RBT: Psalms 60-62

JESUS DESTROYS THE DEVIL'S POWER

Text: Hebrews 2:14-16

Golden Text: “Since the children have flesh and blood, he too shared in their humanity so that by his death he might destroy him who holds the power of death – that is the devil” Hebrews 2:14

Appointments are part and parcel of our lives! We all face appointment every day. For some, it may be a schedule for travel appointment, preaching appointment, counselling appointment, eating appointment, or even a hospital appointment. There are however, two inescapable appointments in the life of every one of us. One is the hour of our birth, and the other is the hour of our death. Birth ushers us into time, while death ushers us into eternity. God oversees the one and overrules the other. While many people expect and rejoice at the delivery of a new born baby, not many of us want to listen to any news about death. Death is scary and to some it\'s tormenting knowing that death is inevitable. The Bible calls death “the king of terrors” (Job 18:14), and the psalmist speaks of “the terrors of death” (Ps. 55:4). Verse 15 of our passage expresses the same thought when he describes those “who through fear of death are all their lifetime subject to bondage.”

However, the Good News is that Jesus, through his death on the cross, won the victory once and for all over death and hell. That is why he came in the likeness of man to share our humanity. Like David, who destroyed Goliath with the giant\'s own sword, so Jesus defeated death with death itself. In the language of Isaiah,“He will swallow up death forever” (Isaiah 25:8). Because of this mighty work of Jesus Christ our Lord, all believers have been saved from spiritual death, and no believer need fear physical death. David knew this experience when he sang: “Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil; for you are with me; your rod and your staff, they comfort me”(Psalm 23:4). You too can walk through life with this assurance of victory Christ has provided for you.

JESUS, THE PEOPLE'S HIGH PRIEST FOREVER

Text: Hebrews 7:18-28

Golden Text: “Therefore He is able to save completely those who come to God through Him, because He always lives to intercede for them.” Hebrews 7: 25

Imagine you have a ten-year old car, with about 150,000 miles on it and you plan to keep it till it runs at least 300,000 miles. You feel it is still in good shape and serving you well. But at a point you discover it is giving you problem and it is no longer meeting your demand.Do you still keep it while you have an option and means to get a new and durable one? Most times we discard a product when it is no longer relevant and has served its purpose to create room for a new and better one. This is the point the writer of Hebrews was making in our passage of today:“The former regulation is set aside because it was weak and useless” (Heb. 7:18). High priests in the Old Testament (OT) stand between God and man to make atonement for sins. But this was just a shadow of the reality to come. The priests of the OT were themselves vulnerable and mortal (Heb. 7:23). They also needed to atone for their own sins. With all the regulations and laws in the OT with all its code of conduct, its priesthood, its sacrifices, and its worship, it was not sufficient to make people better, or bring them closer to God. But God provided us a High Priest in Jesus who could guarantee us salvation; for He made an oath that “you are a Priest forever.” Only in someone who lives forever could this promise be realised. And only God the Son, Jesus, who lives on, could have a permanent priesthood. What is the implication of this continuous priesthood of Jesus to us? It means Jesus is forever by the side of the Father to make intercession for us before God until we experience our final redemption from this corrupt body. Indeed he is able to save us completely!

Wisdom : Jesus living presence certifies that all we need to guarantee our salvation will be provided by Him.

Follow-up Action : Since Jesus lives forever, think of how you will make everything harmonise with Him such that your life will embrace a fresh, holy, and new status.

JESUS, OUR REDEEMER AND DELIVERER

Psalm 34:1-10; Hebrews 2:17-18

There is this lovely story about Martin Luther and his encounter with the devil. The devil came to him and asked him to open the door of his heart so that he could come in and discuss some very important matters with him. Luther told the devil, “I don\'t have the keys to the door; God has them. Ask Him if you wish.” On hearing this, the devil had no option but to take to his heels. This illustrates the constant battle we face with the devil and the nature of our victory over him. He is our arch enemy and his intention remains “to steal, and kill and destroy” (John 10:10). The devil brings diverse temptations our ways so that we can through them fall into sin and lose favour with God thereby breaking our edge of protection. But for this reason Jesus had to be made like us, fully human in every way, in order that He might become a merciful and faithful high priest so that He is able to help those who are tempted (Heb. 2:17-18)

Our victory over the devil is secured eternally through Jesus; He is our redeemer and deliverer. God dispatches His angels on our behalf to watch over us perpetually (v. 7). His redemption package also includes our daily provisions (v. 10). It is a covenant relationship. However, we have our own part to play in activating this covenant. First, we have to seek the Lord with a single heart and wholehearted devotion (vv. 4-5). Second, we must not seek help elsewhere; God alone must be our place of refuge (v. 8). Third, the fear of the Lord must be resident in our heart (v. 9). Believers must remember that because we are born of God, our victory is sure through faith in Him (1 John 5:4). We must keep this truth in view all the time.

DAVID EATS THE BREAD OF PRESENCE

Text: 1 Samuel 21:1-6

Golden Text: “But the priest answered David, \'I don\'t have any ordinary bread on hand; however, there is some consecrated bread here – provided the men have kept themselves from women\'” 1 Samuel 21:4

Have you ever shown your old student ID for a discount, even though you are no longer a student? Have you ever been undercharged for something and failed to notify the appropriate person? Most of us have dabbled at one time or another into the undeniable gray. Such was the situation David found himself when he went to Ahimelech the priest at Nob. David lied to Ahimelech, telling him that he was on a mission for Saul. The lie seemed innocent enough, as David was desperate for food and a weapon.

Ahimelech, however, gave David some of the consecrated bread that was to be eaten only by the priests. He also allowed David\'s men to eat the same bread on the condition that they have kept their vessels (bodies) holy. It is instructive to note that Jesus later, in Matthew 12:3-4 commended Ahimelech\'s act, who realized that the moral obligation to help a person in need was more important than ritual regulations. We should not be too much legalistic in our dealings with other fellow believers, especially when it is urgent to provide needed help. Mercy is to be preferred to sacrifice, and ritual observance must give way to moral duties. Some churches would not welcome others into their church to worship simply because they do not cover their heads. Some other churches would turn any woman with earrings back from entering the church premises even if that is her first time of coming to the church. Today\'s lesson tells us to be careful how we impose our legalistic rules over and above the law of God.

Wisdom : God is interested in faith expressed in love.

LORD DESIRES MERCY NOT SACRIFICE

Text: Hosea 6: 1-6

Golden Text: “For I desire mercy, not sacrifice, and acknowledgment of God rather than burnt offering” Hosea 6:6

Two little boys, Johnson and Jude, were playing together one afternoon. They had played long when Johnson took advantage of his weaker playmate, Jude. Jude, too proud to complain, withdrew some distance and sat by himself, manfully winking back the ready tears. After a short time, Johnson grew tired of his solitary play and called, “Eh, Jude, come back. I\'m sorry.” Jude, recalling his previous experience, did not respond to the invitation at once. “Yes,” he replied cautiously, “but what kind of sorry? The kind so you won\'t do it again?” This story describes the lifestyle of the Israelites as chronicled by Hosea in our passage of today. Their repentance was not genuine; it was not backed up with godly sorrow hence God asked: “What can I do with you, Ephraim? What can I do with you, Judah? Your love is like the morning mist, like the early dew that disappears” (Hosea 6:4).

Sin serves as barrier between us and God. But God is always merciful and ready to forgive when we are willing to repent genuinely (Isaiah 1:18-19; I Jn. 1:9). Genuine repentance entails a complete turnaround with a determination not to return to the past behaviours. God wants us to present our bodies unto Him as living sacrifice before our substances. There are many unrepentant sinners in our churches today who only bring their tithe and offering while they keep perpetuating their wicked acts. The Macedonian Christians modelled this principle: “They gave themselves first of all to the Lord, and then by the will of God also to us” (2 Cor. 8:5). Let us therefore press on to acknowledge the Lord so that He may come down like winter rain, and like spring rains that water the earth.

Golden Text: “Do not go over your vineyard a second time or pluck up the grapes that have fallen. Leave them for the poor and foreigner. I am the Lord your God” Leviticus 19:10

In a lepers\' colony, clothes arrived for distribution among the lepers . One little leper boy was asked what he needed most. He replied, “My hands are still good so I can mend my clothes when necessary, but there are some lepers who have no fingers, and some whose hands are so crippled or sore that they cannot use them. When their clothes get holes in them, they cannot mend them on their own. They are needier than I.” How we need such unselfishness. Today\'s passage points us to the reality that there are others who are needier than we are. God is concerned about the poor and needy and so must we. That is why He made provision for how they should be treated in the law He handed over to Moses. The law specifies that in reaping, they should not reap the field to the extreme edge of the field nor gather together the ears left upon the field in the reaping. This is to allow the poor to partake in the harvest. Ruth enjoyed this kindness from Boaz and from this she was able to take care of her mother-in-law (Ruth 2:17-19).

The church and individual Christians should activate this principle in dealing with one another. The early church upheld this principle such that from time to time those who owned land or houses sold them, brought the money from the sales and put it at the apostles feet and it was distributed to anyone who had need (Acts 4:34). This should be the pattern in contemporary churches.

Wisdom : He who gives to the poor lends to the Lord.

THE SABBATH IS FOR MERCIFUL ACTS

Text: Luke 14:1-6

Golden Text: “Jesus asked the Pharisees and experts in the law, \'is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath or not?” Luke 14:6

A woman visited the city of Jos during extreme cold period, and saw on the sidewalk a ragged cold, and hungry little girl, gazing wistfully at some of the cakes in a shop through the window. She stopped, and, taking the little one by the hand, led her into the store. Though she was aware that bread might be better for the cold child than cake, yet, desiring to gratify the shivering and abandoned one, she bought and gave her the cake she wanted. She then took her to another place, where she purchased for the girl a shawl and other items of comfort. The grateful little girl looked at the woman right in the eyes, and with precious simplicity said, “Are you God\'s wife?” This story summarises the lesson our passage of today wants us to learn. God poetizes the act of mercy in our religious practices.

The Pharisees believe that the Sabbath day must be kept holy and so no work should be done, even showing mercy to the afflicted. Jesus holds a contrary view. He believes the essence of Sabbath is to extend God\'s mercy to those who need it. Now, while Jesus was in the house of prominent Pharisees, there was a man suffering from abnormal swelling of his body. They knew that Jesus could not be in the presence of human suffering very long without doing something about it. Jesus healed the man and this offended the Pharisees. Remember Jesus\' parable of the Good Samaritan in Luke 10:25-36. What distinguished the Samaritan from others, including the priest, was the act of compassion he showed on the wounded (Luke 10:33). Are you so much preoccupied with religious obligations to the detriment of the obviously needy people around you?

Wisdom : Don\'t allow your religious spectacle prevent you from seeing the needy around you.

Food for Thought : What constitutes your activities on the Sabbath day?

Follow-up Action : How do you want to put this lesson to work?

Jesus Christ has left us with the work of the kingdom. He asked us to continue the work until He returns. He charged us to occupy till He comes (Luke 19:13). As you go about your business within the week, do God\'s work by your words, actions and lifestyle. Rescue those who are perishing, help the weak ones and populate the kingdom of God.

MEET HUMAN NEED ON THE SABBATH

Text: Matthew 12:1-14

Golden Text: ...It is lawful to do good on the Sabbath. Matthew 12:12,NIV

A man approached theologian John Vernon McGee to argue about the Sabbath. The man said, “Show me where the Sabbath day has been changed.” McGee answered, “I don\'t think it has been changed. Saturday is Saturday, it is the seventh day of the week, and it is the Sabbath day. The man said, "Then why don\'t you keep the Sabbath day if it hasn\'t been changed?" McGee answered, “The day hasn\'t changed, but I have been changed. I\'ve been given a new nature now, I am joined to Christ; I am a part of the new creation. We celebrate the first day because that is the day He rose from the grave.” That is what it means that the ordinances have been nailed to the cross.”

Jesus gave expression to the Sabbath day by restoring the withered hand of a man. The Pharisees had accused Jesus\' disciples for plucking the ears of corn to eat on the Sabbath. But Jesus countered them by giving the example of David who ate the shewbread at the temple which was meant for the priests. Jesus also told them that He is the Lord of the Sabbath. Jesus was not in any way abolishing the principle of rest and focused fellowship that the Sabbath stands for. But He used the opportunity to teach about doing good even on the Sabbath.

We must always be careful not to over-emphasise the law over the giver of the law. The greatest good was Jesus cooperating with the Father to take away our sins and offer us salvation instead of death. Therefore, we also must be like Him doing good at all times including the Sabbath as the situation demands. Rather than being a burden, the Sabbath should be a day of delight in which we shift our attention from many things that distract us and rest in focused fellowship with our Maker. Jesus is our example and He has shown us that beyond the legalistic adherence to Sabbath laws, which we can barely keep, we should seek opportunities to be God\'s hand in meeting needs as we observe the Sabbath.

Wisdom : Putting high premium on human life is very rewarding.

Food for Thought : Which is better: to know the law and execute it or to know the giver of the law and receive divine inspiration to interpret and obey the law?

Follow-up Action : Strive to know the giver of the law at all times and follow Him diligently.

REHEARSE THE DEEDS OF THE LORD

Golden Text: Then they would put their trust in God and would not forget his deeds but would keep his commands. Psalm 78:7, NIV

Why do we remember certain things but forget others? Scientists say the human brain is especially wired to keep track of events whether good or bad. But they also say that when we are exposed to a real or perceived threatening situation, the adrenal glands increase the production of a hormone called cortisol, which alerts the brain on the importance of the experience, thereby causing the brain to store the event in a \'high priority file.\'

The psalmist considers the history of God\'s good deeds to His people a \'high priority file\', and, therefore enjoins God\'s people not to forget the deeds but rehearse them to their children and generations after them. They are to keep the history of God\'s dealings with them and pass it on to their children. In Israel, parents were commanded to teach the deeds of the Lord so that the successive generations may remain faithful to Him. The Lord\'s saving acts and His covenant statutes must be taught, for together they remain the focal point for faith and obedience through generations.

We must be intentional about reaching the next generation for Jesus. Today\'s society is increasingly antagonistic to the Christian faith and our youths are the worse for it.
