In an age of rebellion, teach them that obedience to God is the only key to fulfilment. In a society that celebrates falsehood, teach them that righteousness exalts, sharing practical experiences of God\'s goodness to the upright.

title: god's tree of justice for all

Text: Ezekiel 17:22-24

Golden Text: All the trees of the forest will know that I the LORD bring down the tall tree and make the low tree grow tall. I dry up the green tree and make the dry tree flourish. Ezekiel 17:24, NIV

The death of King Louis XIV of France in 1715 marked the end of his 72-year reign and the longest in European history. King Louis had called himself \'the Great\' and was the monarch who made the famous statement \'I am the state!\' His court was the most magnificent in Europe, and his funeral was spectacular. As his body lay in state with special candle lit above his golden coffin to dramatise his greatness, Bishop Massilon who ministered at his funeral slowly moved towards the coffin; he snuffed out the candle and said, “Only God is Great!”

God gave Prophet Ezekiel a message of stern warning to those who exalt themselves, forming alliance against God\'s people. Using the imagery of cedar trees, God spoke about the glorious future of the nation of Israel. Most importantly, God was saying He, the sovereign God, will overrule the powerful earthly kings who tried to lord it over Israel. He would subsequently elevate a lesser king to replace the seemingly powerful one. The tall tree would be brought down; the green tree would be dried up while the low tree would be exalted. The tall tree and the green tree represent the political powers that have tried to subjugate God\'s people.

The future of Israel spoken about found fulfilment in Christ who is the Root of Jesse. In Him, those who have been oppressed will find justice. Those who have exalted themselves against God\'s standard would be relegated. The Scripture says, “God resists the proud but gives grace to the humble” (James 4:6). Are you despised or treated disdainfully for Christ\'s sake? Or you have been denied your right to promotion because your faith would not allow you to get involved in some shady deals? You are the low tree and your time of lifting has come.

Wisdom : Put your confidence only in the Sovereign Lord.

Food for Thought : In whom do you put your trust?

Follow-up Action : Discuss among your family members if your actions reflect confidence in the Lord.

RBT: Exodus 37-40

JESUS AFFIRMED AS SON OF MAN

Text: Matthew 16: 13-20

Golden Text: Simon Peter answered “you are the Messiah the Son of the living God.” Matthew 16:16, NIV

Martin Luther said, “The life of Christianity consists of possessive pronouns. It is one thing to say, “Christ is a Saviour”; it is quite another thing to say, “He is my Saviour and my Lord.” The devil can say the first; the true Christian alone can say the second.” Jesus asked His disciples the question: “Who do people say the Son of Man is?” The disciples responded by giving the public perceptions of Jesus. Some say He is John the Baptist, some say Elijah, while others say Jeremiah or one of the prophets. It was easy for the disciples to give shades of public opinion about Christ. But the personal question: \'Who do you say I am?\' became a tough one to answer. Simon Peter, in his usual manner, responded, and rightly too, that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of the living God __ meaning the anointed One.

Peter\'s knowledge of Christ brought about the knowledge of who he (Peter) is in Christ. In Christ, our lives find meaning and relevance. Knowing Him is knowing ourselves and finding purpose and fulfilment. The prophets have come and gone, but Jesus Christ is the final revelation of God to humanity for all generations. Who is Christ to you? Your understanding of who you are is determined by your understanding of Christ. If you must know yourself, a functional knowing of Christ is key.

Wisdom : Not only do we know God through Jesus Christ, we also know ourselves through Him.

Food for Thought : Who is the Messiah to you?

Follow-up Action : Make honest assessment of yourselves and make appropriate amends.

title: jesus, not believed in hometown
message:
JUNE 7 Thursday

BH257: My Faith Looks Up to Thee

RBT: 1 Kings 5-9

JESUS, NOT BELIEVED IN HOMETOWN

Text: Matthew 13:54-58

Golden Text: And He did not do many miracles there because of their lack of faith. Matthew 13:58, NIV

"Familiarity breeds contempt" says an adage. A story was told of the founder of a Nigerian church who left his hometown because his people saw him as an uneducated man. They neither respected him nor believed in his revelation. Almost everywhere Jesus went, a crowd followed Him and people were eager to listen to Him, except at Nazareth His birthplace. His people had become too familiar with His humanity that they lost sight of His divinity. They knew Him as the son of an ordinary carpenter; His siblings were well known to them in the community. Perhaps theirs was a poor family - nothing spectacular about His father\'s house. They, therefore, looked down on Jesus, and treated with disdain the wisdom and power with which He was teaching and working miracles. For their lack of faith, Jesus could not do many miracles amidst them.

Familiarity can be dangerous because it makes us lose sight of the wonder of God in those He has sent to us. When we start getting familiar with God, we stop experiencing His wonderful presence as we start losing insights for living. Faith is the key to unlock genuine miracles. How many times have we told ourselves in a worship service that “I have heard this kind of sermon before”? Sometimes, we get too familiar with the Bible thinking we can predict the message that God could possibly have for us in a passage. When we hinge our faith on what the minister should look like by our own estimate, we rob ourselves of God\'s blessings. God\'s Word and His ways are new every day, and we can position ourselves for a renewed experience with Him each time, if we stick to faith, not familiarity.

Text: Luke 18:1-8

Golden Text: When the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on the earth? Luke 18:8, NIV

Faith is the \'Yes\' of heart that makes a believer cling to God, regardless of prevailing circumstances. Jesus told the parable of the judge and the widow who was persistent in seeking justice against her adversary. The attitude of the judge did not encourage the widow to keep asking. But instead of being put off or discouraged by the judge\'s attitude, the widow was persistent. Jesus said if this unjust judge could answer the woman\'s request because of her persistence, how much more will our heavenly Father answer those who cry to Him day and night. Faith would not make us give up in praying because we believe that even when the answers seem to delay, God will still answer.

More importantly, Jesus Christ charged the Church to watch out for His second coming. As the prophetic signs of the end become more obvious around us, we need to examine our faith, whether it is still beaming hot or waxing cold. Challenges and temptations are inevitable but in the midst of life\'s pressure, we should always remind ourselves that all does not end here. There is a day that God has set apart to gather the saints into everlasting rest. When it looks like everything is getting out of control, we can hold on to our faith by earnest, serious and unceasing prayer. Prayer has power to anchor the soul on God\'s promises, even in the midst of turmoil. When Jesus Christ returns, will He find faith in you?

Golden Text: “Let both grow together until the harvest. At that time I will tell the harvesters: First collect weeds and tie them in bundles to be burned; then gather the wheat and bring it into my barn.” Matthew 13:30, NIV

Jesus told a parable of the weeds that grew with the real crops. Weeds are unwanted competitors growing where they are not planted. \'Tares\' as used in King James version refers to a specific type of weed that looks so much like the wheat itself. In the early stages of growth the tares resemble the wheat such that both are not easily distinguished. As the wheat was growing, the weed was growing also. The wisdom of the farm owner in leaving the tares until the time of harvest is such that the removal of the weed would not affect adversely the growth of the wheat. In the process of removing the weed, the wheat could also be removed.
The tares represented in this parable can be within the church of God. They are the children of the devil who are among God\'s children. They speak the language of the church; may put up a pious look. Sometimes, it may be difficult to differentiate them from God\'s children. But the judgment would eventually distinguish those who are for God and those who are for the devil – whether within or outside the Church.

Finally at the Lord\'s Second Coming, there shall be separation. God will gather home those who believed and accepted Jesus Christ as Lord and Saviour, while unbelievers will be condemned to hell without mercy. Text: Isaiah 1:12-17

Golden Text: Wash and make yourselves clean. Take your evil deeds out of my sight! Isaiah 1:17a, NIV

Isaiah chapter 1 was written at a time the Assyrians destroyed Judah by burning the city and leaving it desolate. Those in positions of authority had put up a system that put burdens on the weak. In their courts of law, poor people were denied justice. In the midst of this decadence, the people continued with their religious activities. The New Moon and Sabbath meeting continued unabated; they still came together to pray to God.

God rejected outright the offerings from the disobedient community of Israelites. They had become ceremonious in their worship. Their sacrifices and assemblies had become detestable to God. Even their lengthy prayers shall not be answered, says the Lord. The only way out is genuine repentance and new life.

The import of today\'s message is that God cannot be mocked. Regular church attendance, Bible study, daily prayer, and occasional fasting are appreciable religious activities. But they would become mere rituals, if, after doing them, we are still involved in injustice and oppression of the less privileged. Titus 1:16 says, “They claim to know God, but by their actions they deny him. They are detestable, disobedient and unfit for doing anything good.” What God desires from his children is a relationship with Him that translates to a transformed life that affects others positively. This is to seek justice, defend the weak and the oppressed, widows and orphans. You cannot have true worship without seeking justice.

Injustice is becoming a norm in the world. Those who are powerful sometimes use every means to oppress the weak and it is considered normal.Today\'s passage reiterates the fact that God is passionate about justice. Injustice in any form saddens God\'s heart. Prophet Amos delivered God\'s call for justice to the people. Their religious activities became repulsive to God because they failed to uphold justice in their community. While they observed feast days solemn assemblies; offered burnt offerings; sang worship songs to God; they neglected justice and righteousness, which are very dear to God\'s heart. The result was that God rejected their worship.

Prophet Amos observed that prosperity was limited to the wealthy who fed fat on injustice and oppression of the poor. With great passion and courage, Amos preached that God would punish the nation. He called for justice to “flow like a river” (5:24).

God abhors religiosity that is devoid of justice and righteousness. As we meet with God in fellowship each day, He expects that our encounter with Him would translate to fair relationship with fellow humans. The second coming of the Lord is imminent, but will mean disaster for sinners and joy for the righteous. Like Amos, Christian leaders must speak out against injustice and corruption that have pervaded every sector of our nation, including the Church.

title: honour your father and mother
message:

RBT: Leviticus 1-3

HONOUR YOUR FATHER AND MOTHER

Text: Exodus 20:12; Deuteronomy 5:16

Golden Text: Honour your father and your mother, so that you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you. Exodus 20:12, NIV

A sad elderly mother wrote this about her son: “I have an only son, who does all sorts of things for other people, yet hates to do anything for me. He rarely visits me although I live 2 kilometres away. He seldom even phones.” Honouring one\'s father and mother is the first commandment with a promise attached. A New Testament commentary says to honour someone is to “treat them with deference, respect, reverence, kindness, courtesy, and obedience which their station in life . . . demands.” The command to honour our parents clearly reminds us that the authority originally vested in God is extended to parents. Parents are God\'s representative with a stewardship authority conferred on them. The command also comes with the attachment of the promise of long life. What this means perhaps is that a lot of young people have had their lives terminated prematurely due to acts of disobedience against their parents.

In our contemporary time, a lot of premium is placed on human rights as opposed to God\'s right and law. Children dishonour their parents daily in spite of the attendant consequences. The command applies to children of all ages. Younger children should learn to obey their parents. Teenagers should cherish the advice of their parents even when they feel like they (teenagers) know more than them (parents). Older or married children should include their parents in their lives rather than see them as pests. Do something to honour your parents this week.

Wisdom : Honouring your parents confers longevity and joy of obedience.

Food for Thought : Could it be that the acts of disobedience of the first law of God is largely responsible for the deaths of young people today?

title: the spirit gives life

Golden Text: He has made us competent as ministers of a new covenant not of the letter but of the Spirit; for the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life. 2 Corinthians 3:6, NIV

A man parked his car at the park in a motel where he put up for the night. When he woke up the next morning, he tried to start the car but it did not start. He stepped out of the car to check what was wrong. He then discovered that the car\'s engine had been taken by unknown people.

Just like the car is useless without the engine, so are we without the Holy Spirit. Making use of powerful imagery from Old Testament passages (Jeremiah 31:33; Ezekiel 11:19), Paul asserted the promise of new hearts and new beginning for God\'s people - a time when God\'s law will no longer need to be written in letters but directly upon human minds and hearts. The Laws of Moses written in letters point to sins and, therefore, lead to death. But the Law of the Spirit points to Jesus and consequently brings life. No one can please God by taking care of their body, giving it everything it needs. It is the Spirit of God that can help us to live the life that God wants. We must acknowledge that with our personal efforts alone we can do nothing, but God enables us to carry out His purpose.

Golden Text: “You are well aware that it is against our law for a Jew to associate with Gentiles or visit them: But God has shown me that I should not call anyone impure or unclean.” Acts 10:28, NIV

We all have our prejudices – about people, things or ideas. Many times, we cannot account for how we formed these prejudices, but we hold so tenaciously to them that they control our lives. To be prejudiced is to pre-judge someone or something without sufficient information. Apostle Peter\'s prejudices would not make him see the move of God towards the Gentiles. title: what defiles comes from the heart
message:
JUNE 16 Saturday

BH301: Near to the Heart of God

RBT: Proverbs 4

WHAT DEFILES COMES FROM THE HEART

Text: Mark 7:14-23

Golden Text: He went on: “What comes out of a man is what makes him \'unclean.\'” Mark 7:20, NIV

Sometime ago, at a bus stop in Lagos, a neatly dressed man was accused by another as a pick- pocket. The accused man denied the allegation, but the accuser insisted vehemently that the man had stolen all the money he had on him. With the help of other bystanders, the accused man was searched and it was discovered that he actually stole the money. But for the timely intervention of the police, the man would have been lynched by an angry mob. One question that was on the lips of everybody was: how could a well-dressed man like him be involved in such a criminal act?
The answer to this question is evident in today\'s passage. Outward neatness will not prevent a man from living a sinful life. The Pharisees of Jesus’ days would not eat until they had performed a ceremonial washing in which water would be poured over their cupped hands. They did this so that they would not eat with “defiled” hands. Though they observed this, they neglected the state of their inner life and as such Jesus called them hypocrites. Jesus told His disciples that what constitutes defilement of the spirit is not what a person puts into his or her mouth but what goes on in the heart.

One great spiritual battle every child of God must seek to win is the battle of the heart. Every act of sin starts from the heart. Once the inner strength to quench evil thought is lacking, sin becomes inevitable. Little wonder Jesus said, “But I tell you that anyone who looks at a woman lustfully has already committed adultery with her in his heart.” (Matthew 5:28) Have you won the battle of the heart? Have you had victory within? While cleanliness is very important, we must not be carried away with the outward appearance at the expense of our inner life. Real purity emerges from the heart. Text: Matthew 15:1-9

Golden Text: For God said, “honour your father and mother and \'anyone who curses their father or mother is to be put to death.” Matthew 15:4, NIV

A man decided to take his aged father to the old people\'s home, because he had no time to care for his father. He took his young son with him in order to show him how the old people\'s home looked like. On their way, the child curiously asked why grandpa was being taken to the home and the father answered, “Well, because I have no time to take care of him.” The son replied, “Thank you daddy for taking me along. They claimed to dedicate their money to God while they abandon the care of their parents. As noble as this may seem, it becomes displeasing to God because God demands obedience to His commands, which includes taking care of one\'s parents. Jesus rebuked the Pharisees for making laws that help them to circumvent taking care of their parents. We must heed Jesus\' teaching to give our parents the best of care, not abdicating our responsibility for any reason. Note that the command to care for one\'s parents attracts God\'s blessings and promise of long life. How are you treating your parents?

title: the folly of riches
message:
JUNE 18 Monday

BH 119: Will Jesus Find Us Watching

RBT: Luke 11-12

THE FOLLY OF RICHES

Text: Psalm 49:1-4, 16-20

Golden Text: People who have wealth but lack understanding are like the beasts that perish. Psalm 49:20, NIV

Leo Tolsoy told the story of a successful peasant farmer who was not satisfied with what he had. He wanted more of everything. One day, he got an offer to acquire all the land around his farm for free, and he jumped at the offer. But there is a condition: he must walk to the end of the land and back in a day. He started out in the morning; he ran and ran so he could cover the land. As sunset, he came close to the point where he left off. Exhausted, he gathered every bit of strength left in him to reach the finish line, but he immediately collapsed, blood streaming from his mouth. In a few minutes, he was dead. Afterwards, his servants dug a grave __ six feet long and three feet wide __ and buried him.

The psalmist underscores the reality that riches last only for a time. No one came to the world with riches and none will take riches along when leaving this world. Riches can give you popularity and earn you the praise of people. But it cannot guarantee you a place in eternity.

That is why the Bible warns us against pursuing wealth at the expense of our soul (Mark 8:36-37). The thought of getting rich is good but the Scripture says, “... those who want to get rich fall into temptation and a snare and many foolish and harmful desires which plunge men into ruin and destruction. For the love of money is a root of all sorts of evil, and some by longing for it have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many griefs.” (1 Peter 6:9-10) Riches are valuable as much as we use them to serve God\'s purpose on earth. God wants us to be rich, but He does not want us to replace His love with the love for riches. Bless others with what God has given you; build eternal treasures in heaven so that when you leave this world, you will be rich in God\'s kingdom.

Wisdom : It is wise to respond to God\'s offer of true and eternal wealth.

Food for Thought : When death comes, wealth become s useless.

Follow-up Action : Start to invest in God\'s kingdom now.

Golden Text: Look, the wages you failed to pay the workers who mowed your fields are crying out against you. The cries of the harvesters have reached the ears of the Lord Almighty. James 5:4, NIV

It is a common practice in some places for people in authority to delay the gratification of workers. They keep the money due to these workers in banks for a specific period where it would yield interest for their own personal gain. While they do this, the workers suffer and groan under the hardship that this practice brings. James was stern and firm in rebuking the employers of his days who refused to pay the workers their wages. Because the pain and cries of these workers have reached the ears of God, James declared that judgment was sure to come upon the oppressors. The fact that money is an everyday necessity is undeniable. Everyone needs money to live and support their families. Having money is not evil but the love of it leads to evil (1 Timothy 6:10). Love of money leads to hoarding it and the Scripture warns everyone fond of hoarding wealth to expect God\'s judgment. The danger of hoarding wealth is that the soul is never satisfied. The more a person keeps money without spending it, the more the urge to keep. This leads such a person to cheat, steal and short-change those working for him.

Those who cheat others to become rich are only gathering fire for their own destruction. In the end, all that they think they have acquired with the sweat of others would amount to nothing. Nothing is as good and rewarding as being content with whatever God blesses us with legitimately. Also, we must remember that God blesses us in order to bless others. God does not condemn the rich, but those who hoard their wealth without helping the needy. Remember Lazarus and the rich man in Luke 16. Both were rewarded accordingly at the appropriate time. Be generous to God, treat your workers justly and give to the needy to avoid God\'s wrath.

We all want to \'live happily ever after.\' One of the common birthday wishes is that celebrants would have many happy returns. This shows the undeniable longing of every human to live happily. In the popular teaching \'the Beatitudes\', Jesus spelt out the requirements that make for a happy and blessed life. One of the requirements is to be poor in spirit.

Being poor means being helpless, lacking strength to face life\'s situation, thereby looking up to a superior for help. On the other hand, being rich signifies being full and self-sufficient. In essence, being poor in the spirit is acknowledging the need for a personal relationship with the righteous God to be made right with Him.

Believers should know that the blessedness of God comes through living according to His standard. Believers are as well saved from the sin of self-righteousness when we experience spiritual hunger and thirst. When we face rejection for the sake of Jesus, it is blessing to us. Acknowledging our inadequacy would help us seek the face of God daily for strength to carry on life\'s journey. Those who depend on God for daily sustenance shall not be put to shame. Instead, they shall receive His fullness and their soul shall continually be satisfied. Will you make a commitment to seek God daily so He can fill your cup and quench the continual thirst of your soul?

An article on Asylum.com profiled some floodtunnel dwellers who formed a community of people living in basement apartments and underground flood tunnel. It is amazing to note that the 700 people who live in the tunnel prefer the darkness there to the lights on the streets. In this basement, they deal with spiders and mosquitoes but they said they are okay with that. It was the same with the people of Jesus\' days. The light of God\'s love has not come to reveal our sinfulness and then ridicule us, but to let us see our need for the Saviour. Without Christ, we make choices that do not guarantee eternal life. Responding to the light means trusting Him and being confident that He alone can save us, while rejecting Him signifies trusting in our ability to save ourselves. Riches guarantee influence and access to lots of good things in this world. With riches come fame and connections. The rich young man (v. 22) probably thought he could use his influence to gain entry into heaven, but he was surprised and sad to learn from Jesus that he had to give out his wealth to the poor to be eligible for heaven. From all indications, the man was full of self-importance. He hoarded his wealth, which is a sin by biblical standard. Those who put their trust in riches cannot trust God, and therefore, cannot live a life of faith.Though the man appeared religious, he was not willing to obey God totally.

Jesus was not in any way condemning being rich. But He was stating the reality that those who are attached to possessions cannot live a life of self-denial which God\'s kingdom requires. We cannot claim to love God with all our heart and keep our possessions to ourselves. Loving God means using resources at our disposal in ways that please Him. You cannot bribe or influence your way to heaven; it has to be according to God\'s laid down procedure. Entering heaven becomes difficult for someone given to the love of money. A heart obsessed by the love of mammon cannot be occupied by love for God at the same time.

Some of the soldiers are usually imprisoned or tortured, but they all endure because they have a hope of a home to return to. Sometimes, they return home to the waiting arms of their family members. Their hope becomes reality.

If the rich man had had the opportunity, he would have changed his destination because, as we know, hell is not a pleasant place. But it was too late. He realised that his state was a permanent one. A typical Jew was taught to show hospitality to others, because they believed guests were sent by God. Jews did not hesitate to entertain friends, enemies and strangers as is evident in Genesis 18, where Abraham hosted three unknown men. The rich man had the same opportunity to care for Lazarus a destitute, but he failed. At death, both arrived at different destinations. Lazarus did not go to heaven because he was poor, neither did the rich man end in hell because he was rich. Their individual disposition to spiritual issues of life determined where they ended.

The rich man lived in so much comfort here on earth that he became complacent that such comfort awaited him in eternity, though it is possible but it was not so for him, because he never lived with eternity in view. There is no hope in hell, a place of permanent agony. The terrible experience of hell would not change anytime. We are in the hour of mercy now. A time would come when the door of mercy would be shut. Make a decision for Jesus now while you still can. message:
JUNE 25 Monday

JOSEPH FORGIVES HIS BROTHERS

Max Lucado said, “When you are hurt, part of you is broken, and the other part is bitter. Part of you wants to cry, and part of you wants to fight. The tears you cry are hot because they come from your heart, and there is a fire burning in your heart. It\'s the fire of anger. It\'s blazing. It\'s consuming. title: forgiving and consoling the offender
message:
JUNE 27 Wednesday

BH399: Sweet Peace, the Gift of God\'s Love

RBT: Leviticus 7-9

FORGIVING AND CONSOLING THE OFFENDER

Text: 2 Corinthians 2:5-11

Golden Text: Now instead, you ought to forgive and comfort him, so that he will not be overwhelmed by excessive sorrow. 2 Corinthians 2:7, NIV

Renowned Christian family psychologist, Dr James Dobson said when it comes to dealing with a strong-willed child, the aim of the parent should be to bend the will without breaking the child\'s spirit. In today\'s passage, Paul addressed the issue of church discipline and forgiveness. A brother in the church at Corinth did something bad which caused grief for other members of the church. While admitting that the offence of a member of the church affects all, Paul cautioned that the discipline to be meted out to the offender should be to restore and not to destroy the person. He asked that the church forgive the offender, comfort him so that he is not overtaken by much sorrow.

In an age where we want to pamper everyone so we can keep them in the church, church discipline is becoming less popular. In churches where there are still modalities for disciplining erring members, we sometimes take the discipline to the extreme. So, it is either we are not upholding discipline at all or we are overdoing it. Discipline in the family and the church should, however, focus on correcting and restoring the offender as well as restoring healthy relationship among brethren. It should be done in love without sentiments. When the offenders realise their mistakes and become sober, Christians should readily forgive and help to restore them. Doing this will give no room for Satan to finally snatch the offender away to hell.

Wisdom : Wisdom requires knowing when to confront sin and when to comfort the repented sinner.

In the book, No Future Without Forgiveness, Desmond Tutu tells the powerful story of his role in South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The Commission sought to bring succour to a people who have been ravaged by so much violence. The belief is that for the country to move forward, the people must forgive one another. Desmond Tutu also asks the questions: Does forgiveness mean we don\'t care about justice? Does forgiveness mean there is no consequence for evil? “No. What it means is that we leave justice and vengeance in God\'s hand...who alone can judge rightly.

Forgiveness is inevitable as long as we are on this earth, relating with other people. Sometimes, believers go about with the erroneous belief that within the church family, there should be no offence. We create a perfect picture of how we want people to behave and when they fail to live to our expectations, we get hurt. Because the church family consists of people from various backgrounds, different personalities and diverse experiences, frictions may be inevitable. However, to prevent these frictions from degeneration to disaffection, Apostle Paul enjoins believers to put on “bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering; Forbearing one another, and forgiving one another” (vv. 12-13) as Christ forgave us. If we allow Christ\'s peace in our lives, and give ourselves to God\'s Word, forgiveness would become a walkover for us.

Golden Text: So watch yourselves. \'if your brother or sister sins against you, rebuke them; and if they repent, forgive them. Even if they sin against you seven times in a day and seven times come back to you saying “I repent,” you must forgive them. Luke 17:3-4, NIV

How much should I forgive? This is a question that often brings agitation when it comes to the issue of forgiveness. How long can I bear with the offence of a brother or sister? For how long should I keep forgiving someone who keeps offending me? Should there not be a limit to forgiveness?

The disciples seem to be asking the same questions. Jesus responded by stating that it is not possible that we would not be offended by someone. He also stated that when someone offends us, and seeks forgiveness, we should rebuke them and then forgive. It is natural to feel that forgiveness has its limits, but we are expected as Christians to move to a higher level of forgiveness. While it may be easy to forgive simple wrongdoings and injustices among family members, grievous sins, which cause permanent damage may be difficult to forgive, yet Christ commands us to forgive, no matter the frequency or enormity of the offence. This is in contrast with the beliefs of the Pharisees in Jesus\' days, who taught that forgiving three times was enough before a person could retaliate.

Forgiveness is a must for us as God\'s children. When we forgive, we receive freedom and peace which we cannot have by holding onto a grudge. Relationships are restored when we forgive one another. There is no limit to how much we should forgive. To live the life of love that God calls us to, we must keep forgiving.

Wisdom : Unforgiveness is the devil\'s bait to keep one in bondage. Do not fall for it.

As human beings, we find it easy to ask God for forgiveness, while finding it difficult to forgive others. Philip Yancey said, “In the final analysis, forgiveness is an act of faith. By forgiving another, I am trusting that God is a better justice-maker than I am. OFFER MERCY AND FORGIVENESS FREELY

Text: Matthew 18: 21-35

Golden Text: Jesus said to him, "I do not say to you seven times, but seventy times seven. Matthew 18:22

Alexander III became the emperor of Russia in 1881 after his father was assassinated. Suspecting that he could be a victim of the same conspiracies that took his father, Alexander III introduced repression of opponents as the corner stone of his reign. But his wife was a sharp contrast to him, being known for her generosity to the needy. On one occasion, her husband signed an order consigning a prisoner to life in exile. The statement read: \'Pardon impossible, to be sent to Siberia.\' Moved by compassion for the prisoner, the wife altered the statement by moving the comma, to read: \'Pardon, impossible to be sent to Siberia.\'

Forgiveness can be difficult especially when someone keeps offending you. Little wonder Peter sought clarification from Jesus about how many times one should forgive. Instead of seven times, as Peter thought, Jesus said seventy times seven. In the parable, Jesus Christ depicted God as the master who pardoned the unpardonable servant. But this servant refused to extend forgiveness to a fellow servant because he had a wicked heart. He was quick to forget the mercy and forgiveness he had just received and so could not reciprocate forgiveness to his fellow servant. However, when the master got wind of what this servant did, he withdrew his pardon, condemned him and had him jailed.

Unforgiveness is more costly than forgiveness. Someone said refusing to forgive is like drinking poison and expecting the other person to die. The poison of unforgiveness builds up bitterness and resentment in a person thereby keeping their heart in bondage. Unforgiveness robs one of peace and brings emotional wounds. Medical experts have traced the origin of many terrible diseases to unforgiveness and have recommended forgiveness therapy for the healing process. The most important is that until you let go of offences and forgive your offender, you are disqualified from receiving God\'s forgiveness and mercy.

Wisdom : One who forgives will be forgiven by God.

Food for Thought : Do I forgive people who offend me or hold grudges against them?

In a remote village where Pastor Nath worked as a missionary to a small tribe, it was with great joy and appreciation that he received a consignment that was sent to them from the city. The pastor\'s wife excitedly tore open the container. Alas! Inside it were a lot of groceries and clothings enough to be shared among the villagers. But when they started checking the items, they discovered that a larger portion of them had expired. They became downcast. The city people had sent to them their leftovers, perhaps things meant for the garbage bin.

As a mark of His covenant with His people Israel, God gave them instructions to give Him the first of their dough. After bringing the Israelites out of captivity and forty years journey through the wilderness, God had to give them commandments that will extend to generations after them. The commandment to give an offering to the Lord is so significant, God asked for “the first of the dough”. God wants the first and the best of all we have, and not leftovers. Many believers have the attitude of taking care of other things first while giving to God the leftover. In the face of scarce resources to meet increasing demands, the temptation to consider God later is very high. Because our physical needs stare us in the face, we may begin to rationalise giving, consoling ourselves that God understands. But God\'s standard does not change with circumstance. As we continually expect to receive the best from God, we should also make commitment to continue to give God the first and the best of our offerings.

Telephone answering machines are a great invention. But it could be very frustrating to give someone a call and while the phone rings and you are expecting to hear the person\'s voice, you hear another voice saying, \'Hi, you\'ve reached the voice mail of Mary Jones. I\'m not available to answer the phone right now. Wait for the beep to record your message. Thanks.\'

It\'s a great relief to know that God does not have a voicemail. He is always available to receive our call and respond to them. Jesus\' teaching about persistence in prayer indicates that God is always willing to hear us. The friend in Jesus\' illustration would not budge initially because the timing of the request seems awkward but he later opened the door to his friend and offered him help because the friend at the door would not give up. Jesus said if a human being with limited resources would respond to a request, then, God, our Father, would respond to those who do not give up in asking, seeking and knocking. God is waiting for you to ask Him to come to your rescue. He wants you to trust Him with your heart\'s desires; to keep asking Him until it is done. Constant and continuous plea to God in faith reveals a heart that trusts Him for answers. God\'s says we should ask and He assures us of receiving answers. No matter how long it takes, don\'t stop asking. Your persistence won\'t disturb God, for He will certainly respond.

A man of God once said, “Christians run short of words in prayers when the focus of their prayer is themselves”. Many times, when fellow believers share their troubles with us, we part by saying \'I will be praying for you\' and more often than not it ends there. Apostle Paul made it known that the burden he had about Christians in Rome did not just end as a burden; he had earnestly and constantly been placing them before God. Truly, their faith in God was a concern to him. Their growth and progress in Christ was a strong burden within him. However, he realised that his present situation incapacitated him from rendering any help in person, thus he took them to God in prayers, believing that God will open a door for him to visit them.

As we live each day, we can carry the burden of prayer for people\'s unpleasant situations. When we do not have anything to give them, we can make commitment to constantly remember them in prayers. God still seeks people who will stand in the gap for others. Most of the things we talk about in people\'s lives are things we should pray to God about. Are there people suffering, afflicted, unsaved, oppressed or frustrated around you? Take them to God in prayers for the effectual fervent prayer of the righteous avails much (James 5:16).

John Bunyan the author of the famous Pilgrim\'s Progress described prayer as a sincere, sensible, affectionate pouring out of the soul to God, through Christ in the strength and assistance of the Spirit, for such things as God has said. Apostle Paul enjoined the Thessalonian believers to esteem those who labour in leadership over the church. He emphasised peace, patience and kindness as virtues that will help as they serve in the Lord\'s vineyard. More importantly, he urged them to pray continually.

As members of the body of Christ, we are dutybound to pray for the various ministries of the church. Watchman Nee said, “The ministry of the church is to bring the will in heaven to earth. How does the church bring the will in heaven to earth? It is by prayer on earth. Prayer is not as small and insignificant as some may think. It is not something that is dispensable. Prayer is a work. Prayer is the church saying to God, “God, we want Your will.” Prayer is the church knowing God\'s heart and opening its mouth to ask for what is in God\'s heart. If the church does not do this, it does not have much use on earth.”

Our prayers should not be centred only on individual and family needs; we must always pray for the church\'s ministry. The continuous prayers of believers enhance church growth and development. A leader who will succeed at leading his followers as God intends needs prayers from others. Spiritual heads, teachers and workers in the vineyard of God, need our support, cooperation, but most of all, our prayers for them to act rightly.

In her book, The Widows, Thurston Bonnie explains that “The Hebrew word for\'widow\'—almanah—has-as its root the word \'alem\' \'unable to speak\', which is related to an Aramaic word meaning to be in pain.” The Greek word for widow \'chera\' comes from the Indo- European root \'ghe\', which means \'forsaken\' or \'left empty\'”.Widows are among the vulnerable and defenceless in the society. Look around you and identify the helpless and vulnerable – widows, widowers, orphans, aliens – and do something to help their situation. Golden Text: Now in these days when the disciples were increasing in number, a complaint by the Hellenists arose against the Hebrews because their widows were being neglected in the daily distribution. Acts 6:1

A 38-year old woman who lost her husband after a long battle against cancer shared her experience about widowhood. According to her, her local church seemed forthright at the time of her husband\'s death. But as time went by, they shifted focus from her, perhaps they assumed that all her needs and those of her three children are being met. The Acts chapter 6 scenario, which became a reference point for the selection of deacons in churches, shows that the disciples considered taking care of widows a responsibility that must be deliberately carried out. That was why they appointed deacons to take it up. The recommendations of the apostle that some brethren should be chosen to take care of the widows pleased the congregation and they selected the people. As seen in this experience, taking care of widows is not a responsibility to be handled by those who are not filled with the Holy Spirit.

Many churches today are not intentional about caring for widows. Widows regardless of their nativity should be taken care of by the church. It is part of the ministry of the church, which should not be disregarded or considered insignificant. Caring for widows involves “serving tables” so those who are not humble cannot be effective in this ministry. Other criteria for those to be involved in caring for widows include, honesty, and wisdom of God. Paul\'s admonition to Timothy as a pastor of a church is, “Give proper recognition to those widows who are really in need (1Timothy 5:3).

Chief Musa Derrick was the richest man in the community. Of all houses in the area, his mansion was the most secured, being guarded by trained guards day and night. However, one day, Chief Musa\'s house was burgled and his trained guards were overpowered and bound. The community members felt so insecured. Nothing happens in the world outside God\'s knowledge. He is omnipresent and He watches over His children. How pleasant is it to know that the Master of the universe is watching over us. This should calm our fears, worries and anxiety; give us confidence and boost our courage. David in Psalms 121 describes how God watches over His people at all times without slumbering. Unlike night guards who go to sleep, God neither sleeps nor slumbers. He is always alert and awake watching over His children. Whenever you are afraid or overwhelmed by your situation, always remember that, “…His eye is on the sparrow and I know He watches me…”

A young girl was walking home with her friend when they saw a wallet on the floor. Inside it, they found a huge amount of money in foreign currency. Her friend was joyous and began to plan for a shopping spree. The young girl, however, searched the wallet until she found an identity card belonging to its owner. When she told her friend that she was going to return the wallet, her friend was shocked. “Nobody returns this kind of money”, her friend said. In today\'s passage, Jesus showed His disciples that there are two options in our life\'s journey: to follow the multitude or to follow Christ. The narrow gate is less attractive and so only a few pass through it. On the other hand is the wide gate which attracts the crowd. Jesus encourages us to enter through the narrow gate which leads to eternal life and shun the wide gate which leads to destruction.

There will be times when we are tempted to act in ways that conform to the norms of our environment, even when it does not glorify God. Today, we are reminded that as believers, we are called to a higher standard, and that we must not compromise even when it seems the normal thing to do. As you go about your activities, do all it takes to remain on the narrow way that leads to eternal life.

STAY CONNECTED TO JESUS

Text: John 15:1-11

Golden Text: I am the vine; you are the branches. If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit; apart from me you can do nothing. John 15:5

What would happen to a working fan that is removed from its source of power? Well, the fan would continue to work for a while but it would eventually stop working. It does not matter how long the fan had been connected, the moment it loses contact with its source there will be a gradual reduction in its operation until it stops working. So it is with the Christian race.

Jesus said He is the source to which every believer is connected, and that we can only bear fruit as long as we remain in Him. The implication is that when as a branch, we are disconnected from the vine, we may seem fresh and full of life for some time, but the branch will soon wither because it is no longer connected to the vine.

Jesus\' illustration shows that there is no room for self-sufficiency or complacency in the Christian faith (2 Corinthians 3:5). To remain relevant in God\'s vineyard, we must pursue a growing relationship with Christ by studying the Scriptures and fellowshipping with other believers. The purpose of remaining connected, however, is to bear visible fruits. The life we live wherever we are is a visible fruit of our connection with the Lord.

Wisdom : Dependence on God is a requirement for fruitfulness.

Food for Thought : A disconnected Christian is a dying Christian.

Follow-up Action : Evaluate your stand in the Christian race. Write down the areas that you need to address in order to strengthen your relationship with God and develop a plan to accomplish this.

title: by their fruits you will know

BH357: Take My Life

BY THEIR FRUITS YOU WILL KNOW

Golden Text: By their fruit you will recognize them. Do people pick grapes from thorn bushes, or figs from thistles? Matthew 7:16

Agriculture experts have stated that all citrus tree species – whether lime, orange, lemon, tangerine or grapefruit – have dark green waxy leaves with a common citrus odour which can make one mistake them for one another. How then can they be differentiated? It is by their fruits. Once a citrus tree starts bearing fruit, the confusion about the specie is eroded as the fruit differentiates it from others.

In the same way, Jesus says a tree is identified by the fruit it bears. Just as a good tree cannot bring forth bad fruit neither can a bad tree bring forth good fruit. In the age in which we live, many people claim to be followers of Christ. They identify themselves through car stickers, hand bands and other souvenirs. However, the true measure of our Christian faith is our character. The passage reminds us that the state of our heart is a determinant of our actions. A heart that loves God will lead to actions that glorify Him.

As believers in the marketplace, the manner in which we conduct ourselves as we go about our daily activities show our fruits. Our actions and inactions send a message to the people around us about who we really are. In our speeches, conducts and reactions, we should be ambassadors of Christ. The disciples were called Christians because they lived like Christ (Acts 11:26). If someone chooses to look at the way you live, use your money and respond to people you interact with, will that person conclude that you are truly a child of God?

Wisdom : Fruits are a reflection of the tree, just as actions are a reflection of the heart.

title: hear and act on the word
message:

HEAR AND ACT ON THE WORD

Text: Matthew 7:24-29

Golden Text: Therefore everyone who hears these words of mine and puts them into practice is like a wise man who built his house on the rock. Matthew 7:24

John MacArthur compares listening without doing to auditing a class in the university. As an auditor, you attend classes. However, you do not complete any assignment, take tests or exams. In other words, you “listen” to the course but you don\'t “do” anything with what you hear. There\'s no accountability, and therefore, no credit for the course.

Jesus says acting on God\'s Word is the solid foundation upon which we can build an enduring Christian life. It is one thing to hear the Word and another thing to do it. Those who hear the Word but do not do what it says are likened to a foolish man who set himself up for a great fall occasioned by the flood and the winds that accompany heavy rain.

The 21st century provides us with more information than at any time in history. Using phones, tablets and laptops, there is no limit to what we can learn about any subject. Broadcast messages, podcasts, pictures and other sources help bring the Word of God to our doorsteps. Also, we have the privilege of fellowshipping with believers physically and virtually. However, the true test of our Christian faith does not lie in how much we hear and know about God. Rather, it is evident in how we act in relation to the Word of God and makes choices that show that we are truly children of God. Hearing the Word of God or storing it up in our hearts is not enough we must develop the willingness to always obey it.

Wisdom : Acting on God\'s Word shows trust in God\'s plan.

title: abundant life today and eternally
message:
JULY 21 Saturday

BH386: O Jesus I Have Promised

RBT: Proverbs 11-12

ABUNDANT LIFE TODAY AND ETERNALLY

Mark 10:28-31

Golden Text: I tell the truth, Jesus replied, no one who has left home or brothers or sisters…for me and the gospel will fail to receive a hundred times as much in this present age and in the age to come, eternal life. Mark 10:29-30

Jim Elliot said, “He is no fool who gives what he cannot keep to gain what he cannot lose.” The disciples of Christ left everything to follow Him. Without the knowledge of what the future held, they entrusted their future to the One who knows the future. Perhaps bothered by their state, Apostle Peter told the Lord that they had left all to follow Him. In response, Jesus gave His disciples the assurance of abundant life as a reward for leaving all to follow Him. He told them that whatever they had left for the sake of the Gospel will be repaid them in hundredfold. Ultimately, Jesus assured them of eternal life, a gift that cannot be bought or earned. The Bible makes it clear that God is the rewarder of them that diligently seek Him (Hebrews 11:6).

For a believer, abundant life does not mean flashy and extravagant lifestyle. Rather, it implies a life that gets its supply from God according to His riches (Philippians 4:19). In a world where resources are scarce and lack is prevalent, it is the desire of God\'s heart that His children lack nothing good (Psalm 23:1, 37:25). The secret to the abundance, as seen in the passage, is surrendering and total obedience. As you go about the day\'s activities, be sensitive to the leading of God\'s Spirit and trust Him to supply all that you need according to His riches in glory.

Wisdom : God is a rewarder of them that diligently seek Him.

title: strive to enter god's kingdom
message:
JULY 22 Sunday

BH229: Jesus Is Calling

RBT: Ezekiel 31-36

STRIVE TO ENTER GOD'S KINGDOM

Text: Luke 13:22-30

Golden Text: Make every effort to enter through the narrow door, because many, I tell you, will try to enter and will not be able to. Luke 13:24

Derek Redmond became popular in the 1992 Olympics not because he won any medal but because of his tenacity to finish his race even when he was injured. At 175 metres to the end of the 400 metre race, Derek pulled his hamstring muscle and collapsed on the ground. But he got up, hobbling on one leg towards the finish line. His father, who was initially cheering him on, beat all restrictions to go help his son; father and son hobbled together and crossed the finish line.

The Greek word for "strive" is agonizomai, implying an agonizing, intense, purposeful struggle. The faith we have received freely is an active faith. We are to leave no stone unturned as we search our lives and seek to enter through the narrow door. Paul in his letter to the Corinthians encouraged them to “fight the good fight of faith” (1 Timothy 6:12). A continuous and consistent effort must be made by every believer to conform to the standards that God requires (Romans 12:1-2). To strive is to shed off complacency and everything that entangles us from running the race set before us and finishing strong.

However, we do not make efforts with our strength. We have the grace of God to help us in the race. As Apostle Paul put it: “But by the grace of God I am what I am… No, I worked harder than all of them—yet not I, but the grace of God that was with me” (1 Corinthians 15:10).

Wisdom : The faith we have received is an active faith.

Food for Thought : To enter through the narrow door, we need the grace of God.

Follow-up Action : Put an image of an athlete or a fighter somewhere you can see it regularly to remind you of the effort required in the Christian journey.

Prayer : Lord Jesus, grant me the grace to enter Your kingdom no matter the distractions and discomfort.

EXEMPTIONS FROM MILITARY SERVICE

Text: Deuteronomy 20:5-8

Golden Text: Then the officers shall add, “Is any man afraid or fainthearted? Let him go home so that his brothers will not become disheartened too.”Deuteronomy 20:8

Distraction or inability to pay attention often interferes with focus, and when focus is affected, D there is room for fatality. After assuring the army of Israel of victory in battle because of His presence, the Lord instructed the leaders of the army to reduce the number of soldiers using some criteria. Any officer who has built a house but is yet to dedicate it should be asked to go back home. If a soldier has planted a vineyard but is yet to eat from it or is betrothed to a wife, he should be sent back home. Also, soldiers who are faint-hearted or fearful are also to be sent back home. By this, God wanted them to eliminate fear or any other thing that can constitute distractions in battle.

With an army of thirty two thousand, Gideon was ready for the battle. However, God instructed him to tell anyone who was afraid to leave the troop and he did so. He was amazed. Twenty-two thousand men left. God did not want any fearful soldier on the warfront, because fear can be fatal. The Word of God likens the Christian life to a battleground (Ephesians 6:11-12, 1Timothy 6:12). And total commitment is required for soldiers on the war front, because anything less could be costly. The exemptions from the army of Christ are those whose hearts are not fully fixed on God. For some, they have other things that are priorities in their lives while for others, their hearts are filled with fear. Apostle Paul rightly observes that, “No one serving as a soldier gets involved in civilian affairs — he wants to please his commanding officer.” (2 Timothy 2:4). To fight the good fight of faith, we must be totally committed to God by dispelling all distractions.

Wisdom : Fear can be fatal

THE WEALTHY AND KINGDOM MEMBERSHIP

Text: Luke 18:18-25

Golden Text: Indeed it is easy for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God. Luke 18:25

Issues of riches and wealth touch the hearts of many people. Because of the many things that wealth can deliver, being wealthy brings admiration. The rich command many things because people see them as achievers in the world.The rich young ruler came to Jesus asking Him what to do to inherit eternal life. Jesus told him to obey all the commandments, and the young man told Jesus he had always done this since he was small. His reaction to Jesus\' instruction to go and sell all that he had and give to the poor showed that he had another god in his life __ his wealth. He was full of sorrow because he was very rich, and was so attached to his riches.
What does Jesus\' statement “How hard it is for the rich to enter the kingdom of God!” mean? Is Jesus condemning being rich? No. Jesus only affirmed the natural tendency to get carried away with riches at the expense of knowing God or serving Him. With many riches, one has the tendency to be proud or trust in one\'s riches rather than God. But Jesus said that we can be rich towards God(Luke 12:21). Being rich towards God makes it easy to share our possessions with those who are in need. Jesus\' parable of the rich man and Lazarus shows us that though riches can give us all the comfort we want in this world, it cannot guarantee us a place in heaven. Apostle Paul states that, “those who want to get rich fall into temptation and a snare and many foolish and harmful desires which plunge men into ruin and destruction. For the love of money is the root of all sorts of evil, and some by longing for it have wandered away from the faith, and pierced themselves with many a pang” (1Timothy 6:9-10). Check your motivation for getting rich. Is it for the love of money or for the love of God?

message:

RBT: Leviticus 19-21

TAKE UP THE CROSS AND FOLLOW

Text: Matthew 16:24-28

Golden Text: Then Jesus said to his disciples, “Whoever wants to be my disciple must deny themselves and take up their cross and follow me.” Matthew 16:24

To many today, the cross is a symbol of a terrible situation that has to be endured. But that was not what it was to the Romans back then. The cross and crucifixion were part of the brutal system of punishment of the Roman Empire. Then Israel was under the Roman rule, and the worst of criminals who had been condemned to death were asked to shamefully carry their own cross to the outskirts of the city where they would be executed by being hung on the cross.

Therefore, when Jesus said that anyone who wants to be His disciples must take up their cross and follow Him, He meant that disciples must be ready to bear suffering and shame for the sake of the Gospel. Jesus also said that anyone who struggles to save his life here at the expense of life in heaven will eventually lose it. But those who regard saving their life for eternity will not be afraid to lose their comfort for the sake of the kingdom.

As believers, we are called to a life of sacrifice. To take up our cross is to follow the example that Christ laid down, that is, to endure ridicule, mockery and shame for the sake of the kingdom of God. Christ does not want disciples that only follow Him for the benefits alone; He seeks disciples who endure through thick and thin. Following Christ implies a personal relationship with Him which compels us to obey Him, no matter the challenge. Being a Christian is costly but it is greatly rewarding in this life and in eternity.

Wisdom : Sacrifice separates disciples from fans.

In a bid to build an empire in historical China, some individuals and their families were elevated from the masses to the ruling class. Adamu was troubled in his heart. For two weeks, he had felt the Holy Spirit urging him to talk to his neighbour about Christ. The problem was that his neighbour was not the kind of person that would listen to the Gospel. However, when the conviction came strongly again, Adamu called his neighbour and shared the gospel of Jesus. To his amazement, his neighbour broke down in tears and accepted Jesus. It was a moment of great shock and joy for Adamu.

The attitude of the Jews who listened to Paul was not encouraging. While some believed, others did not. Those who did not believe must have stirred up dissension such that they started arguing. But Paul, instead of getting discouraged, put their attitude in the perspective of the Scripture as he quoted Isaiah\'s prophecy. The good news is that God has promised that the Gentiles will hear the Gospel and listen.

There are those who we classify as Gentiles. People whom we believe have little or no chance of giving the Gospel a listening ear talk less of giving their lives to Christ. Today, God assures us in His Word that they would listen. The power of the Gospel is not in our persuasive words or beautiful presentations, it is in the message that we preach. The message is that Christ died for our sins and that through Him, we have redemption of sin and hope for eternal life. Do not hesitate to preach this message to those you think are a \'no-go-area\' for the Gospel.

efore any project is carried out, whether a building project or a road construction, there is usually a quotation of the cost implication. This is done in Border for the person to make an informed decision whether or not they intend to carry on with the project.

The wedding of the Robinson\'s daughter was the talk of the town. Three popular musicians were invited to entertain guests at the reception, which held at the most expensive event centre in the city. The first time Victor heard the Gospel, he found it impossible to believe. He was told that by confessing his sins, renouncing them and surrendering his life to Jesus, he would become a new creation. Text: Luke 3:7-14

Golden Text: Produce fruit in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, \'We have Abraham as our father.\' For I tell you that out of these stones God can raise up children for Abraham. Luke 3:8

Growing up in a Christian home and attending church could not deter James from alcoholism, hatred, and anger. He had heard a lot about God, but he had a hard time believing in a God he could not see. At age fourteen, he was popular, and earning more money than his dad. So he thought he did not need God. At seventeen, a lady invited him to a crusade; there he heard a message about the love of God for him, and invited Jesus into his heart. He said, “That moment, everything changed.” And from that day, he began to have love in his heart. In place of hatred for people, he found love while his love for alcohol turned to hatred. He couldnot explain how it happened but he saw great changes in his life.

After 400 years of silence, John the Baptist came to the people of Israel with a strong message of repentance. His description of the Pharisees and Sadducees was harsh but appropriate for the kind of life they were living. Though they claimed to be religious, they were very far from God by their lifestyle. John therefore demanded that they show fruit of repentance. To the people\'s question, “what shall we do?”, John responded that those who have two shirts should give one to someone who has none; those who have food should share with those who are hungry. Bearing fruits of repentance is not a one-time thing; it is something that continues as we mature in our relationship with Christ. Consider your Christian journey. Can you say boldly like that song that, “Things I used to do I do them no more; places I used to go I go there no more; there\'s a great change since I got born again”?

GENTILES EXPERIENCE REPENTANCE

Text: Acts 11:15-18

Golden Text: When they heard this, they had no further objections and praised God, saying, \'So then, even to Gentiles God has granted repentance that leads to life.\' Acts 11:18, NIV

A friend took his daily walking exercise with levity for many years. Day after day, he would push it further and further to the end of his to-do list. This confirmed God\'s acceptance of the Gentiles, which made Him grant them repentance that leads to life. God used the medium to prove to the apostles and church leaders that salvation is for all. People such as harlots, sorcerers, Boko Haram insurgents and others, who have been rejected by the society, are included in the salvation plan. A toddler once wandered out of her house and spent the entire night in the cold. When her parents found her, she was almost lifeless as a result of cold which she had exposed herself to. In like manner, when a Christian backslides, his or her heart grows cold towards the Lord, but God is able to restore the Christian\'s first love if he/she will retrace his/her steps.

Paul had written to the Corinthian Christians in 1 Corinthians 5 to rebuke them of their complicity in a case of incest in the church. Paul\'s action jolted them to their spiritual senses. They realised their deviation from the truth and were convinced of their need to repent whole-heartedly. In the same way, God expects us to realise our mistakes and make amends. He is no respecter of persons as “… the wages of sin is death ...” (Romans 6:23). Life eternal only comes through genuine repentance. Parents should lovingly, but firmly rebuke their children who may want to be swayed by the spirit of the end times. Let us appreciate pastors, teachers and godly parents who, like Paul, prefer to hurt us with the truth than to pamper us with lies. Repentance is a result of yielding to the Holy Spirit\'s conviction. Is there any sin you must repent of now? Do not delay.

Whatever position you hold in the church cannot save you except you become born again and you are a doer of God\'s Word .

GOD'S RIGHTEOUS, IMPARTIAL JUDGMENT

Golden Text: But because of your stubbornness and your unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath against yourself for the day of God\'s wrath, when his righteous judgment will be revealed. Romans 2:5, NIV

In those days, people used to say, “The hope of the Icommon man is the law court.” However, in many parts of the world today, human judges have failed to deliver justice. They are sometimes partial in their judgment. Humans sometimes consider the personality of those involved, and this could make them partial in their judgment. But God is not a respecter of persons; He can never be partial.

The passage addresses the issue of people who think they are better than others. There are Jews who judge and condemn Gentiles hypocritically while they engage in the same sins. They will also be judged by God in accordance with the truth (2:1-4). The Jews knew and approved of the fact that God\'s judgement is in accordance with the truth, yet they failed to apply God\'s revealed standard to themselves. Humans are equal before God who judges all alike impartially and righteously on the basis of their levels of understanding of His law. This is a good reminder that if a sinner fails to repent, irrespective of his status in the church, hell is certain for him or her. God will judge not only according to our deeds but also according to what is in our hearts (Ecclesiastes 12:14). To escape God\'s anger and righteous judgments, come to Him with a penitent heart instead of concentrating on the sins of others. Allow the Holy Spirit to search your heart and obey God\'s laws inwardly in your heart. Ensure you do not neglect the more important matters of the law – justice, mercy and faithfulness (Matthew 23:23).

Golden Text: When the Israelites saw it, they said to each other, \'What is it?\' For they did not know what it was. Moses said to them, \'It is the bread the Lord has given you to eat. Exodus 16:15, NIV

A story was told of a director in a home for the abandoned and destitute. Every blessed day she would lead the children to pray to God for the supply of foodstuffs. And till her demise, God used people to meet her exact needs for years. That\'s our God. He is a great provider. God provided manna for the Israelites in the jungle. He did a similar miracle for Elijah too. He will do yours also today.

Today\'s text is a confirmation that where there is vision, there is provision. The Israelites had enjoyed the wonders of God. But each time they had a need, they grumbled against Moses and Aaron. God had promised Moses that He would rain down bread from heaven. True to His promise, God provided manna for them. The provision of quails and manna was a significant display of God\'s mercy. God provided for them, not only to satisfy their hunger, but also to teach them to depend on Him (Deuteronomy 8:3). When God puts us in a place of need, He wants to do more than meet our needs. He wants us to learn a lesson. Providing Israel with manna was an example of God\'s way of cooperating with humans; gathering it was an example of humans cooperating with God. Israel could not provide the manna and God would not gather it for them. God played His role and the Israelites also played theirs.

People give for various reasons. Some give because of what they will get back in return, some for publicity or fame while others give to meet needs. It is good to give but better to give generously. From our text, we see a poor widow who gave an offering of two small copper coins worth only a fraction of a penny. Meanwhile, many rich people dropped huge amount of money into the temple treasury.

After observing this, Jesus said to His disciples, “I tell you the truth, this poor widow has put more into the treasury than all others....” The poor widow donated all she had into the treasury as a model of humble faithfulness rather than as a sign of God\'s provision for the lowly. It is good to give to the Lord, for givers never lack. But what we give is of paramount importance. What the widow gave was more than just an offering of coins. She gave her life. She gave all she had to live on, having nothing left at home. Does your giving measure up to what God expects from you? You need to give your life first and then your resources. Christ must be your Master not your money. Do you want your offering to attract Christ\'s attention? Give Him your ALL - your life and resources.

A seed of maize that has no defect can be kept for as long as it is safe from pests, but it cannot multiply itself where it is kept. It will only germinate and produce hundreds of its kind if planted. Through planting, the seed undergoes a sacrificial process which makes it produce more. Sacrifice is the hallmark of generosity.

The passage today captures an amazing truth that has ever confronted the minds of humans -- Christ surrendering everything for human salvation. Jesus committed Himself to serving unworthy people at a great cost; modelling what it is for someone to put aside their self-interest in order to do something for others. Paul had to mention Christ\'s pre-existence to show how much Christ sacrificed to become human. He gave up being God so that He might become human; He gave up heaven to be born in a stable. This is contrary to the human desire to enjoy privileges.

Thus, Christ has become a model and the antidote for humans\' desire to grab whatever they have at their disposal. We should not allow the privileges of wealth, status or authority to prevent us from blessing others around us. If Jesus had wanted to always remain God, our redemption would have been impossible. The act of giving is natural in some people. They give with great delight, especially to the things of God. You need to begin to excel beyond the limit you have set for your giving. Trials are one reason people do not give generously. Text: Galatians 5:16-26

Golden Text: So I say, live by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the sinful nature. Galatians 5:16, NIV

The flesh and the spirit are opposites. An old man once said, “Every believer has two lions in their stomachs. The good lion (Holy Spirit) and bad one (evil spirit)”. A curious listener inquired, \'How are they growing?\'The old man answered, “Only the one you feed grows!”

Every Christian has two natures; a sinful nature and a new divine nature. Paul admonishes the Galatian Christians to walk in the Spirit daily so as not to feed the longings of the flesh. The flesh is used to symbolise the sinful tendencies that exist in humans, most of which are manifested in bodily appetites and ambitions. It is not possible to walk in the spirit and obey the sinful nature at the same time because the sinful nature is antagonistic to the leading of the Holy Spirit. Both sinful and divine natures are striving to control our lives. However, we become the servant of the one we obey. If we walk by the Spirit, we allow Him to produce in us the embodiment of virtues as love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. The eternal consequence of living by the flesh is eternal separation from God.

Everyone who wants to live by the Spirit must surrender to Christ by accepting Him as Lord and Saviour. We need to rely on the power of the Holy Spirit to survive on daily basis. To what extent do you yield to the Spirit at home, church or work? Your submission to the Holy Spirit must be total.

Wisdom : To live a life controlled by the Spirit requires faith; a life that is "trusting" instead of "trying".

Follow-up Action : Determine to always walk by the Spirit.

title: respond to abuse with a blessing
message:
AUGUST 15 Wednesday

BH 315: I Would Be True

RBT: Numbers 1-4

RESPOND TO ABUSE WITH A BLESSING

Text: 1 Peter 3:8-12

Golden Text: Do not repay evil with evil or insult with insult. On the contrary, repay evil with blessing, because to this you were called so that you may inherit a blessing. 1 Peter 3:9, NIV

A woman felt her husband was not living responsibly. One day, she tongue-lashed him saying, “Go out there and see how responsible men behave.” She might be right in her assessment of the man but her approach was insulting. The question is: how many men have changed for the better simply because they were tongue-lashed?

Many times, when we come across difficult people, we respond with corresponding attitudes and actions because we feel that is what they deserve. This is what Apostle Peter addressed in this passage. God, through Jesus Christ, calls us to be more than natural in our reactions to people who hurt us. We are not to repay evil with evil. On the contrary, we are to repay evil with good. When we respond to abuse with blessing, God promises us that we will be blessed. In having authentic relationship with God, we need to be different. Our relationship with others should reflect sympathy, love, compassion and humility for them. Peter\'s admonition is directed at Christians since we are the ones that should be examples of goodness and kindness. Jesus taught us that “loving one another” includes those who are not good or kind toward us. We may suffer verbal or physical abuse, even from persons and places we least expect. However, we should learn to always respond with blessings instead of abuse.

Wisdom : The most effective means to change a person is the use of edifying words.

Food for Thought : Vengeance belongs to God, so why take His place?

Follow-up Action : Resolve to always respond to abuse with a blessing.

title: treat enemies with love and mercy
message:
AUGUST 16 Thursday

BH207: Rescue the Perishing

RBT: I Chronicles 5-9

TREAT ENEMIES WITH LOVE AND MERCY

Text: Luke 6:27-36

Golden Text: But love your enemies, do good to them, and lend to them without expecting to get anything back… Luke 6:35a, NIV

Mountain climbing is the hobby of some people. Many have become world famous for their efforts in climbing the world\'s highest peaks. But as courageous and enjoyable as climbing heights could be, many people would never try it, even if offered great rewards. The standard of Christian love in the text today is like climbing the world\'s highest mountains.

In many pulpits today, messages of hatred and destruction of the enemies are more popular than that of salvation. Every old woman in the village must fall down and die. However, Jesus tells believers that to love everyone unconditionally is our duty, while the enemies\' judgment is in God\'s hand. He commands us in today\'s passage to love our enemies, do well to them and even lend to them without expecting to get anything back. Our duty is to obey that command. Not loving our enemies puts us on the same level with unbelievers. God our Father has set Himself before us as an example. He is good to everyone including the ungrateful and the wicked. We must be merciful just as He is. Hostile neighbours can be found in the locality, school or workplace. For us to continue to have a good Christian testimony, we must relate with them in love and understanding.

Loving our enemies is a reflection of God\'s nature in us. It is a mark of our sonship of the Most High God, and it is a behaviour that attracts great reward from God.
