title: don't act by human standards
message:
AUGUST 17 Friday

BH40: A Mighty Fortress Is Our God

RBT: Psalms 96-98

DON'T ACT BY HUMAN STANDARDS

Text: 2 Corinthians 10:1-5

Golden Text: For though we live in the world, we do not wage war as the world does. 2 Corinthians 10:3, NIV

About the US civil war, James Parker writes that, “One of the first battles ... happened near Washington, D. C., on a Sunday afternoon. The two armies lined up for battle, and people came out from downtown Washington ... and set up picnic baskets. It was like a Sunday afternoon soccer match.... They came with their picnic baskets to watch this little battle. And very quickly they realized that it wasn\'t just a little Sunday afternoon scrimmage, a little skirmish; it was a major war, a battle to the death where thousands, and scores and scores of thousands of people would lose their lives.”

Apostle Paul underscores the seriousness of the battle that we fight as Christians and so concludes that in fighting spiritual wars, we cannot afford to use worldly standards (v. 3). Using worldly standards would amount to making ourselves vulnerable to become casualties of war. Paul\'s stern warning in verse 2 suggests that some of the Corinthian Christians may have been distracted to think that they could achieve spiritual success by using carnal strategies. Paul stated categorically that the carnal ways of fighting battles in the world cannot suffice in spiritual battle. He also stated the truth that the thought realm is the most important place where this battle must first be won. Our job in this battle, according to him, is to destroy strongholds of human reasoning because the battle for sin always starts in the mind.

It is an error for us to still be involved in the deeds of darkness such as deception, slandering, back-bitting, and other works of the flesh, and expect that we will win the battle in the spiritual realm. To arm ourselves for this battle, we must put on the spiritual armour of prayer, the Word of God, truthful speech and other deeds of light. When we live in righteousness, we cooperate with God, who is the unconquerable warrior who fights for us each day.

Wisdom : The deeds of darkness cannot achieve victory in Jesus.

Food for Thought : Am I in any way fighting with worldly standards?

Follow-up Action : Do not be guided with worldly principles henceforth.

title: new life in christian community
message:
AUGUST 18 Saturday

BH175: Seal Us, O Holy Spirit

RBT: Proverbs 17-18

NEW LIFE IN CHRISTIAN COMMUNITY

Text: Romans 12:1-8

Golden Text: Do not conform to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God\'s will is – his good, pleasing and perfect will. Romans 12:2, NIV

A man was selling an old warehouse. The building had been empty for months and needed repairs. As he showed a prospective buyer the property, he told him that he would replace the broken windows, correct any structural damage, and clean out the garbage. The buyer smiled and said, “Forget about the repairs. When I buy this place, I\'m going to build something completely new and different. I don\'t want the building; I want the site.”

The Christian life is a completely new and different one from the old life. When we come to Christ, He does not repair our old self; He gives us a totally new life. There must be a significant difference in the way a Christian used to live before knowing Christ and after encountering Christ. Paul told the Roman believers that the new life in Christ entails that they do not conform to the pattern of this world; rather, they must be transformed through the renewing of their minds. When their minds are renewed, they will be able to discern God\'s will, and are enabled to do it.

Another thing that the new life in Christ affords us is that it takes away conceitedness – a feeling of being something all by ourselves. We realise that the life we live now is not ours but the life of Christ, and that whatever we attain is by the power of the Holy Spirit within us. In the new Christian community, even though we are many, we see ourselves as one, and the life of one affects all, as the life of all affects one. There is no room for boasting as we see our gifts as a fragment of the many other gifts that Christ has endowed the body with. With this mind, we exercise our gifts to the benefit of others, and the glory of God.

The transformation that Christ brings to our lives is not mechanical but is real and powerful; it manifests all the more as we daily yield ourselves to the Holy Spirit.

Wisdom : You cannot change your habit until your mind is transformed.

Food for Thought : How much of kingdom lifestyle do I exhibit?

Follow-up Action : Stop conforming to the standard of this world.

BH348: Let Others See Jesus in You

RBT: Daniel 7-12

BEHAVIORAL ACTION GOALS OF CHRISTIANS

Text: Romans 12:9-21

Golden Text: Love must be sincere. Hate what is evil; cling to what is good. Romans 12:9, NIV

An Israeli settlement called Netzarim in the heart of the Gaza Strip was a point of much conflict with militant Palestinians for several years until evacuated in 2005. Those who lived there did so at great personal risk because they felt it was an important part of keeping their land free. A schoolteacher who lived in Netzarim in 2001 said, “I don\'t live where it\'s comfortable; I live where it\'s important to live.” Living the Christian life may not be comfortable but it is important.

Clearly identified goals often help people to achieve a desired end. Christian goals are not optional; they are duties for those who will continue to share with Christ. The first and greatest duty is love. Our love must be sincere. True love comes from our spirit which has been imparted by God\'s love through the Holy Spirit (Romans 5:5). A person whose love is false and hypocritical seeks only his/her own interests and welfare. On the other hand, a person whose love is sincere seeks the interests of God and the welfare of others.

Genuine love makes other duties achievable. These other duties include hating what is evil, showing honour to one another, being steadfast and patient in suffering, practising hospitality, blessing instead of cursing those who persecute us, identifying with people in their times of joy as well as sorrow, living in harmony with one another, willingly associating with people of low position, and never taking revenge. If people would see Christ in us, all of these virtues must be present.

Wisdom : Our love for God must reflect positively in the way we treat others.

Food for Thought : How do we help one another grow toward Christian goal?

Follow-up Action : Ask the Lord to develop in you that behaviour you find difficult to exhibit.

title: buried in baptism; raised with christ
message:

BH359: I\'ll Live for Him

RBT: John 5-6

BURIED IN BAPTISM; RAISED WITH CHRIST

Text: Colossians 2:6-12

Golden Text: Having been buried with him in baptism, in which you were also raised with him through your faith in the working of God, who raised him from the dead. Colossians 2:12, NIV

Paul uses different metaphors to describe how Christians should follow Christ. The first is that we should walk in Him. Paul reminds the Colossian Christians that since they have received Christ the Lord, they should walk in Him. The idea of walking is used as a metaphor for the manner in which a Christian should live; it includes the actions, attitudes and motivations of a Christian, all of which should be centred on Christ. Another phrase is to be rooted and built up in Him, and established in the faith. The stamina to sustain the outward growth of any plant is in the root. So, Paul is suggesting that if we must grow in Christ, then we must establish ourselves in Him. Being rooted in Christ involves praying and feeding our hearts and minds with the Word of God so much that it takes over the centre of our imagination. Then we begin to manifest the fruit of the Spirit. When we are rooted in Christ, we would be able to discern those who take people captive through hollow and deceptive philosophy (v. 8) and would not fall prey to them.

Paul also said that believers have been circumcised in Christ. For the Jews, physical circumcision was a symbol of being set apart as a people unto God. That we are circumcised in Christ then means that we have cut off the foreskin of flesh and have been set apart to live a new life, pleasing Him alone. Another metaphor that Paul used is that we are buried with Christ in baptism and are risen with Him in faith. Baptism reminds us of our union with Christ in His death and resurrection by which we receive the power of God to live a new life. In baptism, we bury the old life of sin and rise of to a new life of righteousness, which is lived for Christ alone at all times.

Wisdom : It is impossible to carry Christ\'s life and not live in a Christlike way.

Food for Thought : Are you dead to sin and alive to Christ?

Follow-up Action : Being buried in baptism means death to self; be dead to self today.

GOD'S EXAMPLE IN ALL RELATIONSHIPS

Text: Matthew 5:43-48

Golden Text: Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, that you may be children of your Father in heaven. Matthew 5:44-45, NIV

Author Anthony Walker recounts the experience of General Robert E. Lee. A soldier was surprised when he heard the General speak so well about a fellow officer. The soldier said to him, “General, do you know that the man you spoke so highly of is one of your worst enemies and that he misses no opportunity to slander you?” The General said, “Yes I know, but I was asked of my opinion of him, not his opinion of me.”General Lee\'s character provides an inspiring model of returning good for evil.

When Jesus spoke about responding to evil, He laid down two principles: i) Do not resist an evil person and 2) respond to evil by doing good. This is certainly a challenging task Jesus put before His disciples. It is tempting to respond to evil in kind, especially when the mistreatment comes from an enemy. But in our text, Jesus\' command is that we respond to hostility with love, and to persecution with prayer. To be like our Father in heaven, we must love all people because God causes the sun to rise on both the evil and the good, and sends rain on both the righteous and the unrighteous. God sent Jesus to die for us even when we were still sinners (Romans 5:8). He loved us truly when we were His enemies. In the same way, we must love other people. As Christians, we must not allow the imperfections we see in others to debar us from loving them, bearing in mind that we are not perfect as well. Loving relationship is made possible by the help of the Holy Spirit within us.

Wisdom : Loving those who love you is natural; loving your enemies is divine.

Food for Thought : How do you treat those who hate you?

Follow-up Action : Examine where your relationships do not measure up and make amends.

LIFE WITH CHRIST IN THE WORLD

Text: John 17:14-19

Golden Text: As you sent me into the world, I have sent them into the world. John 17:18, NIV

A submarine is a specialized watercraft that can operate underwater at very high pressures beyond the range of unaided human survivability. A submarine shines and fulfils its purpose under water. When it is out of water, it cannot be effective. Even though the submarine is surrounded by water, the water cannot get inside because it is insulated. Jesus\' prayer to the Father is that His disciples will not be taken out of this world, but that we will be protected from the evil in it. We have a purpose to fulfil even in this hostile world, and that is the reason God has kept us here. Jesus also states the fact that though believers are in this world, we are not of the world. The system of the world should not penetrate us but we should influence the world for the Lord.

In order to be insulated against the system of this world, Jesus prays that we would be sanctified by the truth, which is the Word of God. As Christians, we are set apart for a holy purpose. Only when we are sanctified are we fit to serve God in this world. Just as God sent Jesus into the world to save us, we are also sent into the world to continue with the mission of making disciples of all nations (Matthew 28:19-20). We must be conscious of our position as ambassadors of Christ in our daily interactions at home, school, and workplace. As His chosen people, our lives must be a practical demonstration of the teachings of the Bible through obedience. Are you obeying God\'s truth? To survive as Christians in the world, we need the Word.

Wisdom : To live in the world and yet distinct from it will result in hostility from the world.

Golden Text: You, however, are not in the realm of the flesh but are in the realm of the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. And if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, they do not belong to Christ. Romans 8:9, NIV

Tribal marks are very important in some African cultures, where they are considered means for identification, beautification and protection. Wearing the tribal mark of a family is a sign that someone is a legitimate child. It could also serve as a key for access to family inheritance. The Holy Spirit is God\'s mark of ownership on all believers. In fact He is the seal of our salvation (Ephesians 4:30b). Our divine sonship is forfeited without this mark.

We become God\'s children when we accept Christ and the seal of our adoption is the Holy Spirit. That is why Paul says that those who are in Christ no longer walks after the flesh but after the Spirit. Paul admits that Jesus was the sin offering who paid the price for our wrongs so that our future may be different from our past and that through walking in the Holy Spirit we may make better choices. The law could not make people attain righteousness in God, but with the power of the Spirit in us, we can live to please God.

People who live in the Spirit have their minds set on what the Spirit desires and the result is that they have life and peace. Life in the Spirit guarantees guidance as He helps them to focus their lives on God. If you have received Christ, and you still find yourself indulging in the works of the flesh, it is not that you do not have the Spirit, it is because your yieldedness to the Spirit is not enough. Will you commit yourself anew to the Holy Spirit and ask Him to take total control of your life.

message:

SPEAK TRUTHFULLY ALWAYS

Text: Ephesians 4:25-30

Golden Text: Therefore each of you must put off falsehood and speak truthfully to your neighbour, for we are all members of one body. Ephesians 4:25, NIV

Winston Churchill said, "Men occasionally stumble over the truth, but most of them pick themselves up and hurry off as if nothing had happened." That may be a general response to the truth, but it is against what God expects of His children. There is no way to love and follow God without loving and speaking the truth. The two cannot be separated.

God commands us in today\'s passage to put off falsehood and tell the truth to one another. We must speak the truth always, and in every situation. There are two aspects of speaking truthfully that we must consider. First, it is not enough simply to refrain from lying; we must speak the whole truth. Telling half-truth is deceptive as it leads others to believe in falsehood. To deliberately withhold the truth is the same as to tell a lie.

Second, speaking truthfully is keeping our word and promises. Sometimes, we make promises that we do not intend to keep. This is not right. Parents especially need to beware not to fall into this trap in dealing with their children. Unfaithfulness in marital and business relationships is often rooted in telling lies. Falsehood belongs to the sinful nature that we must put off, while speaking truthfully belongs to the new nature that we must put on. We must live a life worthy of God\'s calling, as we determine to always stand for the truth.

Wisdom : Truth is a hall mark of Christians.

title: replace anger with forgiveness
message:

REPLACE ANGER WITH FORGIVENESS

Text: Ephesians 4:31-5:2

Golden Text: Be kind and compassionate to one another, forgiving each other, just as in Christ God forgave you. Ephesians 4:32, NIV

At a writers\' workshop, one of the facilitators emphasised the need for trainees not just to edit their writings, but also to edit their lives. In editing, there is the need to delete or replace words that do not bring the best out of the article. In a similar way, today\'s devotion is a command to delete anger from our lives and replace it with forgiveness.

Paul asked us to get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger, brawling and slander, and every form of malice. In place of all these vices we should put kindness, compassion and forgiveness. To forgive, they say, is divine. So, when we forgive each other, we are following God\'s example, who forgave us in Christ. Ultimately, we are to imitate God as His children, as we live a life of love. Our model of love is seen in Christ who gave up Himself for us. Anger and unforgiveness are destructive. They must not be allowed to continue in our lives as Christians, whether in the church fellowship or in our nuclear families. Let us remove these vices from our conduct before they destroy our peace and harmony. With God\'s help you can overcome anger in your life. Ask God to give you power to live a life of love.

Wisdom : God Himself is our example on forgiveness. Follow Him.

Food for Thought : If we do not forgive others, God will not forgive us.

Follow-up Action : Forgive anyone that has wronged you and let the person know it.

Text: Colossians 3:1-17

Golden Text: Therefore, as God\'s chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. Colossians 3:12, NIV

A new clothing line opened a shop at the biggest market in town. Part of its policy is that shop attendants must put on clothes that belong to the brand each day of the week. Their strategy is that consumers would get more attracted to their designs as they see them on their attendants. They call it “branding the sellers”.

Apostle Paul told the Colossian brethren to become brands of Christ by wearing virtues that would attract others to Him. To do this successfully, they must first set their hearts and minds on things above, not on earthly things. They must put to death things like sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desires, greed, anger, rage, malice, slander, filthy language and lying. In place of these, they must clothe themselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience, bearing with another and forgiving each other.

If clothing brands can be mindful of how their sellers appear to customers, then believers too should be concerned about how we represent Christ to the world. Our lives should express Christ and attract others to Him. We attrract others to Christ when we deal with them with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. In place of vengeance, we should forgive others just as Christ forgave us. Our preaching may not convince some people to come to Christ, but the fragrance of our lives will not fail to attract or send them away from Christ. The question is: Is your life bringing others to Christ or repelling them from Him?

In watching the process of refining silver, a woman saw the silversmith held a piece of silver over the fire and let it heat up. He explained that one needed to hold the silver in the middle of the fire where the flames were hottest so as to burn away the impurities. The woman taught about God holding us in such a hot spot. Believers can feel the heat of fire, but God has His eyes on you keeping His hand on you and watching over you until He sees His image in you.

Peter enjoins believers to have a positive attitude to suffering. Instead of being ashamed or broken about our suffering for the sake of the Gospel, we are to rejoice, and glorify God for it (v. 16). Though suffering is hard to bear, it is inevitable for those who are willing to do the will of God in this crooked world. Anyone who faithfully follows Christ will suffer troubles and persecutions. Today\'s passage guides us as to the proper response when we bear reproach and abuse for Christ\'s sake. Being insulted because of the name of Christ is not a disgrace but an honour and privilege (Acts 5:41).

Let us not be angry with God or humans when suffering comes, because through suffering, we are being made holy; our faith is being tested and strengthened; and we are being prepared to receive a place in God\'s kingdom. The presence and power of the Holy Spirit is the secret of survival in times of suffering of faith.

Wisdom : Christian suffering is an honour, not a disgrace.

Food for Thought : Remain faithful. God will never abandon you in your pain.

Follow-up Action : Identify and encourage a suffering believer today.

RENEWED BY THE CREATOR

Text: Colossians 3:8-11

Golden Text: And have put on the new self, which is being renewed in knowledge in the image of its Creator. Colossians 3:10, NIV

\'The way you dress determines the way you will be addressed\' is a common saying. No normal person likes to dress in old ragged shabby clothes when they move around town since they would not like to be taken for an insane person.

Apostle Paul enjoins believers to take off their old garments so as to put on a new one which identifies them as Christians. We are to put off anger, rage, malice, slander, and filthy language from our lips. “Do not lie to each other, since you have taken off your old self with its practices” (v. 9). The implication of putting off these is that they do not identify us as Christians. Anger and rage are both destructive emotions expressed out-ofcontrol. Malice is animosity or an intent to injure someone. Slander is making a false statement about someone with the intent to damage their reputation. Filthy language includes profane and obscene words which, rather than edify, pollute the mind of the hearers. Lying violates the commandment not to bear false witness against one\'s neighbour.

As we take off these garments, we need to put on the new self which is being renewed in knowledge in the image of Christ (v.10). This renewal happens as we continue to behold Him in studying and meditating on His Word, praying, and living out His life. This new life in Christ also enables us to relate with everyone in love regardless of their race, gender or social status.

Wisdom : The new garment of a Christian is Christ.

Food for Thought : Do I always put on Christ for people to see?

GOD PROVIDES THE WATER

Text: Isaiah 41:17-20

Golden Text: I will make rivers flow on barren heights, and springs within the valleys. I will turn the desert into pools of water, and the parched ground into springs. Isaiah 41:18, NIV

The United Nations expressed a growing concern for water scarcity which is already affecting every continent. According to the UN, around 1.2 billion people – almost one-fifth of the world\'s population – live in areas of physical scarcity while 500 million people are approaching this situation. Water scarcity can affect life because no human being can do without water. Plants and animals which humans depend on also need water to survive. So we can say water is survival.

The need for water can be physical and it could be spiritual as well. It is then comforting to hear God promise to make water flow on barren heights, and springs within the valleys. God also promises to turn the desert into pools of water, and the parched ground into springs. With the provision of water, the growth of the cedar, the shittah tree, the myrtle, the oil tree, the fir tree, the pine tree, and the box tree becomes possible. Water is critical for growth of any living thing.

The desert is a place far away from the source of water. And only God can make it possible to get water and growth there. When we are spiritually dry, we can draw from Jesus - the source of living water that never runs dry. Jesus told the woman at the well, “Everyone who drinks this water will be thirsty again, but whoever drinks the water I give him will never thirst. Indeed, the water I give him will become in him a spring of water welling up to eternal life.”(John 4:13-14) At the scent of this Living Water, bareness, weariness, sickness give way for life and growth. You need the Living Water for a refreshing today.

Wisdom : A constant refreshing from the Living Water sustains our spiritual life.

Golden Text: They were terrified and asked each other, \'Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!\' Mark 4:41, NIV

Scientists say the oceans are rising at the fastest rate ever in the history of the world, leading to tidal flooding that is already affecting coastal cities. The consequence of tidal flooding can be fatal as water fills people\'s homes and destroys lives and properties. Because water current is not easily controlled, stormy floods could be terrifying.

Little wonder the disciples were terrified at the stormy tidal waves that almost overturned their ship. After a busy day, Jesus and His disciples got into a boat to sail across the Sea of Galilee. But their smooth sail was interrupted by a windstorm which beats water waves into the boat. It is amazing to note that in the midst of such terrible storm that left them breathless, Jesus was calm and fast asleep in the ship. The disciples could not fathom the fact that the Master remained peaceful in that terrible storm. In desperation, they awoke Him. Jesus rebuked the wind and calmed the seas. He then reproached His disciples for their fear and lack of faith.

The presence of Jesus in the boat made all the difference in the disciples\' experience. No matter how terrible the storm, we can rest assured in Jesus who is never rattled by any situation. We need to exercise our faith in Him to calm the storm and restore the order of things. With the power of Jesus in you, you can say to that stormy sea today, “Peace be still.”

Text: Matthew 5:43-48

Golden Text: But I tell you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, that you may be children of your Father in heaven. He causes his sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the righteous and the unrighteous. Matthew 5:44-45, NIV

Our society is often divided along the lines of race, religion, tribe and status. Most people tend to be kind and merciful only to those of their circle. But God is not like that. God owns the sun and the rain and allows everyone to enjoy them. Jesus teaches that we should move beyond the natural tendency to love those who love and hate those who hate us. Instead, we are to love our enemies and pray for those who persecute us. How easy can that be? It is the most difficult thing to do for any natural human. The natural response to enemies is to condemn and destroy them, but Jesus says when we show love to our enemies and pray for our persecutors, we show ourselves as children of God who sends rain and sun to both the evil and good people.
We can only be legitimate children of God if we imitate Him in our dealings with people. Even if people by their actions behave as enemies, ours is to reciprocate their opposition with love. We will be perfect as our heavenly Father is perfect when we resolve to be like Him in all respects, even in being kind and loving to our enemies. To love our enemies as ourselves requires that the Holy Spirit is ruling in our hearts. He will make what is difficult naturally become possible for us.

Wisdom : The primary way you demonstrate that you are Christ\'s disciple is by your love for others, particularly your enemies.

Food for Thought : What is difficult with you is easy when the Holy Spirit is involved.

Follow-up Action : Be kind to everyone today.

GOD CREATED THE HEAVENS AND EARTH

Text: Genesis 1:1-13

Golden Text: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth." Genesis 1:1, NIV

"Dad, where did we come from?" Dan asked his father as he was driving out of the school gate. "Why do you ask that question?" The father queried. Dan said, "Our teacher taught us the \'Theory of Evolution\' today; he said the earth came into existence as a result of a big bang, and that we came from apes; our progenitors were apes." The question this boy asked is one that people have asked all through human history. Christians\' understanding of God, the world and humankind largely comes through the Genesis creation account. The Genesis account gives us a clear understanding of how everything came into being.
The Bible proves science wrong on the idea of the beginning of things. The first statement in the Bible reveals that things did not just happen; God created them. Nothing is an object of chance in the universe. God brought forth the heavens and the earth and populated them with different creatures for specific purposes. He orderly put everything in place on different days. The sun, the moon, the animals, the seas __ God put them in place, not by mistake but on purpose. You are special; you did not come to this world by accident. Like He said to Jeremiah, God created you in the womb and He set you apart for a purpose before you came forth from your mother. Do not fail to identify and fulfil your purpose in the world God has created.

Wisdom : It takes a redeemed sight to see God\'s logo on things.

Golden Text: "Who by his understanding made the heavens, His love endures forever. who spread out the earth upon the waters, His love endures forever." Psalm 136:5-6, NIV

From science we discover that the distance between the sun and the earth is just the proper distance for the sun to maintain the right surface temperature suitable for life and the many important ecological processes. If we are any closer, we would burn up; if we are any farther away all plant and animal life would freeze. Humankind should be able to look at creation and deduce that there is a Being with eternal power behind it all. Proverbs 3:19 says “The Lord by wisdom founded the earth, by understanding He established the heavens.” This excellence of God ignited praise from the psalmist and a call to others to praise the Lord. The command to give thanks is repeated in verses 1, 2, and 3, each time with the same reason given - "for His love endures forever". Believers need to be constantly reminded of God\'s goodness because the enemy often tries to get us to doubt it, especially in times of troubles. In addition, the psalmist urged us to give thanks for God\'s power in creation, which displays His everlasting love. The psalmist shows us why God created the world. The creation is an undeniable proof of God\'s love for humankind. And this love is unconditional. Jesus said God makes the sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and unjust (Matthew 5:45). The wonders of God\'s creation should cause us to give thanks to Him and marvel at His everlasting love that made these wonders so that we would worship Him.

Wisdom : Living on earth is dwelling in the midst of God\'s love.

I once visited a poultry farmer in his farm. He asked me to go ahead of him into the farm while he was busy with an urgent task in the farm house. The bald eagle is the fastest creature of the air. Not only can the eagle fly at tremendous speed, its eye-sight is like no other. At an elevation of 10,000 feet (or about 2 miles) the eagle can see a rabbit in the forest. And, within a matter of seconds that eagle can fly down from the sky at a rate of over 100 mph and pick up that rabbit. The African crowned eagle, the most powerful bird of prey, has been known to kill antelopes weighing up to fifty pounds. Not only are eagles strong, they are also big. Eagles have a wing span up to 7 1/2 feet, and can weigh as much as twenty pounds.

A look at the heavens brings the realisation that life did not begin by chance but by design. To study nature is to see the fingerprint of the almighty God. Today\'s text teaches that animals have qualities that we should either emulate or avoid. Job tells us to ask the beasts and see what we could learn from them. Even animals can teach us spiritual character. He wants us to derive deep understanding from the study of creatures around us. The earth refers to the seasons as regards plants; they all can speak to us. You are not destined to be stranded in life. All the information you need for progress are readily available. Go all out for it, and the truth you find will set you free. Let the Holy Bible explain everything nature communicates to you in Christ Jesus.

If we would have fellowship with God, we must begin with Him, His authoritative revelation of Himself, His holiness; and we must not walk in darkness but in the light. This implies that we engage all the available channels of grace around us – personal prayer, fasting, witnessing, Bible study and Christian fellowship. Mr Raymond did not like putting on seatbelt while driving. He only used it to avoid being arrested by the road safety officers. But one day he learnt a big lesson. A little boy ran across the road, he applied the brake suddenly to avoid hitting the boy, and the car skidded and hit a brick wall beside the road. In the process, he hit his head against the windscreen.

The road safety rules are not made to benefit the government but the road users. This is very true about God\'s laws too. This law tells us to observe a special day of rest and worship. Everyone needs a day off work. God also rested on the 7th day. The word \'Sabbath\' means to cease; to cease from work. For Christians, the Sabbath is a three-fold celebration – celebrating God\'s creative power, His redemptive power and His provision. This Old Testament law has its fulfilment in Christ Jesus. Jesus is our promised rest (Matthew 11:28 NIV). God\'s laws were ultimately made to help humans live a beautiful life. The requirement for observing and keeping the Sabbath has been transformed to focus on Christ rather than a day of the week. If we have faith in Him, we will enter God\'s rest and, therefore, keep the spiritual intent of the Sabbath. In the New Testament, everyday is equally holy. Christians ought to live lives that are focused on Jesus and for His glory. Though Sunday is chosen as a day to celebrate the Lord\'s resurrection, we ought to live for Christ every day, worshipping Him in Spirit and in truth.

title: the seventh day, hallowed and blessed
message:

BH43: Immortal, Invisible

RBT: Proverbs 23-24

THE SEVENTH DAY, HALLOWED AND BLESSED

Text: Genesis 2:1-3

Golden Text: And God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it he rested from all the work of creating that he had done. Genesis 2:3, NIV

The rest note — an interval of silence within a piece of music - creates a deliberate pause, a temporary break in action. Although they often pass by unnoticed, rest notes are a vital part of musical structure. They blend the music piece and make it more interesting. They also help to create a good rhythm of the song. Without rests, the piece is overwhelming, clumsy, and the musicians, whether they are singing or playing an instrument, could quickly become tired and breathless. Genesis 2:1-3 describes the seventh day of creation as God\'s day of rest. God sanctified the seventh day because on it He rested from all His works. That God sanctified the seventh day in an instruction to us on how important rest is. God released His goodness in bringing the universe from nothing; He exercised His Spirit in bringing meaning out of meaninglessness. He looked and saw how the sun rises, the moon and the stars pursue their course; the plants grow, the flowers bloom, the fruit ripens and animals seek their food and provide for their young. So, God rejoiced and blessed the seventh day.

Before God gave the command of rest to His people (Exodus 20:8-11) He had already modelled it. In as much as it is good to be hardworking; it is equally good for us to take time out to rest. Without rest, our body is stretched beyond limit and we risk experiencing burnout. As we join God in working to manage the universe He has created, let us also imitate Him in creating time to rest so that we can continue to fulfil His purpose for us with vigour and vitality.

Wisdom : Rest is sweet after labour.

Food for Thought : Do you set a day apart when you cease from the work of the other days and be refreshed in body and soul as you spend time worshipping God?

Follow-up Action : Give the members of your family reasons you should set apart a day to celebrate God.

Golden Text: And said, “For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.” Matthew 19:5, NIV

Sister Lucy was not enjoying her marriage because her mother-in-law interfered a lot in the affairs of her home. Her mother-in-law was not living with them, yet her husband could not make any important decision without consulting her. Her husband would follow whatever her mother-in-law said to the letter. What God intended from creation for marriage is a permanent union of one man and one woman. Both man and woman must obey God\'s instruction for marriage if they will fulfil God\'s purpose. Anything short of that is not God\'s standard. Marriage is a re-enactment of the design of God for creation. God\'s principle for a successful marriage is that the relationship must be permanent; no one should seek to be separated from the union. The permission for divorce in the Scriptures indicates that people failed to live up to the model of God, though this did not in any way bring the approval of God upon failed marriages. Jesus draws the conclusion from this that if God joined the two together, they are one by God\'s will. Thus, a couple must secure their relationship against negative influence of parents, siblings and friends. As a couple, you must deal with anything that threatens oneness in your home.

MARRIED AND DEVOTED TO THE LORD

Golden Text: Do not deprive each other except by mutual consent and for a time, so that you may devote yourselves to prayer. Then come together again so that Satan will not tempt you because of your lack of self-control. 1 Corinthians 7:5, NIV

Sister Ronke loved the Lord, and she decided not to marry so she may devote all her time to serving Him. Few months after she made this decision, a brother proposed marriage to her. She decided not to pray about it, but the Lord appeared to her in a vision. The Lord said, “I want you to marry my son who proposed marriage to you because marrying him will afford you the opportunity to be in the centre of my will for you.”

Marriage and service to God are not contradictory but complementary. God, who established marriage, is the same One who assigns ministry. You can get married and still effectively serve the Lord, but you must have a balanced view in all things. Apostle Paul instructs Christian couples to strike a balance in their relationship with each other and with God. It is God\'s delight that you satisfy your spouse physically, emotionally and financially. Text: Hebrews 13:1-6

Golden Text: Marriage should be honored by all, and the marriage bed kept pure, for God will judge the adulterer and all the sexually immoral. Hebrews 13:4, NIV

Mr James was among the candidates the state governor was to appoint as local government caretaker chairmen. However, on the eve of the day their names were to be announced, his political party held a meeting. In that meeting, they introduced certain old women to the chairmen-to-be, mandating them to have sexual intercourse with the old women in order to be successful in their political career. He wants Christians to see marriage as God sees it. God established the institution of marriage as a channel through which humans may be able to exercise dominion in the world. And for this purpose, God sets marriage apart from all other human relationships. For instance, you can go in and out of other relationships as you wish and you may still remain okay with God. But, you must stay permanently in your marriage relationship if you will please God. It is the only relationship where sexual intercourse is permitted. The sanctity of marriage must be a priority to Christians, as we apply the teachings of Christ, pray and work daily to avoid neglect or defilement. Is God pleased with how you treat your spouse?

Also, our relationship with one another, as members of God\'s church, should be characterised by sincere and active love. In fact, this love should grow stronger through diligence, experience and time. We develop healthy spiritual discipline in our relationship with other Christians as we grow in our obedience to the Lord. Christianity is not a mere set of religious doctrines, beliefs about God. It is a relationship with God through Jesus Christ and fellow believers. Apostle Peter had confidence that his readers were genuine Christians who can manifest the attributes of God in all their relationships. FOR THE SAKE OF YOUR PRAYERS

Text: 1 Peter 4:7-11

Golden Text: The end of all things is near. Therefore be alert and of sober mind so that you may pray. 1 Peter 4:7

Someone described effective prayer as a process of building fire to cook food in the farm. The process involves gathering and arranging dry wood, and igniting the fire. With a spark of fire, the wood burns and releases its energy to cook the food. Without the fire, everything stands still. So, wood and fire are indispensable for a successful cooking.
1 Peter 4:7-11 teaches Christians ways to live godly lives. Peter spends time focusing on the positive things that should be the pivot of accomplishing the will of God. Just like building a fire requires effort, effective prayer has some requirements. Apostle Peter enumerates two of them in our text today. The first is alertness in the world. As believers, we cannot afford to be insensitive to the things happening around us. We must observe events in the light of the Word of God. This will empower us towards praying timely and effective prayers. The second factor is the soberness of the mind. We cannot afford to be frivolous and careless in the way we live, for our enemy is prowling around like a lion seeking for whom he may devour. It is the sober Christian who can identify the devil when he is around. Your life will become more effective in God if you become alert and sober.

A radio preacher told a story about an African traditional chief who was presented with a mirror by a visitor. Strangely, the chief steered into the glass and commented on the ugliness of the person he saw. When he realised he was looking at himself, he was enraged and smashed the mirror. There is ugliness in any natural human being, which is waiting for an opportunity to be revealed. Many times, the real picture of a person is not easily discernible from the outside.

The ugliness inside of Cain found room for expression after he and his brother, Abel brought their offerings before the Lord. While Abel brought fat portion of some of the first born of his flock, Cain brought from the fruits of the soil. However, God regarded Abel and his offering and did not regard Cain. Thus, Cain resented the way God treated him, transferred his anger on Abel and killed him. God confronted Cain and rebuked him.

We must daily open ourselves to the Word of God and the voice of the Holy Spirit within us so that our hearts will be right with God. When we brood upon offences for too long, we could be giving room for the devil to build a stronghold of evil in our hearts. This could lead to hatred that could lead to murder. As a family member, God expects you to consciously care for the rest; to ensure that your family members are safe. What offence has your spouse or siblings committed against you? You ought to forgive. Never ignore your responsibility to care for your family members.

Ben and Janet had a good start as a newly married couple. Ben is loving and supportive of his wife in the home. They did things together even in the kitchen. But one day Ben\'s father visited them and saw his son washing plates while his wife was cooking in the kitchen. The old man was shocked but kept silent. Later, he accused his son of becoming a slave to his wife. He also insinuated that the wife must have cast a spell on his son.

The garden God made was beautiful with abundant provisions, but something was lacking – a suitable mate for Adam. God fashioned Eve to complement Adam physically, spiritually, socially, emotionally and intellectually. For a healthy marriage, there must be determination of the couple to attain unity in all spheres of life. God\'s presentation of Eve met with Adam\'s delight and expectation. For the two to become one, it is necessary that a man leave his mother and father and cleave to his wife. The marriage of Adam and Eve was blessed with children. They were fit for God\'s agenda. Brother James was a very fervent member of the Baptist Student Fellowship on campus. Many members admired him as a leader. However, he thought that he had grown beyond temptation. He used to say that anyone who falls into temptation had never been a genuine Christian before. Unfortunately, the sisters\' coordinator became pregnant when she was preparing for youth service. Guess who was responsible? Brother James!

Immorality does not spring up in people. It begins with tiny seeds sown in the mind and subsequently acted upon. God described David as a man after His heart. David trusted in, obeyed, and worshipped the Lord. He always sought and submitted to God\'s direction for his life. And God accomplished great things through him. However, David had a weakness – his relationship with the opposite sex. And that was what Satan used to tempt him. Why did David fall into immorality? A number of things like success, lack of accountability and indulging in pleasure, could be responsible. Instead of being at the battle front, David was idling away time at the roof-top of his house. There, he saw a woman bathing at a distance and was aroused. He took steps to act on the temptation and he fell into sin. The way out of temptation is not indulgence, but self-control and obedience. We must confront our weaknesses with the Word of God and flee all appearances of evil. No matter who you are in the church, you must watch out because anyone can fall into temptation.

Golden Text: "Then the devil left him, and angels came and attended him." Matthew 4:11, NIV

As students, we once protested against our physics PTA teacher because he did not have a mastery of the subject he was assigned to teach. He could not explain concepts clearly. He was often clueless when asked to solve certain questions. Therefore, we concluded that if he continued teaching us, we would all fail physics in WAEC. The school authority did their investigations and found out that the teacher truly had no mastery of the subject.

Jesus Christ overcame the devil\'s temptation with His mastery of the Word of God. The Spirit of God led Jesus into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil. After fasting for forty days and forty nights, He was hungry and the devil came to tempt Him. However, we see Christ not only resisting but defeating the devil. In each of the temptations, we see Christ relying on God\'s Word and His relationship with His heavenly Father to defeat the voices of evil time after time. The passage shows that Jesus Christ is the Master of life. He faced the temptations that every human faces in life and He overcame. Turning stones into bread is to satisfy the lust of the flesh; jumping down from the temple\'s pinnacle is to gratify the pride of life, and bowing down to the devil for the glory of this world is to satisfy the lust of the eyes. By overcoming, Jesus became the perfect example of the kind of person God is looking for, a person who will absolutely live for God in thoughts and deeds, a person who will overcome life\'s temptations. Always trust in the Lord to overcome temptations.

A minister once preached a powerful message on the surrendered life. As he made an appeal to his hearers to surrender their lives, a woman whispered to another woman sitting beside her: “That is excellent preaching, but I doubt if such a life is possible?” Ways of life and comments can deter others from following Jesus. All Olympic medalists have one thing in common: they are mentally and physically fit. They achieve fitness through a lot of difficult and painful exercises, drills and trainings. "Hi, my friend, how are you in Nigeria?" That was the greeting I received from an unknown phone caller. He claimed to be my old friend who was resident in London. The question today is, “What part of God\'s word is Satan making you question?” When we take time to study God\'s Word and obey His commandments, Satan becomes powerless. title: the sins of the first humans
message:
SEPTEMBER 30 Sunday

BH 419: Stand Up, Stand Up for Jesus

RBT: Obadiah

THE SINS OF THE FIRST HUMANS

Text: Genesis 3:8-17, 20-24

Golden Text: And he said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?” Genesis 3:11, NIV

A classmate of mine while I was in primary four had mental problem. I was curious about her case because her mother and her maternal Auncle also had the same problem. I asked my father why the family had such problem. My father told me that my classmate\'s maternal grandparents maltreated a slave to the point of death, and at the point of the painful death the slave placed a curse of insanity on their children and every child that is related to the family.

Our passage today shows the origin of human problems. Adam and Eve had the opportunity to rule the earth and lay good foundation for the entire humanity. God commands them not to eat the fruit from the tree that was in the middle of the garden but they disobeyed. When they heard the voice of God walking in the garden, they both hid themselves in spite of the fact that they used to fellowship with God before in the garden. And when God asked Adam if he had eaten the forbidden fruit, he shifted the blame on Eve and Eve in turn blamed the serpent. They granted the devil access into God\'s world. They undressed themselves of divine glory. And above all, they put all of us into trouble: we all became sinners from birth. Sin always separates us from our walk with God and the shame that comes with it keeps us from asking for forgiveness. THE LORD'S SORROW FOR ALL CREATION

Wherever it is found, evil pierces at God\'s heart and those who are sold to evil must be ready to bear the consequences of their choices. Noah\'s generation had to face the music of its moral decadence - demons (fallen angels) intermarried with the daughters of men. They not only intermarried with them, they also gave birth to children through them. Sin, the destroyer of nations and civilizations, finally overwhelmed the entire human race. And God saw that they were not willing to stop perpetuating evil. Wickedness and moral corruption was so deep and widespread that God had to destroy the race and start anew.

Though God\'s redemptive project for the human race appeared to be defeated, Noah found favour in God\'s sight. He was described as righteous and blameless; a man who walked with God (Hebrews 11:7). The truth of the redemptive history is that God always has a man to carry on His saving purpose. The world today is flooded with evil as in Noah\'s days, and many times, it seems we have to be enmeshed in evil to make it in life. But the truth is that we have no excuse for evil, and God has called us in Christ to stand out in favour with Him like Noah did. Even in the midst of so much evil, you can be that one person who stands out for righteousness. Scripture says, “Where sins abound, grace abounds much more” (Romans 5:20). You too can receive grace to bring God joy, and not sorrow, all of your days.

RBT: Hebrews 5-7

GOD WILL SEND A GREAT FLOOD

Text: Genesis 7: 1–5

Golden Text: “Seven days from now I will send rain on earth for forty days and forty nights, and I will wipe from the face of the earth every living creature I made.” Genesis 7: 4, NIV

We have warning signs everywhere: the traffic signs; safety seatbelts; caution – sharp bend ahead; and other forms of danger signs. But many times, humans ignore these warnings signs. Why do people ignore warning signs? Perhaps because they feel that the one who put up the warning sign is not as intelligent as they are; or they feel they can manage the risks and still get their desired result. But experience has shown that many who ignore warning signs do so at their own peril.

God did not wipe away the first earth without a warning sign. Noah was the bearer of God\'s warning of impending danger because he obeyed God despite the evil that flooded the world. His sons were responsible and shunned the evil of their peers. Ahead of the impending judgment, they were invited into the ark of safety, and they heeded.

The world as it is will one day be destroyed, and only those who have heeded to God\'s call of safety in Christ will be spared from the impending destruction. Those who ignore God\'s warning signs are heading for a crash just like it happened to people of Noah\'s days. Noah\'s call typifies the call that the gospel gives to poor sinners. God is love but He is also holy, and we must keep this balance in perspective. Security is found in standing right as Noah did, while disobedience leads to destruction. How amiable would it be if you can emulate Noah\'s obedience in our generation?

Food for Thought : Keeping yourself from evil secures you in times of calamity.

Follow-up Action : Build your life on the principles of God\'s word and his directions always.

For you as a believer who has already made Jesus your dwelling place, God is calling you to exercise your faith in Him. It is one thing to believe in God, it is another to exercise your faith. Rick Warren said, “Faith is more than believing. Faith is more than thinking, talking, or having convictions about Jesus. Faith is action. It is movement; it is activity. Faith is something you do. WILD AND DOMESTIC ANIMALS CLIMB ABOARD

Text: Genesis 7: 11–16

Golden Text: “They had with them every wild animal according to its kind, all livestock according to their kinds, every creature that moves along the ground according to its kind and every bird according to its kind, everything with wings.” Genesis 7:14, NIV

Recently, bio-scientists have decried the human activities that have brought about the extinction of some animal species. Their concern is that all of life is connected, and any activity that has a negative impact on wildlife will eventually affect humans negatively.

In the six hundredth year of Noah\'s life, the rain started. After Noah and his family had entered the ark, the animals of all kinds, male and female, also entered the ark. God in His wisdom did not only make provision for Noah\'s family in the ark, He also provided for the preservation of wild and domestic animals. Why would God be concerned about animals? God\'s concern for animals only reflected His concern for humans. God commanded preservation of both sexes of every kind of bird and animal to provide for procreation. Thus, one generation was wiped out, but the surviving remnant would raise up a new generation. The creatures, in obedience to God\'s command, went to meet Noah in the ark for preservation.

If God, out of His concern for us, is interested in preserving wildlife, we should be concerned too. God has made us stewards of His creation, and one of the things He committed into our hands is to preserve them for generations to come. We are stewards of God\'s creation, including animals, and we should handle them responsibly.

Wisdom : Life is meant to be preserved, not to be destroyed.

Golden Text: “Every living thing on the face of the earth was wiped out; men and animals and the creatures that move along the ground and the birds of the air were wiped from the earth.” Genesis 7:23, NIV

As God promised, the rain came upon the earth for forty days and there was a great flood. As the waters increased, the ark continued to be lifted up above it. The waters covered the whole earth – the hills and the mountains inclusive. Every living thing upon the earth\'s surface – whether human or animal – died. But Noah and those that were with him on the ark were spared. Many scientists have theorised and argued about how an ark containing such volume of human beings and animals could float on the water that covered hills and mountains. But God who gave specific instructions to Noah to build the ark - which Noah followed to the letter – already had the wisdom to make the ark float.

Believers have been called out of this corrupt world, and God\'s expectation is that we do not conform to the world. When believers conform to the world, there are always tragic consequences. Scripture says, “The world and its desires pass away, but the one who does the will of God lives forever” (1 John 2:17). Noah and all that were in the ark were saved from the destruction that came upon the world because they did the will of God. Are your goals and ambition in conformity to the world or the will of God? Are you persuaded to stand out for God in this corrupt generation or you are being tempted to join the crowd to do evil? God does not set out to destroy anyone but our choices will place us somewhere – whether in the safety that God provides for those who do His will or the destruction that awaits those who continually vex Him. Your choice determines the consequence.

GOD'S COVENANT WITH NOAH AND ANIMALS

Text: Genesis 9: 8–17

Golden Text: “I establish my covenant with you: Never will all life be cut off by the waters of a flood; never again will there be flood to destroy the earth.” Genesis 9:11, NIV

Biblical history is filled with God\'s dealings with His people through covenants. And whenever God enters into covenant with anyone, there was always something to mark it, not because God would forget but because He wants humans to have something to remember. God\'s sign of covenant with Abraham was circumcision of male children. Centuries before Abraham, God entered into a covenant with Noah. And the token of that covenant was the rainbow. The rainbow is still with us today – an indication of the faithfulness of God to keep promises. The token of God\'s final covenant with humanity is the blood of His dear Son Jesus Christ, shed for the remission of our sins. All other covenants culminated in Christ. On the first day in a small class in a seminary, the students were asked to stand up to introduce themselves, and say why they had applied to the seminary. A student stood up and said, “I am here because my denomination wants me to have an M.Div. degree so I can grow a mega church.” We can say his going to the seminary was not so much about God.

Though the tower of Babel was a great human achievement, it was not of God. It opposed God\'s command in Genesis 1:28 and 9:1 to “fill the earth and subdue it”. Evidently, the people\'s idea to build themselves a city to unify them and a tower to connect heaven was borne out of rebellion against God\'s command to fill the earth; their intention was to make a name for themselves. God initiated the strategy of destroying their unified language and scattering them over the earth when the sin of pride, which caused the Fall and spread of evil, was discovered.

Whatever we establish to call attention to us gives us identity and self-worth but takes God\'s place in our lives. Whenever we are driven by self-centred motives to do something even if it is in the name of religion, we set ourselves up against God, and hinder His plan and purpose from coming to pass. It is good to be passionate and ambitious, but any drive we have to accomplish something must be placed side by side with God\'s vision. Check your ambitions. Will they make you draw closer to Christ and serve His purpose or pull you farther away from Him? Our plans and pursuits will bring true meaning and fulfilment, only if they are set within the purpose of God.

Wisdom : Standing in God\'s way makes a person His enemy.

ABRAM, SARAI, AND LOT IN CANAAN

Text: Genesis 12:5–9

Golden Text: “He took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, all the possessions they had accumulated and the people they had acquired in Haran, and they set out for the land of Canaan, and they arrived there.” Genesis 12:5, NIV

A small community of peasant farmers have been praying to God for rain for some months. In one of their prayer meetings, a young boy came with an umbrella, to the chagrin of others. One woman moved closer to the boy and asked him with disdain, “When was the last time you saw a drop of rainfall that you came here with an umbrella.” The boy simply told the woman, “It\'s a step of faith.” Martin Luther King Jnr. said, “Faith is taking a step even when you don\'t see the whole staircase.”

Abraham\'s first step of faith in responding to God\'s call was to leave Haran and relocate to Canaan. Abraham was wise enough to know that he needed to carry along his household in obedience to his God-given vision, so he took with him his closest family. He went out of his community, culture and family, to grow the nation God intended. God\'s call to service is not to a husband alone but to the wife also, because they are one before God.

Faith is a journey that requires us to turn towards the direction that God points to us. Abraham responded by faith, leaving the timing and method of accomplishment to God. He closed his eyes to obstacles on the basis of God\'s promise. There may be difficulties, but so long as God has promised, there should be no hesitation. His promises will come to fulfilment in His own time.

Wisdom : Obedience is the key to divine acceptance.

NOAH TO ABRAHAM: FAITH IN ACTION

Text: Hebrews 11: 6–10

Golden Text: “And without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him.” Hebrews11: 6, NIV

A.W. Tozer said, “Real faith is not the stuff dreams are made of; rather it is tough, practical, and altogether realistic.” Men of old had divine encounters with God through their unshaken faith. Noah demonstrated his great faith by acting on the warning against the coming flood, building an ark as commanded by God to save his family. Understanding the circumstances out of which Abraham was called reveals his unusual faith. His act of faith took place amid idolatry, immorality, and demonic power. To renounce his previous beliefs would have stirred up oppositions against him. But he acted on God\'s word because “...he was looking forward to the city with foundations, whose architect and builder is God” (v. 10)

Active faith in God does not insist on knowing the future, but in trusting God, taking one step at a time as He instructs. In every generation, God looks for a person to whom He can commit treasures of His kingdom and with whom He can continue to accomplish His purpose on earth. No matter the decay, God has always found a man. The world we live in today is filled with all kinds of evil, and sometimes, it seems difficult to do what God wants. But if men of old could stick to God in the midst of decadence, we have no excuse. In fact, we are more privileged than them because we have the Holy Spirit indwelling us. Those whom God used took a decision to trust God and act on His word, not because things were easy for them all the way, but because they knew that God always has the best plan. God still needs people to transmit faith to the next generation. Will He find you dependable?

Wisdom : Faith sees what others don\'t see.

GOD HONOURS COVENANT WITH ABRAHAM

Text: Psalm 105:1–11

Golden Text: “He remembers his covenant forever, the word he commanded, for a thousand generations, the covenant he made with Abraham . . .” Psalm 105: 8,9, NIV

Recently, the social media was awashed with the story of a young lady whose last words to her dying father were “I will never serve your God.” She felt that the God – who could not give her father many luxuries of life – was not worth serving. One day, she was invited for a job interview. When she got there, she introduced herself. As she mentioned her father\'s name, the chairman of the company who was one of the panellists asked to be sure who her father was. Then she clarified. That was how she got the job. She felt like retrieving those words she said to her father, whose good reputation had paved way for her. Our names represent all that is good or corrupt about our lives.

This is true of Abraham who was chosen of God to possess the land of Canaan, which is now called Israel. His absolute faith in God brought him this covenant blessing even to his descendants (Hebrews 11: 8–21). Humans may forget, but God is faithful to remember all His promises. He repeatedly affirmed His covenant with Abraham (Genesis 12:1–3) and later reaffirmed that covenant with Israel, the name by which all Abraham\'s descendants came to be known (Psalm 105: 9–10). The nation was to have a special role in God\'s overall plan of redemption, for through Israel He would manifest Himself to all nations. God chose Abraham and promised that his descendants would live in Canaan and be too numerous to count (Genesis 17:6–8).

We are seeds of Abraham by faith in Christ (Galatians 3:18, 29). Apostle Paul says, “For the promise that Abraham would be heir of the world was not made to him and his descendants through the Law, but through the righteousness that comes by faith.” We become partakers of the honour of the blessings of Abraham only as we have faith in Christ.

Wisdom : God rewards those who sincerely look for Him.

Golden Text: “So Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram gave the name Ishmael to the son she had borne.”Genesis 16:15, NIV

Johnny had to wait on the floor of an office to get something he needed so urgently. He thought he would quickly get what he wanted because he was up against time, but that was not to be as he had to wait several hours to get it. At a time, he stood up, and started pacing the floor in a frenzy. Someone close by had to ask him, “Johnny what is the problem?” He answered, “The problem is that I\'m in a hurry but God isn\'t.”

After waiting several years for the child God promised, Sarah encouraged Abraham to have a child with her servant Hagar. And Abraham consented as he went in to her wife\'s maid. The result of this impatient decision was Ishmael, and the consequence has remained a danger to the Church and the world at large.

In this age of quick fixes, smart phones, fast food, we may be tempted to think that spiritual things should also happen at the tap of our finger. But we must be careful not to help God perhaps because we feel things are dragging. When we try to fulfil God\'s purpose with human wisdom, we are bound to fail and create problems. We should carefully consider the effects of our decisions before we follow through. Patience is important while we wait for the fulfilment of God\'s promise.

Wisdom : To trust God is to trust His timing.

Apostle Paul stated unequivocally in today\'s passage that the promise of bles sings that God made to Abraham is for all nations. Through Christ Jesus, everyone is entitled to the benefits of sonship. As Apostle Paul said, “There is neither Jew nor Gentile, neither slave nor free, nor is there male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.” The only requirement for access to the blessings of salvation is to accept Jesus as Lord and Saviour.

Faith in Christ overrides race, colour, culture or any other basis for segregation in the world. We are not Christians because we are black, white, African or Hispanic. When we come to Christ, the yardsticks of inequities are melted, and we become one in Christ, “who has made the two one and has destroyed the barrier, the dividing wall of hostility.” (Ephesians 2:14b)

GOD'S COVENANT EXTENDED THROUGH ISAAC

Text: Genesis 17:15–22

Golden Text: “But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you by this time next year.” Genesis 17:21, NIV

A. W. Tozer said, “God is looking for people through whom He can do the impossible. What a pity we plan to do only the things we can do by ourselves.” Abraham had many options for an heir. Before Ishmael came, he had Eliezer. Now that there was Ishmael who was from his own loins, he thought he had a better option. God should just bless Ishmael and make him Abraham\'s heir. But because human manipulations do not achieve the purpose of God, God rejected Abraham\'s proposal. God made a promise to bless Abraham\'s seed. Contrary to Abraham\'s understanding, however, God intended to fulfil His promise through Isaac rather than Ishmael. The original plan of God was that His covenant with Abraham would be extended through Isaac. Changing \'Sarai\' to \'Sarah\' was not for fun.
God was going to make her mother of nations through Isaac that would come from her womb. Even when Abraham thought that was no longer necessary, God made him realise that He would not change His mind.

The popular statement, \'the end justifies the means\' does not hold with God. God is not only interested in the result but also the process. He has great plans for us but He wants to achieve them by His own methods. Often, we settle for Ishmael when God has a better plan to give us Isaac. Because we are impatient and can\'t see beyond our nose, we settle for less when we can have the best. God wants you to trust Him absolutely. If He has given you a word, He wants you to trust Him to bring it to pass, even when it seems so impossible. God does not want you to concern yourself with how it would be achieved. He only wants you to trust Him to take you to your expected end.

Wisdom : God\'s promise can be fulfilled only through His preferred channel.

Text: Genesis 18:1–8

Golden Text: “He said, \'If I have found favour in your eyes, my lord, do not pass your servant by.\'”Genesis 18:3, NIV

In her book, Making Room – Recovering Hospitality as a Christian Tradition, Christine Pohl submits that our generation knows little about the life-giving character of Christian hospitality. She laments that the word \'hospitality\' has lost its moral dimension as we have replaced the real essence of hospitality – caring for vulnerable strangers – with the picture of having families and friends come over for a good meal.

In large churches, we now have \'hospitality committees\' who cater for tea time and entertaining visitors Today, we read about a great i nm tohde eclh oufr chho.spitality pictured by Abraham and Sarah\'s care for three strangers. They rendered help with no thought of payback. Abraham\'s importunity in making the strangers stop by to be refreshed is outstanding. He pleaded with the men to wait so he could give them water to wash, a place of rest, and food before they continued on their journey. And Sarah joined him in caring for these strangers.

Hospitality is easy when we open our homes to known \'guests\'. But when it comes to taking care of strangers, we may like to redefine hospitality. The Greek word for \'hospitality\' is \'philoxenia\' which means \'love for stranger\' and its opposite is \'xenophobia\' which means \'phobia for strangers\'. In today\'s world, xenophobia is taking the place of \'philoxenia\' as the zeal to help strangers is fading away. The inherent danger in helping people you don\'t know is scaring many believers away from hospitality. But should we scrap hospitality so we can be safe? The author of Hebrews says, “Do not neglect to show hospitality to strangers, for thereby some have entertained angels unawares. Remember those who are in prison, as though in prison with them, and those who are mistreated, since you also are in the body” (13:2-3).

A child defined marriage as “a contractual arrangement between a man and a woman for the benefit of the man”. This is true of a coach who recently divorced his wife of 26 years when he left a school team to become the head of a national team. He said he needed a wife who would fit into his new social circle and his wife did not meet the criteria.

Today\'s reading gives a blueprint of the roles of the husband and the wife in a Christian home. First, because both husband and wife are under Christ\'s leadership, they are to submit to one another out of reverence for Christ. The wife should submit to her husband, as unto the Lord, encouraging him to fulfil his God-given role of the head of the family. The husband should love her wife sacrificially as Christ loves the Church, putting her well-being and progress above personal interests. Obedience to this command is not to be determined by whether either party fulfils his or her role or not. Each one, the husband or the wife, is to fulfil his or her role as unto the Lord.

Many married couples today see their spouses as tools they can use to serve their selfish purposes. The result is that we have many broken homes and endured marriages. Love is the bedrock upon which great marriages are built, and this love is not self seeking but sacrificial and Christ-centred. We will enjoy the blessings that God has put into marriage when we follow this blueprint.

Wisdom : Mutual love is the fuel that keeps the fire of marriage burning.

message:

Text: 1 Peter 3:1–9

Golden Text: “Do not repay evil with evil or insult with insult. On the contrary, repay evil with blessing, because to this you were called so that you may inherit a blessing.” 1 Peter 3:9, NIV

Two words are prominent in today\'s reading – honour and submission. Honour is an internal attitude of respect, courtesy and reverence. To honour means to set a price on, value, esteem, regard, or respect. Someone defined submission as “the defined calling of a wife to honour and affirm her husband\'s leadership, and so help to carry it through according to her gifts.”

Apostle Peter enjoins husbands to honour their wives, having in mind the equal status they have as coheirs of the grace of God so that their prayers will not be hindered. By \'weaker vessel\', Peter did not suggest that women are inferior but he meant the delicately constructed frame of the woman which needs to be treated with gentleness. Women are to be handled with care like you would handle a fragile, precious and beautiful vase. A man who honours his wife would not have any basis to raise his hand to hit her.

When God established marriage, He made the woman as a helpmeet for the man. God desires that partners complement rather than compete with each other. The movie, \'The Straight Story\' chronicles the life of a man in his seventies who took a journey to reconcile with his brother whom he had not spoken to in ten years. When they arrived at the cemetery, this woman went no further than the gate while her children went in to make the purchase; despite already living as long as anyone could ever dream of, she couldn\'t bear the sight of her own grave. Esau had already shown his contempt for spiritual things when he chose a plate of food over his birthright. The Bible records that he despised his birthright (Genesis 25:34). Thus, he became unfit for divine placement in destiny. Esau\'s loss made him weep uncontrollably. But his tears could not change his situation.

Desire is God\'s gift to a sense of fulfilment in humankind, but we must not allow our desires to control our lives. Isaac was caught in the web of his desire. Isaiah chapter 40 opens the second half of Isaiah\'s prophecy to the people in exile. The preceding chapters centred on God\'s judgment for the sins of His people. Here, we see God\'s promise of comfort to souls wearied and depressed by the burden of oppression. The message came at a time when the people of God had started having a feeling of being neglected and forgotten by God (v. 27). Isaiah challenged them to renew their hope in God. To a people wearied and tired, God promised renewal of strength.

Particularly, verses 27-31 deliver a message of renewal of hope for Israel that in the midst of a seemingly hopeless situation, they can trust the omniscient and omnipresent God. It is a call for the people to yield their struggles to God; give Him their hearts, and believe in Him who gives power to the faint and increased strength to the weary. Trusting totally in God would renew their strength, so that they can mount up with wings as eagles; run and not be weary; and may walk and not faint.

At that point in life when everything seems to get out of control; when you feel tired and wearied by what life throws at you; where do you turn to? The Scripture points our attention to a reliable source of help. Facing the reality of our limitations as humans would make us depend on the infinite God, who never grows weary or tired (v. 28). A GREAT PRIEST FOR THE PEOPLE

Text: Hebrews 10:19-25

Golden Text: And since we have a great priest over the house of God, let us draw near to God with a sincere heart in full assurance of faith... Hebrews 10:21-22

Pastor Rich McCarrell explained to his young son how his secretary screened his phone calls at the church office. He said, “If your mom calls me and I\'m busy, the church secretary will tell her what I\'m doing, and then Mom will decide if I should be interrupted or if she should leave a message.” Then he said to his son, “If you call me, you\'ll be put right through. I want you to know that you can call me anytime, because you\'re my son.” A few days later, the church secretary put a call through to the pastor from his son. He said hello and asked what he could do for his son. He replied, “Nothing, Dad. I just wanted to make sure I could actually get through to you that easily.”

As our Great High priest, Jesus tore open the temple curtain for us to have instant access to God, anytime. Resting on this assurance, the writer of Hebrews invites us to draw near to God with a sincere heart, in full assurance of faith, after our heart and body might have been cleansed through the sacrifice Jesus made. The Old Testament high priests could only speak to God on behalf of the people, who do not have direct access to Him. But Jesus changed the old order of things through His once-for- all sacrifice for sins for all who believe in Him. You can cultivate a real and living relationship with God once you give your life to Christ. You have a direct access to God, and you do not need any intermediary any longer for you to communicate with your Father.

Wisdom : Relating with God as Father is a privilege to be cherished.
