RBT: Psalms 131-133

TITHE TO SUPPORT LEVITES AND COMMUNITY

Text: Deuteronomy 14:22-29

Golden Text: So that the Levites (who have no allotment or inheritance of their own) and the aliens, the fatherless and the widows who live in your towns may come and eat and be satisfied, and so that the LORD your God may bless you in all the work of your hands. Deuteronomy 14:29, NIV

In a sermon, Billy Graham said, “One of the greatest sins today is the fact that we are robbing God of that which rightfully belongs to Him. When we don\'t tithe, we shirk a just debt. Actually we are not giving when we give God one-tenth, for it belongs to Him already. This is a debt we owe.” The Lord instructed the Israelites to bring to Him one-tenth of the increase of their seeds. This special tithing is to be accompanied with a time of feasting and celebration before the Lord. An important part of the celebration is to make provision for the Levites, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widows in the community. God stated that the purpose for this is “so that you may learn to revere the LORD your God always” (v. 23). Giving is an acknowledgement that our whole being and all that we possess ultimately belongs to the Lord. God asked the people to make provision for the Levites because they are fully devoted to God\'s work. The command to care for the less-privileged shows that God expects us to have compassion on those who are in need.

Just as God commanded the Israelites not to neglect the Levites living in their towns, for they have no allotment or inheritance of their own, so He is commanding us to give priority to the welfare of pastors and fellow believers who are less privileged. Ministers of God should not become beggars. When we are faithful in bringing our tithes and other gifts to the church, we bring progress to God\'s work; comfort to the ministers and joy to the doors of the needy.

RBT: Ecclesiastes 7-8

NATHANIEL WILL SEE GREATER THINGS

Text: John 1:47-51

Golden Text: Jesus said, “You believe because I told you I saw you under the fig tree. You will see greater things than that”. John 1:50, NIV

When Philip met the Lord Jesus, he believed in Him as the One of whom the law and the prophets have written (v.45). To meet this long-expected Messiah, Philip brought Nathaniel. Though Nathaniel was meeting Jesus Christ for the first time, the Lord knew who he was. Nathaniel was amazed at Jesus\' perfect description of him, and he also came to believe that Jesus is the Son of God and the King of When Jesus Christ described (v. 49). Nathaniel confessed Jesus because of what he saw, but Jesus told him that was just the beginning – that Nathaniel would see greater things.

We begin a relationship with Christ when we confess and accept Him as Lord and Saviour of our lives. But our relationship with Him does not end there. Our revelation of God progresses as He takes us from one level to another. We continue to grow each day as we seek His face in an intimate and experiential encounter. As Jesus told Nathaniel, believers should continually long to have a greater experience with the Master as we mature in the faith. There is more to God than a casual knowledge of who He is. But God does not force Himself on us. Seeing Him in greater ways and knowing Him more intimately requires a deliberate commitment to studying His Words, earnest prayer, and a willigness to listen in for the still small voice of His Spirit in us; and then obey. Experiencing God in a greater way also requires a great faith that believes in God\'s ability to do great and mighty things, irrespective of the prevailing circumstance. As you intentionally seek God\'s face daily, may you see greater things.

title: transformed by god's visitation
message:

BH 322: Nearer My God to Thee

RBT: Zechariah 1-7

TRANSFORMED BY GOD'S VISITATION

Text: Genesis 28:10-22

Golden Text: I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you." Genesis 28:15, NIV

Jacob ran away from home to escape the wrath of his brother Esau, after having deceitfully claimed Isaac\'s final blessing. Neither Jacob\'s physical state (with stones as pillows) nor his emotional state (fear of being killed by his brother, and of loneliness) could have prepared him for an encounter with God. But in his low moment, when he could least think about divine presence, God revealed himself to Jacob, and assured him of continuing His covenant promise to his grandfather through him.

Jacob\'s story changed after this encounter. Even though God had chosen him to carry on His covenant, Jacob had not had any personal relationship with God before this time. And if he must carry on God\'s purpose for his generation, he would need more than second- hand stories of God\'s dealings that he might have heard from his father and mother. God came to him in a definite personal encounter to assure him of His presence, protection, and assurance of fulfilment of His promise (v. 15). Jacob\'s experience happened in his dream but it was so real that after he woke up, he built an altar to the God of his fathers who had appeared to Him (vv. 18-19).

There is no experience that is as life-changing as the experience with the omnipresent God who sees and knows us inside out. Even at those times when God seems far away, and our feelings make us think that He is uninterested in what we go through, we need to continually assure ourselves that God is near and He always cares for us. Maybe you have a past that has kept hunting you and has given you a feeling of being unwanted. Know that God thinks specifically about you. He wants you to move closer to Him in a life- changing encounter as it happened to Jacob. You can start by giving your life to Jesus today.

Wisdom : God\'s presence makes all the difference.

Food for Thought : Are you willing to cultivate a lasting relationship with God?

Follow-up Action : Create a plan to increase your time of personal fellowship with God.

BH 522: Lead Me Lord

JACOB MARRIES LEAH AND RACHEL

Text: Genesis 29:15-30

Golden Text: Laban said to him, “Just because you are a relative of mine, should you work for me for nothing? Tell me what your wages should be.” Genesis 29:15, NIV

Laban was fair to Jacob to have asked him to name his wages so he would not work for him free of charge. Jacob took the opportunity to ask Laban to allow him marry Rachel. Though Jacob knew that Leah was the elder, his eye for beautiful things made him prefer the younger to the elder. But just when he thought he had got what he wanted, slaving for seven years to get it, Jacob was outsmarted by Laban who told him that it was against the custom to give the younger daughter in marriage before the elder. The deceiver was also deceived. It felt bitter to taste of the same pill he had earlier given to his brother Esau. This time, Laban did not give Jacob a fair deal. Though embittered, Jacob was willing to work for another seven years to marry the woman o his dream.

Though the different episodes of Jacob\'s dealings with Laban may not be a model for us today, in all we see God working through the changing scenes, to accomplish His will for the generation of Israel and the world at large. God used Laban to teach Jacob life lessons that he had failed to learn earlier. God offered him opportunities to undergo discipline and to deal with his weaknesses in order to be fit for God\'s use. Jacob also learnt a lesson in waiting. Jacob\'s commitment to work and his determination to get what he wanted in spite of the odds could inspire us to be diligent in whatever our hands find to do, and to expect ultimately that our rewards come from God; and that we must do everything to His glory.

Wisdom : You can defy odds to become who God has destined you to be.

LEAH GIVES BIRTH TO FOUR SONS

Golden Text: When the LORD saw that Leah was not loved, He enabled her to conceive, but Rachel remained childless. Genesis 29:31, NIV

Can you imagine how Leah must have felt when she discovered that she was not loved by the man she was forced to marry? Imagine her state of mind as Jacob complained to Laban that this was not whom he worked for seven years to get. She must have been heart-broken to discover that after all, Jacob was willing to work for another seven years to marry Rachel, whom he preferred above her. In the midst of so much un-love, the Lord looked to Leah with favour and enabled her to conceive while Rachel remained childless. Leah gave birth to her first born and called him Reuben, “...for she said, \'It is because the Lord has seen my misery. Surely my husband will love me now\'” (v. 32). She conceived again and gave birth to Simeon with this testimony: “Because the Lord heard that I am not loved, he gave me this one too.” (v. 33) With her third son Levi, she believed that “Now at last my husband will become attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.” (v. 34). Leah\'s fourth son was Judah of whom she said, “this time I will praise the Lord.” It is interesting to note that Judah became the progenitor of our Lord Jesus Christ who is rightly called the Lion of the Tribe of Judah.

God is willing to showcase His glory in the life of the despised ones of this world. Mary rightly said about God: “He has put down the mighty from their thrones, And exalted the lowly. He has filled the hungry with good things, And the rich He has sent away empty” (Luke 1:52-53). Are you forsaken by those you expect to love you? Jesus\' love offers you hope and promise of a fulfilled life.

THE GOD OF JACOB BRINGS VICTORY

Golden Text: May the LORD answer you when you are in distress; may the name of the God of Jacob protect you. Psalm 20:1, NIV

In the African tradition, the authority of a king is strengthened by his peaceful reign, provisions for his people\'s needs and his ability to defend them in times of war. Several warriors have promised to protect their people but have failed when the battle became fiercer that they had imagined. Those who promised to protect the people then became casualties of war themselves, in which case victory becomes a mirage. Charms will always fail, but those who put their trust in God will always prevail over all their challenges.

This psalm presents to us God, a very sure help in times of need; a sure shelter from the rains and One who is able to defend in stormy days. God answers when we call on Him in distress. He protects us, sends us help and grants us support, if only we put our trust in Him. The Bible discourages having trust in mortal men and their crafts. Jeremiah 17:5 says, "Cursed is the one who trusts in man, who depends on flesh for his strength and whose heart turns away from the Lord." Each time we pray for victory, we must never forget the capacity of the One we are calling upon. Regardless of the enormity or intensity of the battle, we should always rely on the One who has never failed to bring victory. His victory is not just a record that any human can surpass. It is a record that is established for eternity. Jesus has won the battle between life and death, good and evil. His name is synonymous with His presence and power. He has never failed and will never fail.

The household of Laban quickly forgot all Jacob\'s efforts to prosper their family. So, Laban\'s sons became envious of Jacob\'s success (v. 1). Laban also had the same disposition towards him (v. 2). Though, he was his son-in-law, he seemed he had overstayed and he was in no wise different from a stranger and supplanter in Laban\'s house. Wherever there is envy, malicious acts are never wanting.

In the midst of the coldness and jealousy of Laban and his sons, the Lord spoke to Jacob to go back to his fatherland (v. 3). But instead of following through with God\'s promise to protect and to inform Laban of his willingness to leave with his family, Jacob sneaked out on Laban, running away with his wives, children and livestock. He connived with his wives, appealed to their emotions, and he succeeded in winning them to his side (v. 15). Jacob was right to have left as God had commanded but he was wrong to have left secretly. He did the right thing the wrong way.

We need courage to do the right thing in the right way, even in the midst of hostilities. That others are doing the wrong thing is not an excuse for us to join the throng and begin to do things the way God does not approve. Sometimes, people respond to hostilities, whether in the neighbourhood or workplace with all kinds of scheming. It is like allowing themselves to be dragged in the mud. With God on our side, we can overcome any adversity and be who God wants us to be. But we must be determined to live above board, so that our testimony will not be tainted.

JACOB AND LABAN MAKE PEACE

Text: Genesis 31:43-50

Golden Text: Come now, let\'s make a covenant, you and I, and let it serve as a witness between us. Genesis 31:44, NIV

Laban must have been enraged by Jacob\'s actions when he learnt three days after that Jacob had fled. Immediately, he ran after Jacob, perhaps with evil intent, but his rage must have been doused by the warning he received from God in a dream not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad (v. 24). He caught up with Jacob after seven days and sought every avenue to make peace with him. Jacob and Laban entered into a covenant. With this covenant, Jacob was now free to return to the land of his inheritance with all that the Lord has blessed him with.

In our daily relationships with others conflict is inevitable but what we make of the conflict matters. Jesus taught us to cultivate a forgiving spirit (Matthew 6:12) and to never hold on to any offence as such will hinder our prayers from being answered. As Laban initiated the peace solution to the rivalry he created with Jacob, so should we be good examples of peacemakers. It seemed Laban realised the unfortunate consequences that came as a result of deceiving Jacob to marry Leah, which resulted in polygamy. Thus, he cautioned Jacob not to increase his problems by marrying more wives (v. 50). We should sue for peace at all times, and guard against rancour which can make life unbearable for those involved.

The Pharisees and Sadducees were often out to tempt Jesus, in order to trap Him with His words. But Jesus always lived above their schemes. On one occasion, a lawyer asked him a question to tempt Him. He wanted to know which is the greatest commandment in the law (v. 36). As a reply to this question, Jesus gave a summary of the whole law. Jesus said to him, “\'Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind.\' This is the first and greatest commandment. And the second is like it: \'Love your neighbor as yourself.\' All the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments.” (vv. 37-40) By this response, Jesus established that love is the whole essence of the law – love for God and fellow humans. The spirit of all the commandments given to the Israelites is the spirit of love. If only they could love God wholeheartedly and others as themselves. Many of them struggle to keep the law using all kinds of legalism because true love for God and others was lacking.

God\'s expectation from us today is still to love. Loving God and loving others are two sides of a coin. You cannot choose one and leave out the other. Love for God is best demonstrated toward fellow human beings. Apostle John says we cannot claim to love God who we cannot see when we find it difficult to love people that we can see (1 John 4:20). Love towards one another springs from the love of God as its source. Thomas a\' Kempis said, “Whoever loves much, does much.” When we love God genuinely, our love for Him will be seen in actions of obedience to His words. We would not be compelled to obey Him. Rather, we would do it as an act of devotion.

title: treat your neighbours justly
message:
NOVEMBER 27, Tuesday

BH 438: Make Me a Channel of Blessing

RBT: I John 1-3

TREAT YOUR NEIGHBOURS JUSTLY

Text: Leviticus 19:13-18

Golden Text: Do not pervert justice; do not show partiality to the poor or favoritism to the great, but judge your neighbor fairly. Leviticus 19:15, NIV

Sometime ago, a black teenager from Chicago visited relatives in Mississippi. Because the boy tried to talk to a white woman, two white men brutally murdered him. The two men were declared not guilty by an all-white, male jury. Many years later, the two men confessed to the crime in a magazine article. Following the verdict, the teenager\'s mother said, “Two months ago I had a nice apartment in Chicago. I had a good job. I had a son. When something happened to Negroes in the South, I said, \'That\'s their business, not mine.\' Now I know how wrong I was. The murder of my son has shown me that what happens to any of us, anywhere in the world, had better be the business of us all.”

Today\'s text points our focus to the fact that whatever happens to our neighbour is our business. Our neighbours include those who work for us (v. 13), the less-privileged, (v. 14), our colleagues at the workplace, our church members and all others who have a need. Treating them fairly includes not withholding whatever is due to them, regarding them in honour, not speaking ill of them, and forgiving them when they wrong us. In other words, we should treat them as we would like to be treated.

In a world of individualism where people are only concerned for themselves and their families, Christians are called to be sensitive to the needs of their neighbours and to treat them justly. We should be respectful to all; speak up against injustice meted to anyone; be concerned about others\' suffering and be willing to help others in the name of the Lord.

Wisdom : Treat others as you will like to be treated.

Food for Thought : If you were to evaluate your attitude to people, how would you describe it?

Follow-up Action : Resolve to treat everyone respectfully from today.

Prayer : Almighty God, I receive grace to let go of all resentments in my heart and to express the love of God in all my relationships.

BH 443: In Christ There Is No East or West

RBT: Deuteronomy 20-22

FULFILLING THE ROYAL LAW

Text: James 2:8-13

Golden Text: If you really keep the royal law found in Scripture, “Love your neighbour as yourself,” you are doing right. James 2:8, NIV

The sin of favouritism or partiality is the subject of our text today. Favouritism is the act of treating one person or a group of people better than the others in an unfair way. It manifests itself in various ways. Sometimes, we treat others better because of the favour we receive from them. Sometimes, we are victims of partiality and sometimes we benefit from it. Each time we benefit from it we feel so good but whenever the table turns against us, we condemn it. To overcome the pains of favouritism, we must uphold the royal law of love.

James\' admonition is that everyone deserves to be well regarded. Favouritism is condemned in the Scriptures in strong terms: one who shows favouritism is considered a law breaker (v. 9). Jesus demonstrated love in dealing with people without bias. Therefore, relationships must be built on fair treatment of others as oneself. Love becomes the royal law through which all human conducts are monitored. It becomes the guiding principle upon which human relationships are established. Apostle Paul presented it as the most important of all Christian graces and the very heart of Christian ethics. The Bible tells us that discrimination and faith are incompatible. Accept others the way they are and treat everyone impartially.

Wisdom : Each time you show favouritism , it is always at someone\'s expense.

Food for Thought : Do I treat everyone equally?

Follow-up Action : Eschew favouritism in your dealings with others.

RBT: Nehemiah 1-4

DON'T FORGET THE LORD

Text: Deuteronomy 6:10-15

Golden Text: Be careful that you do not forget the LORD, who brought you out of Egypt,out of the land of slavery.Deuteronomy6:12,NIV

When some people are in desperate situations in life, they make promises but once their situations get better, they forget to fulfil their promises. A story was told of a little boy, whose parents gave a bowl of ice cream. His parents then asked the boy to share out of his ice cream. The boy refused to share as he held on tight to the bowl. Afterward, the boy missed his steps, slipped and the bowl of ice cream fell into the sand. He wept bitterly as he pressurised his parents to buy him another bowl of ice cream. This is the way we sometimes treat God! Israel was about settling down into God\'s inheritance for them. Then God forewarned them against the sin of forgetfulness and running after other gods. He did not want them to overlook any act of His kindness. God asked them to always remember Him. He provided all they needed throughout their journey and He freely settled them.

It is easy to seek God when we want Him to better our lot. But the true test of our devotion becomes obvious after we have got what we want. When we become comfortable and we have everything we need – sound health, a fat bank account, a growing business, wonderful relationships and our minds are at rest - forgetting God could be easy. Because prosperity can lead to complacency, God is warning us today not to forget Him when we become satisfied.

Wisdom : When you eat and are satisfied, do not forget God.

Golden Text: Do what is right and good in the Lord\'s sight, so that it may go well with you and you may go in and take over the good land that the Lord promised on oath to your forefathers. Deuteronomy 6:18, NIV

The complexities and complications of modern life are making it difficult for many people to do the right thing. In our society, some right values that used to be considered sacrosanct are now being questioned and shoved aside. Some would even say that there is no right or wrong, it depends on the way you view it. How can Christians live to please God in such a society?

Today\'s text points our attention to the truth that God expects us to good and right. Though societal values change, God\'s standard does not change with time. Though many are finding it difficult to know what is right, and others who know it are not doing it; we are called to be models of what is good and right by God\'s standard in the Scriptures. As we seek God\'s blessing, we should not neglect obedience to His commands which must come first for Him to bless us. Each time we disobey God, we put our health at risk and God\'s patience to test. Also, we are giving the Devil a chance to get at us. There is no obedience if there is no fear of God. Obedience to God strengthens the bond of unity within the family, and makes the society a better place.

title: fear the lord and live rightly
message:
DECEMBER 1 Saturday

BH 239: His Way With Thee

RBT: Ecclesiastes 11-12

FEAR THE LORD AND LIVE RIGHTLY

Text: Deuteronomy 6:20-25

Golden Text: And the LORD commanded us to do all these statutes, to fear the LORD our God, for our good always, that he might preserve us alive, as it is at this day. Deuteronomy 6:24

History is a gap-bridger. It connects the present generation to events in the past which are pivotal to their living now as it would also help the way they view the future. It is a tragedy for a people\'s history to be lost because an important part of what makes them a people s taken away.

Moses urged the Israelites to keep a history of God\'s dealings with them. They were to keep the statutes, testimonies and judgments which the Lord had commanded them. When generations to come would ask them why they were doing so, they were then to tell them the history of how God delivered them with a mighty hand from slavery in Egypt; how he afflicted Pharaoh and his household because he would not let them go; and how the Lord brought them to their Promise Land. In doing this, they would teach generations to come the fear of God and righteousness.

We have a rich history in the Word of God to pass on to generations after us. And we must not fail to fulfil this responsibility for the Christian faith to continue after our generation might have gone. If we must do it well, then we must familiarise ourselves with this history, be well grounded in it and live our lives by it. The greatest history the younger generation can have is the testimony of a righteous life which upholds biblical values even in the face of opposition. Teaching them the Word of God is great, but living in the fear of God is greater and it helps them to better grasp the history. How is your own relationship with God? Do you fear the Lord and live rightly? Can God count on you to pass on faith to the next generation?

Wisdom : Those who fear God will be kept safe.

Food for Thought : What do you think would become of the world, if everyone lives and behaves like you?

THE LORD ALONE IS GOD

Text: Deuteronomy 6:1-9

Golden Text: Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God, the LORD is one. Deuteronomy 6:4

A renown young entrepreneur committed suicide. After the event, his wife said, “my husband\'s business wasn\'t just a job; it was his identity, his nationality, his religion. He put the whole of his life into it and was successful in it. But everything had gone sour the moment he killed himself.” Though being fully committed to work and other things that we do is highly commendable, but none of these things are qualified to take the centre of our lives. Today\'s passage stresses the truth that God alone should be the Lord of our lives. Whatever else we do that takes the place of God in our lives is another god. The Lord commanded the Israelites to teach His commandments, statutes and judgment in the land they were about to possess. They should not only teach them; they should do them. The core of the commandments is that God is one and they must love Him with their whole being. In exhibiting their love for God, they must keep His words in their hearts, teach them to their children, talk about God\'s Word as they sit and walk along the way; as they lie down and rise up. They shall bind them upon their hearts and their eyes, and write them upon the posts of their houses and gates.

In a world filled with many options for living, the value making everything we do to be about God is fading away. Many times, we only add God to many several options that we have, when He should take the core of our lives. Whatever you do and whoever you are, always remember that the Lord owns you, and He should be considered first in whatever you do or don\'t do.

We are created for relationships – relationship with God and fellow human beings. Our vertical relationship with God is a catalyst for our horizontal relationship with others. The Lord stated agin to the Israelites that He is their God and they must have no other gods after Him. God created us with the innate ability to look for an object of worship; that is why he stated categorically to them that they must not have any graven image or idols which they would worship except Him alone. Because God created us, He deserves to be the only focus of our worship.

Today, many things have become gods in the lives of people ; they include money, fame, work, pleasure and so on. Though these are not in themselves evil, they can become evil and gods when we concentrate too much on them for personal identity, meaning and security. When our lives are being controlled by them, they become our masters. If we want to establish a relationship with God, we must learn to reverence His name and worship Him in sincerity of hearts. RULES ON PEOPLE RELATING TO PEOPLE

Text: Exodus 20:12-17

Golden Text: “You shall not covet your neighbour\'s house. You shall not covet your neighbour\'s wife, or his manservant or maidservant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbour.” Exodus 20:17

After our relationship with God comes our relationship with people. Managing our human relationship is important because we cannot live in isolation in this world. God created us to live in the midst of others, and for us to fulfil our purpose for living, we must be mindful of what it takes to have good relationships. The first law about relating with people goes to the children, who are commanded to honour their father and mother. This law comes with a promise of long life for those who obey it. The commandment not to steal, kill, commit adultery, bear false witness or covet what belongs to others, shows that God is concerned about the way treat others and the effect our actions have on them. And we must be concerned too. Children who disobey their parent without thought are putting themselves up against God who gave this commandment.

Respecting authority helps to build strong family ties and helps foster peace. Honouring one\'s parents includes speaking well of them and politely to them, and acting in a way that shows courtesy and respect. Children must place value on the words of their parents and obey them as unto the Lord. When parents/children\'s relationship is solidly grounded, a good generation would emerge that would abstain from committing murder (v.13), adultery (v.14), stealing (v.15) or even bearing false witnesses against their neighbours (v. 16). God demands us to be honest in our private and public dealings. Also, He wants us to have regard for people\'s properties.

Joshua recognised that his death was imminent. He therefore charged the people of Israel as to how they would live in the Promise Land. title: rescued from egypt, settled in canaan

RESCUED FROM EGYPT, SETTLED IN CANAAN

Text: Joshua 24:4-12

Golden Text: And I [God] brought you into the land of the Amorites, which dwelt on the other side of Jordan; and they fought with you: and I gave them into your hand, that ye might possess their land; and I destroyed them from before you. Joshua 24:8

As part of his valedictory speech to the people, Joshua recalled how God delivered Israel, beginning with God\'s calling of the people in Abraham and His protection and leading of the patriarchs, Isaac and Jacob. He listed all that the Lord had done for them from Egypt to Canaan; how afflicted the Egyptians and brought the Israelites out of Egypt; how He disgraced the Egyptians who pursued them with chariots and horsemen as far as to the Red Sea; how He paved way for the Israelites to walk on dry ground while the sea covered up the Egyptians. God gave the Amorites who fought against them into their hands and made them to possess their land. When Balak, the king of Moab sent Balaam to put a curse on the Israelites, God did not listen, so Balaam blessed Israel again and again and God delivered them out of the hand of Barak, king of Moab.

The implication of this historic sermon of God\'s mercies is for them to remember where the Lord had brought them from and commit themselves to serving Him wholeheartedly. For us, it is an exhortation to fear and serve God, for His favour. God gave us Jesus Christ to rescue us from bondage, and we are expected to reciprocate. Spend some time today to teach your children the historic experiences of your walk with God.

Wisdom : A wise man always ascribes his acievements to God.

Food for Thought : How will you appreciate the mercies of God over your life?

Follow-up Action : Determine to reciprocate what God has done in your life and family by dedicating yourself to His service.

title: we promise to serve god

BH 386: O Jesus I Have Promised

WE PROMISE TO SERVE GOD

Text: Joshua 24:16-21

Golden Text: And the people said unto Joshua, Nay; but we will serve the LORD. Joshua 24:21

Life is about choices and the choices we make in life will either make or mar us. Sometimes, we are torn between making a hard choice or taking the easy way out. At such times, we need courage to choose right. Joshua gave the Israelites opportunity to make their choice. He put the matter plainly before them and asked them to choose. Though Joshua had made his own choice: “… But as for me and my household, we will serve the Lord” (v. 15); he would not force his choice on the people. But he helped them to see the options they have as well as the consequences of each choice. Then, the people made a choice, as they echoed “No! We will serve the Lord”.

The greatest choice any one alive can make is to serve God. The promise to serve God may be easy, but the courage to follow through is not easy. When you are faced with either serving God and losing your rights or putting God aside and doing what people expect of you so you can have some goodies; it takes courage to stand by your decision to serve God. When you are pressured to fit into the world\'s standard so as to belong, it takes courage to stand alone. The choice to serve God is a lifetime thing; it is not like clothes that we can wear and take off at will, but something that must identify us whether it rains or shines. Choosing to stand by your promise to serve Christ may be demanding, but it is a choice you will never regret making.

Wisdom : A choice to serve God is the most valuable decision a wise person can make in life.

Food for Thought : Are you still firmly standing by your choice to serve Christ.

title: covenant with god confirmed

COVENANT WITH GOD CONFIRMED

Text: Joshua 24:25-28

Golden Text: And Joshua said unto all the people, Behold, this stone shall be a witness unto us; it shall be therefore a witness unto you, lest you deny your God. Joshua 24:27

Covenant is a promise taken farther with a more serious agreement binding on the parties involved. After the people had promised to serve God, Joshua brought them to a point where they were willing to enter into a covenant with God to serve Him as they have promised. Rather than scare us away from doing what we have promised, covenants should strengthen us and give us a sense of commitment to do as we have promised. As a memorial to the great event, Joshua wrote the words of the people\'s promise in the book of the law, took a great stone and set it up under an oak that is by the sanctuary of the Lord. The stone is to serve as a witness and a remembrance to the people to keep their commitment to God alone.

Today, God has made a final provision for a covenant relationship between humans and Him by giving us the Lord Jesus to die for our sins. By accepting Jesus, we initiate the process of relating with God as children and being empowered to serve Him committedly. The Scripture ascertains that the covenant of which Jesus is the mediator is superior and holds better promises (Hebrews 8:6). In Him we receive grace to say no to ungodliness and live according to God\'s righteous demands.

Wisdom : Wise people hold on to the covenants they make.

Food for Thought : Take a paper and a pen and write down promises, vows and covenants you have made.

Follow-up Action : Pray , make a commitment first, to ask for forgiveness, then take positive steps to redeem them.

title: choose to love and serve god
message:

BH 389: O Happy Day

CHOOSE TO LOVE AND SERVE GOD

Text: Joshua 24:1-3, 13-15, 21-24

Golden Text: And the people said unto Joshua, ‘The LORD our God will we serve, and his voice will we obey.’ Joshua 24:24

There comes a time in everyone\'s life when one has to choose who to serve; when one chooses who to believe in. As Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel in Shechem – their elders, leaders, judges and officers, he put it to them to choose whom they would love and serve. The history of God\'s dealings with Israel since the day the people left Egypt till this time was a testimony of God\'s love for them. Joshua therefore charged them to reciprocate this love, and make a commitment to serve God. He charged them to fear God, serve Him in sincerity and truth and put away the gods their fathers served beyond the River and in Egypt.

We, like Israel, must decide to love and serve God. A commitment to love God is a commitment to serve Him and to do away with whatever takes His place in our hearts. Whatever you desire more than God has replaced Him in your life. It could be revenge, anger, hatred, a new car, your job or your money. Love for God increases our desire to know Him more in Bible study, prayer, fellowship with other believers, and living a life that does not misrepresent Him to people. Your love for Him also spur you to obedience even when it seems difficult. You can\'t sit on the fence; it is either you love God or you don\'t.

When we are confronted by tribulation, distress, persecution, nakedness, peril, sword or other challenges of life, what do we do? Where do we run to? This passage reaffirms God\'s profound love for His people and that no matter what happens to us, we can always trust in God\'s love. Suffering should not separate us from God\'s love; rather, it should help us to identify with Him more and allow His love to reach us and heal us. The hardships we face may make us afraid but they should not take us away from God. Jesus’death on the cross for our sake is a proof of His unconquerable love. AN ANSWER IN TIME OF TROUBLE

Golden Text: In the day of my trouble I will call to you, for you will answer me. Psalm 86:7

An emergency services operator in the US was once accused of intentionally disconnecting distress calls while on her shift. The woman was seen sighing and hanging up when someone called to report a robbery, dangerous driving and homicide. Her supervisor noticed her call logs were filled with short conversations lasting around 20 seconds or less. When she was questioned by investigators as to why she was disconnecting the calls, she said she “did not want to talk to anyone at that time”. Even a 911 officer could be distressed. It is then comforting to note that God does not disconnect our calls anytime we call Him. He is above all situations, cannot be moved by them, and that is why He is always ready to listen to us. The psalmist expresed an assured trust in God to answer him in the day of trouble. Troubles are part of the fallen world, and as much as we would like to be trouble-free all the time, we discover that they are inevitable. The psalmist pleaded earnestly with God to answer him, guard his life, save him, have mercy on him, bring joy to him and hear his prayer. God\'s goodness is evident in that He is forgiving and good, abounding in love to all who call on Him. The Scripture says, “Those who trust in the LORD are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken but endures forever.” (Psalm 125:1) Our trouble or pain could be so great, but we should never let them prevent us from crying out to God like the psalmist. And when we feel there is no relief in sight, all we can do is to acknowledge the greatness of God and wait for better days ahead. The conviction that God answers prayer will sustain us in such difficult times.

message:

BH 2: Love Divine

RBT: Nehemiah 10-13

ACTS OF GOD'S STEADFAST LOVE

Text: Nehemiah 9:16-21

Golden Text: But you are a forgiving God, gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and abounding in love. Nehemiah 9:17

Dan gave his life to Christ at the age of 17. At 18, he got admission to a university. But when he came back home a year after, on holiday, his parents saw a different person. His heart had grown cold towards people, and towards spiritual things. His parents became unhappy and tried to talk to him about coming back to God, all to no avail. Then, his life began to fall apart. He had problems at school that almost got him expelled. In the process, his friend died. He became so afraid, and nothing seemed to help him overcome this feeling. Then a boy met him and told him that God could help him out of his trouble. He fought the thought of going back to the God he had once forsaken, but he eventually yielded and surrendered to God.

Dan\'s story reminds us of Israel\'s history with God. Nehemiah narrates how the nation responded to all that God did for her by refusing to bow to His authority or obey His will. At Kadesh-Barnea, the people took laws into their hands by appointing a leader to take them backto Egypt (v. 17; Numbers 14:1-5); and when Moses was on the mountain with God, they made and worshipped idol (v. 18; Exodus 33:1). God led them by the cloud and fire,taught them the word, provided them with the necessities of life, and gave them victory over their enemies.Inspite of their shortcomings,Godstill had great compassion on them and did not abandon them in the desert because He is a God who forgives, gracious and compassionate,slow to anger and abounding in love.

These attributes of God should encourage us to draw near to Him – even after we might have wandered away. When we truly forsake our rebellious ways and turn back to God, He is always willing to welcome us back home.

Wisdom : God\'s children reciprocate good deeds.

GOD ABOUNDS IN STEADFAST LOVE

Text: Exodus 34:1-7

Golden Text: And the LORD passed by before him, and proclaimed, The LORD, The LORD God, merciful and gracious, longsuffering, and abundant in goodness and truth. Exodus 34:6

This was the second time Moses would be meeting God on the mountain to collect the tablets containing the laws. Before now, Moses had gone to Mount Sinai, where God gave him two tablets of the testimony, the tablets of stone inscribed by the finger of God. But as Moses was coming down from the mountain, he saw that the Israelites had made for themselves a golden calf and worshipped it. Then his anger burnt within him and he threw the tablets out of his hand, breaking it into pieces at the foot of the mountain. In today\'s text, The Lord ordered Moses to prepare two new tablets; this meant he was going to replace the tablets that Moses had broken. God said to Moses, "Chisel out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on them the words that were on the first one, which you broke." So Moses did as the Lord had commanded him. When he got up the mountain with the two tablets in his hands, the Lord came down in the cloud and stood there with him and proclaimed His name. God proclaimed His attribute (vv. 5-7) as One who abounds in steadfast love. Moses repeated these words to God at Kadesh-Barnea (Numbers 14:17-19), the Jews used them in Nehemiah\'s days (Nehemiah 9:17-18) and Jonah quoted them when he expressed his displeasure outside Nineveh (Jonah 4:1-2).

God still remains the same today. His love for you is constant. Even when you wander away, He waits for you like a father longs for his lost child. Embrace the love of God in Christ, and become a partaker of the wonderful things He has in store for those who reciprocate His love.

Wisdom : God is loving but He punishes sin.

GOD FORGIVES AND LOVES PEOPLE

Text: Numbers 14:13-20

Golden Text: In accordance with your great love, forgive the sin of these people, just as you have pardoned them from the time they left Egypt until now. Numbers 14:19

For the second time God offered to make a new nation out of Moses and completely destroy the Jewish people (Numbers 14:11), but Moses refused. Moses reasoned with God and argued: Firstly, that His glory would be tarnished if Israel were destroyed. Moses said, “If you put these people to death all at once, the nations who have heard this report about you would say, \'The LORD was not able to bring these people into the land he promised them on oath; so he slaughtered them in the desert.\'” (vv. 15-16) Secondly, Moses argued because of the covenant God had made with the patriarchs years before (v. 16). The Lord had promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob that He would give them the land, and He could not go back on His word (Genesis 13:17; 15:7-12; 28:13; 35:12). Moses\' third argument was on the character of God (Numbers 14:17-18; Exodus 34:6-7). He reminded God of His promise saying, “Now may the Lord\'s strength be displayed, just as you have declared: The LORD is slow to anger, abounding in love and forgiving sin and rebellion ....\' He further challenged God that in accordance with His great love, He should forgive the sin of Israelites just as He had pardoned them since they left Egypt until then. And the LORD replied, “I have forgiven them, as you asked.”

For His benefits toward us, for the forgiveness of our sins, healing of all our diseases, redemption of our lives from the pit, His love and compassion for us, the satisfaction of our desires with good things and the deliverance from oppression, the psalmist calls on us to render praises to God. The Lord works righteousness and justice for the oppressed, He is compassionate and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in love, He does not harbour His anger forever or repay us according to our iniquities.

Like the nation of Israel, we are blessed by the Lord and, are therefore, under obligation to express our praise and thanksgiving to Him. Jehovah is our righteous deliverer (v.6), not only when He rescues us from our troubles, but also in His provisions and divine guidance (v. 7), leading us day by day through His Word and His servants. In verses 21-22, the psalmist calls on all to praise the Lord the angels, all His heavenly hosts and all His works everywhere in His dominion.

God makes everything beautiful in His time. Zechariah (Jehovah has remembered) and Elizabeth (God is my oath) were a godly couple who both belonged to the priestly lineage. Inspite of their godliness, they were childless, yet Zechariah and Elizabeth faithfully obeyed the word of God and lived blamelessly. God often speaks to His people and calls them while they are busy doing their daily tasks. When we get busy for God, we experience His divine guidance.

Golden Text: And all they that heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, What manner of child shall this be! And the hand of the Lord was with him.” Luke 1:66

Many people make promises, but not many keep their promises. People give excuses for not fulfilling their word but this is not so with God. God is a covenant-keeping God; His words are yea and amen. Matthew 1:16 and 18 make it clear that the birth of Jesus Christ was different from that of any other Jewish boy named in the genealogy. Matthew points out that Joseph did not “beget” Jesus Christ; rather, Joseph was the “husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ”. Jesus was born of an earthly mother without the need of an earthly father (the doctrine of the virgin birth).

If a woman who is betrothed to a man becomes pregnant for an unknown person, it is considered adultery (Deuteronomy 22:13- 21). But this was not the case with Mary. God spoke to Joseph in his dream about the unusual event and instructed him to take Mary in as his wife.

Joseph\'s obedience is exemplary and worthy of emulation. In the midst of his confusion about Mary\'s pregnancy, while he was planning to secretly leave her, so she would not be disgraced, God spoke to him. And he immediately obeyed God. The response of the people around them was something to contend with, but all of that did not matter to him any more because God had spoken. Like Joseph, Christians are to learn to listen and act in line with God\'s will, even when it goes contrary to norms.

Wisdom : The wise do not argue with God.

title: anna speaks of the child jesus

BH 136: Jesus Thou Joy of Loving Hearts

ANNA SPEAKS OF THE CHILD JESUS

Text: Luke 2:36-38

Golden Text: Coming up to them at that very moment, she gave thanks to God and spoke about the child to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem. Luke 2:38

After Simeon had finished praising God for bringing His word to pass by sending Jesus for the consolation of Israel, the Bible records that there was also a prophetess, whose name was Anna, in the temple. The name Anna means “Grace”. Anna was a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel, from the tribe of Asher. She lost her husband seven years after marriage. As a widow, she never left the temple but worshipped night and day, fasting and praying (v.37b). She remained in the temple, waiting for the appearing of God\'s promised Messiah. Anna came up just as Simeon was praising the Lord for the Jesus, so she joined in the song. But Anna did much more than singing; she also spread the good news among the other faithful members of the \'remnant\' who were waiting for the redemption of Israel. The Bible records that she came up to them at that very moment, gave thanks to God and spoke about the child to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem.

Anna\'s words were a source of encouragement to Mary and Joseph as well as people around. As believers God has given us the responsibility to be His voice to those who are weary and to speak words of hope to those who are dejected. As you go out today, speak about Jesus to someone, and tell them that they can be saved if they put their faith in Him.

\'Happy and delighted to welcome our baby girl at 3:32pm today\' was what a father tweeted to announce the birth of their baby recently. The birth of a baby always brings joyous celebration as people rejoice at the arrival of a new addition to the family and the world at large.

And the first set of people to be given the good news were the shepherds. While the shepherds keep watch over their flock at night, the angel of the Lord appeared to them and told them of the birth of the Saviour in the city of David. Though the angel\'s visit brought fear in the shepherds, their fear melted away as the angel told them of the miracle birth of the Saviour of the world that was lying in a manger.

Golden Text: You will be with child and give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus. Luke 1:31

The purpose of God for Jesus was clear from the beginning – to save the people from their sins. Mary and Joseph may have thought that they were alone in this, and that what God was doing was not known to many. But the events that followed after Mary conceived and when the child was eventually born proved otherwise. After Mary\'s days of purification were over, they took the child to Jerusalem to present Him to God as was the custom. There they met people whom the Lord had spoken to about Jesus who came to confirm what God was doing. Though the Bible does not specifically refer to Simeon as a prophet, his words qualified him as one. The Holy Spirit had revealed to him that he would not see death before he had seen Christ. He was led of the Spirit to the temple to meet Christ whom he had long awaited. Then he took the baby into his arms, blessed God and said, “Sovereign Lord, as you have promised, you now dismiss your servant in peace. For my eyes have seen your salvation, ... a light for revelation to the Gentiles and for glory to your people Israel” (vv. 29-32).

Many things happen around Jesus\' birth that look like coincidences, but they are actually God- incidences. The lesson for us today is that Jesus is real – His birth, ministry, death and resurrection. And one major event about Him that also sure is that he is coming back again. Are you prepared to meet Him? Have you made Him the Saviour of your life?

LIVE BY FAITH

Text: Habakkuk 1:2-4; 2:1-4

Golden Text: Behold, his soul which is lifted up is not upright in him: but the just shall live by faith. Habakkuk 2:4

Habakkuk\'s vocabulary in this chapter indicates that things and times were difficult and as well dangerous. Habakkuk prayed that God would do something about the violence, strife, and injustice in the land, but God did not seem to respond as desired. As the prophet prayed about the wickedness in the land, he became more and more burdened and wondered why God seemed to be indifferent to the plight of the people. He said, \'How long, O LORD, must I call for help, but you do not listen? Or cry out to you, "Violence!" but you do not save? Why do you make me look at injustice? Why do you tolerate wrong?\' (vv. 2-3). In chapter 2:1-4, the prophet saw himself as a watchman of the walls of Jerusalem, waiting for a message from God that he could share with the people. "I will stand at my watch and station myself on the ramparts; I will look to see what he will say to me, and what answer I am to give to this complaint." (v. 1)

In a world ravaged by evil when it sometimes seems that God would not punish evil doers; we can be depressed especially when we suffer the effect of their wickedness. But as God told Habakkuk, we need to continue living by faith. As we wait on God, seek His face and interceed on behalf of our land, we also have · the responsibility to keep faith. We must refuse to let go of our belief in God perhaps because we feel He is silent. The just shall live by faith.

Wisdom : Without faith it is impossible to please the Lord.

REWARDS FOR HOSPITALITY

Text: Matthew 10:40-42

Golden Text: He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me. Matthew 10:40

Helping people especially strangers is becoming more scary in today\'s world. People rarely listen to the call for help of others who they barely know. For fear of being conned, modern people, even believers, are gradually scraping hospitality. Jesus in today\'s passage, encourages us to show hospitality to people in His name. He told His disciples that whoever received them recieved Him. “And if anyone gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is my disciple, I tell you the truth, he will certainly not lose his reward.” (v. 42). For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you." (Luke 6:38) Today\'s text summarises the message that we can be a blessing to others with our lives, resources and spiritual gifts or talents. Some people will welcome us and our kindness and as such be blessed. "Anyone who receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet\'s reward, and anyone who receives a righteous man because he is a righteous man will receive a righteous man\'s reward." title: welcoming children
message:

BH 512: Jesus Loves Me

RBT: Deuteronomy 32-34

WELCOMING CHILDREN

Text: Mark 9:33-37

Golden Text:Whosoever shall receive one of such children in my name, receives me; and whosoever shall receive me, receives not me, but him that sent me. Mark 9:37

After the disciples had heard what Jesus said about His own suffering and death, one would think they would have forgotten their own selfish plans and concentrate on Him. Jesus then set a child before them and explained that the way to be first is to be last and the way to be last is to be the servant of all. The innocent child is an example of submission and humility. A child knows he is a child and acts like a child and that is his secret of attracting love and care. A child who tries to impress people by acting like an adult does not get the same attention. In like manner, we should not regard ourselves as better than or more superior to others. We should be humble in spite of our achievements in life. Humility is one of the attributes of a true child of God. The Scripture admonishes us in Philippians 2:3-4 that we should do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit, but in humility consider others better than ourselves. Each of us should look not only to our own interests, but also to the interests of others.

True humility means knowing yourself, accepting yourself, being yourself and giving of yourself for others. If we have the heart of a child, we will have little difficulty being servants, and if we have the attitude of servants, we will welcome children as representatives of Jesus Christ and the Father.

Wisdom : Great people are humble.

Food for Thought : To be first is to be last and to be last is to be a servant of all.

Follow-up Action : Make effort today to learn the attitudes of a child.

WAIT, THE LORD WILL COME

Text: 1Thess. 4:13-18

Golden Text: Then we which are alive and remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air: and so shall we ever be with the Lord. 1 Thessalonians 4:17

How can mortal man penetrate beyond the grave and find assurance and peace for his own heart? From the Old Testament days till the present, humankind have tried to solve the riddle of death and life after death. Philosophers have wrestled with the question of immortality. Spiritists have tried to communicate with those who have gone to the great beyond. In our contemporaryworld, scientists have investigated the experiences of people who claimed to have died and returned to life again. They have also studied occult phenomena, hoping to find a clue to the mystery of life after death.

Paul solved the problem when he wrote, “For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord, that we which are alive and remain unto the coming of the Lord shall not prevent them which are asleep. For the Lord himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trump of God: and the dead in Christ shall rise first.” (vv. 15-16) We must keep in mind that God\'s revelation climaxed in the coming of Christ who abolished death, and brought life and immortality to light through the Gospel. "But it has now been revealed through the appearing of our Saviour, Christ Jesus, who has destroyed death and has brought life and immortality to light through the gospel." (2Timothy 1:10) We look to Christ for the complete revelation concerning death.

Wisdom : Only God can reveal the mystery of life.

title: keep awake and ready
message:

BH 439: Ready

RBT: Psalms 149-150

KEEP AWAKE AND READY

Text: Matthew 25:1-13

Golden Text: “Watch therefore; for you know neither the day nor the hour whereinthe Son of man cometh.” Matthew 25:12

The parable of the ten virgins is another parable Jesus used to teach about the kingdom of heaven. Jesus used this teaching to tell us to be prepared at all times because no one knows the time or the hour the Son of Man will come. A wedding in Jesus\' day had two parts. First, the bridegroom and his friend would go from his house to claim the bride from her parents. Then the bride and groom would return to the groom\'s home.

In this parable, the ten virgins were waiting for the bridegroom when they fell asleep. when they heard the cry that the bridegroom had come, they quickly sprang to their feet, and trimmed their lamps. Unfortunately, the five foolish virgins had run out of oil; so they said to the wise virgins, "Give us some of your oil: our lamps are going out."\'No,\' they replied, \'there may not be enough for both us and you. Instead, go to those who sell oil and buy some for yourselves.\' While they were on their way to buy oil, the bridegroom arrived. The virgins who were ready went inwith him to the wedding banquet, and the door was shut. This suggests that not every churchgoer will make heaven, for some really have not trusted God, and therefore, are not saved. Jesus ended this parable with the warning He had spoken before: “watch” (Matthew 24:42; 25:13). This means we should stay awake and be alert (Matthew 26:38-41).

Wisdom : Wise people get prepared when embarking on an important project.

Food for Thought : Those who patiently wait should do so with certainty that they have enough oil in their lamps.

Follow-up Action : Keep your Christian faith bright.

MULTIPLY GOD'S GIFTS

Text: Matthew 25:14-30

Golden Text: Then he that had received the five talents went and traded with the same, and made them other five talents.(v.16)

In the parable of the talents, the man with much ability was given five talents; the man with average ability received two talents; the man with minimal ability received one talent (a talent was worth about twenty years\' wages) according to his ability. God assigns work and opportunity to man according to abilities. We are living in an era in whichpeople act like the man who was given one talent. The Scripture says, "Then the man who had received the one talent came. \'Master,\' he said, \'I knew that you are a hard man, harvesting where you have not sown and gathering where you have not scattered seed. So I was afraid and went out and hid your talent in the ground. See, here is what belongs to you.\' It is a privilege to serve the Lord and multiply His goods. The servants took their talents and put them to work for their Lord. The unfaithful servant hid his in the earth. Instead of using his opportunities, he buried them. He did not purposely do evil as it were. But by doing nothing he was committing sin and robbing his Lord of service and increase.

This parable encourages us to consciously wait for His appearing, and labour faithfully until He comes. We should watch, witness and work. We may not be successful in the eyes of men, or even popular with others, but if we are faithful and profitable, we shall receive our reward.

Wisdom : Children of God long and labour for the coming of their Lord.

Food for Thought : How have we treated and handled the gift of God?

The text before us explains how Jesus Christ will judge the nations. There are two groups in the passage: the sheep and goats. What Jesus said to the sheep was interesting. BH212: Love Lifted Me

LOVE AS I HAVE LOVED YOU

Text: John 15:12-17

Golden Text: This is My commandment, That you love one another, as I have loved you. John 15:12

On October 2, 1954, First Lieutenant James O. Conway took off from Boston Logan Airport, flying a plane that carried a load of amunitions. As the plane became airborne, he suddenly realised that he has lost control of it. Right there, he was faced with making a choice – either to eject from the plane and save his own life or crash the plane and cause his own death. If he ejected himself, the plane would crash into a neighbourhood filled with homes and families. Amazingly, Conway chose to crash the plane, giving his life for the lives of others.

Many people talk about love when they are set to exploit others or harm them.Some others who claim to love contradict what they say by the i run loving actions to those they claim to love.Jesus called love a new commandment and told the disciples to love others just as He had loved them. Loving others in the name of Jesus is a command for every Christian. We are indebted to Jesus to love others just as He has loved us.The commandment to love is not theoretical. We do not claim to love others only by saying it. Jesus demonstrated this for us when he sacrificed His own life so we can be reconciled to the Father. How much are you willing to sacrifice for the benefit of others?

Wisdom : The true test of love is in how much you are willing to give.
